author: {'steamid': '76561198031709258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 34169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34169, 'last_played': 1672939833}
review:
I have played this game ever since it came out. In total, I should have clocked around 4000-5000 hours on Civ 3 Vanilla, Play theWorld and Conquest. This game is very satisfying. I can allow myself to share the following about Civilization 3: Complete edition:

1) You can allow yourself to play with mouse only. This is not only very convenient but it is also a testimony for an almost perfect GUI.

2) Well arranged icons, buttons and menus. Everything is exactly where you expect it to be.

3) This version, the complete edition is the best you can have. Each civilization in this game feels unique and each special unit feels special. With Conquest and this Complete edition, they finally managed to find the balance.

They finally managed to fix the issue with the Great Person: it really provides +20% Scientific Output. Although, you might want or need to spend it on a Wonder?! You never know, as no two games are the same.

Always play in such a way, that you use the specific bonus for your civilization. When your special unit wins in battle, you will have a Golden Age! Never forget about that. If you are a peaceful builder, then build wonders, which triggers Golden Ages for your specific type of civilization.

Stack all "Double Scientific Output" wonders in one city.

Always try to produce an Army, which to be victorious. Then, you can build more armies and after the Pentagon, you can have 4 units per Army. After you produced the maximum amount of Armies, you can disband the oldest ones (with older obsolete units) and build a brand new one, full with the latest and deadliest units.

Do not go for dead-end research (Steam Engine, Fascism, etc.), especially if you have a small scientific lead, so that you can gain an even bigger margin. Never underestimate the power of the carrier! Always try to get Philosophy first (one free Technology), then the Great Library and then Republic. If you meanwhile manage to get some resources and roads, plus save yourself from conflicts, then you will win later in the game. If not, then Monarchy/Feudalism is the right way, especially if you will not have any luxury resources. In such scenarios, you can skip researching Republic, as there is Democracy down the line. Also, if you do not have luxury resources and nobody to trade with, then Sistine Chapel is a must.

I might one day write a "how-to play civ" manual for all civ games with the most optimum strategies for each game, according to the amount of resources, the terrain you are on and the neighboring civs around you, as per turn 10 or 15. Remember, every turn counts and sometimes games are being lost for 1-2 turns.

Never-ever underestimate Espionage! Never!

I love this game! One more turn for life! One more turn till I die!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057734042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 38830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 908, 'playtime_at_review': 20530, 'last_played': 1710811369}
review: So I am a poor old man and I cannot afford a nice computer right now. Life. I can play CIV III on my little weenie hp laptop. I have CIV VI, and played it a great deal, but CIV III it is until I get a computer with the guts to run it. What I have found is this: the older versions are far more combat oriented. I suspected as much, as religion became more important in later versions, as did diplomacy, with the addition of city-states. The simplicity of the earlier versions lends to conquest victories, as cultural and diplomatic victories offer little in regards to actual gameplay. These victory types seem much more passive in CIV III. But I love this version, because the AI is brutal and unforgiving. You cannot make mistakes, you always pay. I believe that makes these versions a tad more realistic in feel, though low reward visually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089787824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1672436513}
review: Civ 1 and 2 are way more customizable, the map choices suck considering civ 1 had the real world map as an option and this game doesnt. There is a map seed system but there is no way to browse the seeds, the game has a ton of limits that dont exist in 1 and 2. You cant even play forever the game ends after a maxed out 1000 turns so you cant just keep playing forever to get max tech. I didnt even get past the menus and i knew the game would suck compared to 1 and 2. So far my favorite civ game is still the SNES game after all these years. The lack of map options is unacceptable considering this game is like 50x bigger than the SNES game and they couldnt even put planet earth in the game. Also the game keeps crashing, its not fully compatible with modern PCs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844146206', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1701880681}

author: {'steamid': '76561197967255834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2717, 'last_played': 1686268898}
review: I grew up on CIV 2 and have puts 100s of hours into 5/6 as an adult.  I decided to jump in the wayback machine and give this game a spin as its one in the series I missed... boy does it not hold up.  I'm a competent civ player and can usually win up 2 difficulties from medium in modern civ games, without too much trouble. I'm playing this one on EASY and every other AI has declared war on me despite me having a strong army, getting wonders is a struggle, combat is an endless slog despite the dumb AI throwing units away.  Compared to modern games the UI sucks, the music sucks,  the combat sucks because its incredibly RNG dependent and one unit will always die (unlike modern games where there is RNG but usually well positioned units won't die to a single attacker).  I'm sure it was revolutionary for its day but this one does not hold up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063463096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 12693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11496, 'last_played': 1671339639}
review:
i got civ 6 for free on epic and was playing it and enjoying myself until i realized the game is broken in that the computer never builds any army (even on the hardest difficulty) which makes the game pointless i decided to try 3 again which i loved back in the day on CD and man this game is just so much more balanced so much more fun, music and presentation is top notch and AI is smart. before i just face checked swordman and  tanks now i am using all the different types of units and they work so well together. This game is so much better than 6. If you've never tried this game its 5 dollars and will be well more than worth the money.

BTW this is an old game and has minor non game breaking issues on steam, to skip the opening cut scene after booting do not click, instead hit escape or your game will crash. There used to be different music when trading depending on the time period and mood of the civ leader but its not there now which is a very small non gameplay thing. (your only in that screen for a few minutes a game). lastly when when you complete the game you'll go through the awesome post game screens i think its when the barbarian hits the carnival meter with the hammer to tell you how much you suck, again do not click or it will freeze hit escape i believe. That all i have encountered.

I CRASHED??- there is an auto-save feature so don't rage quit if the game crashes on you which even used to happen on the disk version too i've crashed 3 times in 180 hours so not too bad all you need to do is load game and there should be an autosave tab you will only lose a turn or 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104006467', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3319, 'last_played': 1689430257}
review:
Умерли грузин, хохол и еврей. И, попав на приём к богу, все втроём взмолились:
— Отпусти нас обратно на землю, мало мы пожили ещё, молодые совсем.
— Хорошо,—ответил им бог,—но только до первого соблазна.
И вот очутились они на земле, в каком-то доме. Видят: стол накрыт, жратвы на нем видимо-невидимо. Только сел хохол за стол — тут же пропал.
А грузин и еврей вышли из дома и пошли дальше. Вдруг видят на дороге 100 долларов лежат. Еврей наклонился за деньгами и пропали оба.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128809394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 94, 'playtime_at_review': 2618, 'last_played': 1710521497}
review:
So much nostalgia here. I remember when my uncle showed this to me when I was 5 or 6. I thought it was so cool even though I didn't understand it. When I was about 9, we got it on our family computer and I played for hours upon hours, even though I sucked. It's an absolute gem of a game that holds up to its sequels.

If you're looking for a blast to the past in turn based strategy, this is your game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125618289', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1669015494}
review:
When i first played Sid Meier´s Civilization I was almost 10 years old. And yes, it was the first part. I didn´t had my own PC and played with my friend Benjamin on his father´s Computer. I was so excited about the game that I told everyone from the 4000 BC timeline until about 2000 AD. The cities and nations, which you could expand at will, were such a nice game concept that when I wasn´t sitting in front of the computer with Bejamin, I would spend hours in my children´s room imagining how our civilization might be progressing.

The second part of Civilization was published almost 5 years later. In the meantime I had my own PC. So I already played the second part extensively and had partly built up such large nations that the rounds seemed endless to me. I still remember a score with Russia on the real map; it was one of my greatest saves in Civilization II.

Sid Meier´s Civilization III was published in 2001. When i heard about it, I immediately ran to the computer store near my parents´house. I begged my parents until they agreed to buy me a new PC. So, i ran back to the computer store and bought a new PC for Civilization III.

And I have to say it was the best Civilization of all time up to that point. The intro was cinematic at the time and the animated units enthralled me so much I thought I was in Sid Meier heaven. The expansion of the palace is also still present in this part, wich was taken over from the first part.

Okay, you could see this text as a clumsy advertisement for Sid Meier´s Civilization series. But in truth, only the little boy is speaking here, who sat down in front of the game Civilization a long time ago and has been a real Sid Meier fan ever since.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030373895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 47838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1457, 'playtime_at_review': 16383, 'last_played': 1710330679}
review:
I have played this game since I was 8 back before there was a Conquest DLC let alone a complete edition and it still my favorite of any of the Civ titles. It doesn't have the polish, expanded features or animations of VI but  it definitely has the feel of those fantastic early 2000's games that can't be replicated nowadays. That quirky charm is huge here and unlike some of the other nostalgic games of the time, this doesn't have nearly the same difficulty curve. If you set it to a higher difficulty the AI will definitely make quick work of you but lower ones make it enjoyable to discover or get your bearings after not playing it for 20ish years. Absolute banger as far as I'm concerned.

Also the music is best in any Civ title. Fight me.

author: {'steamid': '76561199126053950', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1665864523}
review:
This game is ridiculously complex, incorporating concepts of culture, war exploration, manpower and resource management at a ridiculously high level, well, everyone knows Civ... And it's the best of the 6.

It has no built-in support for widescreen or windowed mode, but at least you can get widescreen support by editing the .INI file and setting the KeepResolution=1 variable, which will make it respect your desktop resolution.

Unfortunately, there is currently no decent workaround to make it work in windowed mode.

This one and FreeCiv are simply the two best civs we have at the moment, Civ 6 can suck my dick.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031222112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3648, 'last_played': 1701885012}
review:
Toujours aussi envoûtant après toutes ces années. 
D'une grande efficacité et rejouabilité. Aucune partie n'est identique. 
Le plus grand CIV jamais crée, avec le IV en second. Le V et le VI ne sont que de pâles ersatz ou on passe de la gestion d'un empire a celui d'une cité état. 
Même les graphismes ont leur charme.

review: No doubt this is a great game. You can get it for super cheap. I grew up playing Civ 4 and I just enjoy that one way more than this one. I am sure this is a great nostalgia drip for some people. I'll stick with 4 and if you are trying out the series I would recommend 4 over 3.

Overall: Civ 3 is one of the classics that brought me into civilization series. I have probably hundreds of hours in this game if we include my disc playtime. This game has a lot of depth that may not be noticed at a first glance. Coupled with the dlc you'll have a civ 4 experience for the most part. Game graphics are pretty old but fitting for a 2001 game. The music is nostalgic and inspiring/relaxing. There are plenty of mods and maps on the forums still being made today. This game has steep difficulty spike as the Ai cheat in a a lot of ways and have no problem landing musketmen on your shores while you're still learning how to make walls in your cities. The combat is very rng heavy allowing for the infamous spearman beating a tank situation to happen. Get this game if you're looking to play a cheap civilization that still holds it's weight. You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055378035', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 17366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2226, 'last_played': 1665532553}
review:
Esse jogo é ridiculamente complexo, envolvendo noções de cultura, reconhecimento bélico, força de trabalho e gestão de recursos em um nível ridiculamente elevado, bom, todo mundo conhece o Civ... E esse é o melhor dos 6.

Ele carece de suporte nativo à widescreen ou modo janela mas pelo menos o wide você pode conseguir editando o arquivo .INI dele colocando a variável KeepResolution=1, o que faz ele respeitar sua resolução Desktop.

Infelizmente até o presente momento não existe um workaround decente para fazer ele rodar em modo janela.

Esse e o FreeCiv são simplesmente os dois melhores civvies que temos no momento, Civ 6 pode chupar minha rola.

author: {'steamid': '76561198982891119', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1662829155}
review:
As a looot of people have said, this game has one of the most broken ai ever made. I can fully accept the fact a lot of shooters or adventure games have clucky ai, it's not fine but hard to change. But really, strategy? With simple hex system? Regardless of difficulty you choose, every time you get invaded or just "metastasized" by any civilization (Zulu in Berlin bruh). No matter how hard you try, they obviously cheat and spam hordes of units. It could be defying, but became tiring and boring. Once you get your first medieval unit, yo "great neighbors" already spam knights and siege-weapones and prepare to invade your ass. I don't even know, what the New time looks like, cause I haven't ever survived till it:)

Buy only if your time costs nothing and your patience is as  huge as Zulu sword

author: {'steamid': '76561199272464309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1661963810}
review: It doesnt show the Advisor screen, you cant control your funding and other stuff.. all the background is loaded, but the values on the sliders and such things arent shown. I saw a post from a decade or so ago with the same issue, unanswered. I looked around, tried normal way, tried editing the conquest.ini files with recommendations I found on forums, but no. You're literally better off finding a cracked version, cause those guys do make necessary adjustments to the game to run on modern systems.. or they at the very least have an instruction accompanying the file(s), to explain how to get it to run. Alternatively I saw Gog has it, I bet theirs runs better. edit: Yup, bought the GoG one and it works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050455318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1700537791}
review:
As someone who has played quite a bit of Civ IV, V, and VI, this game is a whole different animal than the newer ones. It's relatively simple, there arent many menus and UI elements so if youre coming from the newer games itll feel like youre missing a lot of information. Mechanically there isn't a ton of depth either, the focus is on expanding like crazy and then micromanaging your population and finances and everything more intently vs the more specialized mechanics and strategies of the newer games. It makes each game and all of your cities feel pretty generalized and the game itself have a lot less character to be honest. All in all it seems much more like a scaled-up, turn based version of Age of Empires than what I'm used to from Civ at this point. Its also extremely long, research is way slower and you stay in each era much longer than the other games as well, which isn't inherently a bad thing if you like longer games anyway (I usually play epic speed in the other games so it doesn't really bother me). Edit: I'm realizing that there are less "eras" in the game than in its sequels, eg. the ancient and classical era are merged, medieval and renaissance are merged, etc. so each age is much longer but there are fewer of them so it probably balances out.

I will give it a thumbs up, I didnt entirely dislike it though it doesnt scratch the same itch. I do especially like the atmosphere of the game, the visuals and music are pretty interesting. I'll probably come back to it at some point when I feel I want something to fill that niche. And considering its very cheap I would say its worth picking it up and trying it regardless. I do recommend looking up a guide for your first game if youre coming from the newer games like me, the flow of the game is just so different and a lot of concepts dont translate over as much as you would think.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999854019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 66901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60341, 'last_played': 1661579327}
review: First, 20+ year old game, so graphics are primitive. BUT, intricate and detailed turn based strategy. Still a lot of mods (and modders) out there. May need a few tweaks to function on anything past Win7, but well worth it. There is a REASON why this series is legendary. WARNING - the "One More Turn" syndrome is strong here. You may find yourself looking up and discovering you have spent the whole night playing. I have been a fan of this series since Civ 1, on 3.5 inch floppies for my 386 machine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003185277', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 12455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11497, 'last_played': 1684410733}
review:
+ Comfy 2.5D graphics
+ Charming things lost in later games: create-your-own palace, city view, and leaders' outfits changing through the ages (Genghis Khan in a suit!)
+ First in series to introduce culture, cultural victories
+ First in series to introduce unique civ traits
+ Happiness is city-by-city instead of global
+ Challenging combat; beating AI at Prince is harder than Civ V Immortal

- This game is REALLY hard. If you normally play Warlord/Prince on Civ 5/6, you will not even survive the ancient era. 200 hours in I can only beat Emperor (normal)
- Combat can get tedious because of unit stacking, late game is a nightmare
- Building "tall" is not possible. You will get steamrolled if you have 4 cities to the AI's 32
- UI is just "OK" but if you've played Civ you'll get it

Anecdotal, but I had almost zero problem getting this running on Windows 10/11.

review:
Civilization III

When you have experienced franchises like this from the very first one you can not be disappointed unless the developers do something really stupid.

Thankfully they kept it close to its origins.

With several newer ones out, it doesn’t hurt with these older ones, yes the graphics are obviously older but the essence of the game is there.

For the collection, sure why not.

Recommended : Why not
Replayability : A rough yes
Drawbacks : It’s just an older game

-Universal Gamer

review:
之前一直玩的盗版，现在来补票。
非常好的游戏，即使在21年后的今天玩起来仍然趣味十足。席德梅尔的文明有着独特的魅力，很少有游戏能把历史宗教地理军事政治等因素如此完美的结合起来，Civilization让其变成了可能。

author: {'steamid': '76561199028191756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 38813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3233, 'playtime_at_review': 22749, 'last_played': 1710863442}
review:
Well, 20 years later it runs on Win 10 and is still the same badly balance faux war game , AI cheating, time wasting  key banging game it was then.
The distribution  of resources on large  maps is still dreadful, play Rome  on a big map and you will likely get no Iron which means no UU that  m,eans the Unique  Unit of the specific Civ. ( the Legion here ), play  India, no  elephants, an on it goes.  On a big map, if you don`t get Iron and Horses No Win no way. If your an old player re- playing this is like the old joke about re-marring your divorced wife, it is  a triumphant of Hope over Experience.  Save your life. Read a book. Talk to a friend.

 New on 1/24  where are all these "New " great reviews from, small  map players , game over in an hour guys, or some other...emmm.  It really is an unfinished, poor  4x game.

review: Not only is this game very nostalgic, it's just all around a great game. Simple and enjoyable to play but can also have the difficult scaled to whatever challenge you're feeling up to. I think the newer Civilizations games have become overcomplicated and the art style has become too cartoony, but maybe that's just me being a boomer about it. Regardless, if you're looking for a fun turn based strategy game that won't melt your computer, this is it.

review: I enjoyed playing the game. It was very much like I remembered many years ago. Only part I would change is the issue of time (turns) the game maxes out at the year 2050. Even if you change the max turns it still will only go that long. Hard to dominate max opponents by rolling over their pikemen with tanks and bombers if you limit the length the game will play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198379417772', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1657385006}
review: This game SUCKS! I played the newer Civ games before and they were way better than this. The controls are so stupid, I can't even find an explanation on Google to tell me how to fucking attack! I sat idly by as other civilizations were taking over my cities, unable to do anything but defend! Clicking on enemy units does nothing. There's no button on the screen for it either. The escape key just exits the game, no ingame settings while you are in a match. I don't care that it's an older game, plenty of games during that time had tutorials and tooltips and control schemes listed in the ingame menu!!! There's an option in the main menu that says "Tutorial", but I ticked it on and there was still no tutorial! What the actual fuck? Many options in this game are broken or don't even work at all! I will say that the price I paid for it was about right ($2.00USD), but I wish I didn't even spend that. I won't even be playing this at all anymore. Waste of time and money. Civilization: Revolution on the Xbox was an amazing game compared to this. And that was just "aight".

author: {'steamid': '76561198052825265', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7784, 'last_played': 1668656912}
review: This is a nostalgia game for me, having said that though, I prefer this style of turn based strategy (or the total war series) over the newer civ games. For an old game brought up without a remaster/remake, it works surprisingly well. It does crash occasionally, and the music does stutter for me constantly (i turn off the game volume through my computer's volume mixer when that happens), but its very playable and enjoyable for me. Also there's an autosave every turn and it keeps the most recent 3, so if you crash, its easy to recover. Alt tabbing is a bit difficult due to very low resolution the game runs in though.

review: So far its a dud. I played this game years ago and loved it, but it will not run in Steam on Win10. The opening video runs fine, but at the end, the screen goes dark and and error message pops up saying "Input Not Support" - yes, verbatim - it says "support" not "supported."

Головним нововведенням мабуть є ресурси. Тепер не все можна створити маючи певний рівень технологій. Треба ще мати певні ресурси щоб почати робити наприклад конні війська, чи залізну зброю. always loved this game. spent days on this game in the past with no sleep back in the day throw on headphones your favorite playlist and time just eludes me lol. 
I just finished my first game in maybe 10+ years they change  some stuff over the years i have not checked out everything just yet but this game will always be one my favorites. one this i never like was 2050 year end game for victory conditions most time had to go pass it for tech/war etc. this new game i was in 2200 or something still going atm. author: {'steamid': '76561198361137972', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 16214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16214, 'last_played': 1647536149}
review:
經典回合制4X遊戲。

可控的操作項目多且細，
諸如城市生產、修路灌溉、升兵建築、部隊調動等等，
甚至可以調整城市內的生產格和市民職業，
以及科技樹和娛樂的預算分配，
資料片的內容也很豐富。

缺點部分，
單兵作戰運氣成分太高，簡直在靠賽。
離首都遠的城市貪汙超級高，很難發展起來。
電腦只要不是選最弱等級，控制的城市都buff不少，
小島城市最明顯，同等條件的小島玩家控制的城市發展受限，
有那種只能養3個人的，電腦卻能突破系統限制到7、8個人，
整體來說難度高，但是都高在一些很奇怪的地方。

author: {'steamid': '76561198077501600', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3618, 'last_played': 1693681539}
review:
Before talking about the game in itself, I want to say thank you to Sid Meier about the franchise. At the beginning a video game adaptation of the Civilization board game, it began to be a universe of its own. I've played every single games from Sid Meier the first being Civilization III. this game defined my entire personality and made me discover at the age of four countless cultures and heroes. I'm glad to have grown with Civilization III and Age of Empires II. 

This game is in my opinion the best of the franchise. I don't care about graphics when the gameplay and overall design is of this quality. When I was a kid I've played this game for hundred of hours without being bored and I didn't have the complete edition at that time. The excitement of finding the original game on steam (my cd is too old for windows 10 and 11) with double the number of civs that I remembered plus scenarios plus the original map editor... It was too much. If like me you grow with this game, you can understand the overall joy of finding this masterpiece.

The gameplay is fantastic, as good as I remembered. You have unique game mechanics that no other Civ games retried. It is a shame and at the same time makes it rare gem. To name a few of theses unique mechs: the palace, the best diplomacy system of all civ Games, custom civilization principle, easy city management...

if you like graphics with big flashing screens and Uncanny Valley Nightmares you will find this game outdated and boring. Civ III does not give instant gratification. It also has a comedic tone with the leader portraits that are changing in each era. Civ VI may have been inspired by the goofy and well tought designs of some characters from Civ III, while Civ V is more serious.

On the multiplayer level, I can't say much.  I never were a multiplayer guy for Strategy games. But I intend to do it soon. I did some games with my brother and AI but not full players. However the multiplayer screen is well optimized.

However I've found some disturbing bugs and compatibility problems in this version that can break the entire experience. For instance, you will never hear the diplomacy sound of leaders because of the two channel trouble. Also when you finish a game and click on the X button, the game will freeze. You must click on Esc. This is ruining the game in some ways but some awesome individuals found the solution to these bugs.

To conclude: If you enjoy good gameplay over graphics, this game is for you. The game was well put into modern computers and i wish the same thing could be done to Civ I and Civ II that were also fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972447046', 'num_games_owned': 921, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 8441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8402, 'last_played': 1658725146}

review: Best turned based strategy game i have ever played. In may opinion the newer civ games not as good game play different and is a turn off for me. This game however 20 years later still has me playing hours at a time always different and infinite scenarios. The game can be buggy through steam with startup issues and once and a while auto shut down but I think the game is still great just save frequently. The buggy issues should be addressed I would happily pay $$$ for remastered version to fix game play issues. There are some games that don't need to remade just updates this is one. Been waiting since 2001...

review:
Sid Meier and his team crafted a game to stand the test of time.

There are a lot of bugs, but they are all well known, and they don't make the game a bad experience. There is a reason that this 20+ year old game still has a small but thriving community, and that is because it is a pure 4x experience with a strong focus on being a pure implementation of what it is supposed to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119130352', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 29588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22103, 'last_played': 1688762055}
review:
//Edit:
 This game is completly about RNG not about Your "skill"... i mean it SOMETIMES do matter and it can help... but imagine that im starting game, its giving me just a banana and tons of jungles all around, then i discover rome... guess what they got on capitol?...

River that Covers 11 tiles ( +11 Gold ) Wines x5 ( thats a lot of extra gold and food ) Hills and Bonus Grasslands ( that gives a lot of shields = fast production ) 

and im sitting with a fking BANANA IN JUNGLE... they comes to me... they demand my technologies... i dont give them and they declare war to me... 

Its all about fking RNG if You get really bad start You can't do shit...
 Other time i was playing on Archipelag with 60% Water...

i got spawned on tiny islands with 2 computers... i was able to put 5 cities...
 and guess what... ONE COMPUTER SPAWNED ON GIANT CONTINENT AND HAD LIKE 20 NEW CITY 2... when You build many many many cities and game is running out of names for cities it just names them with "new" in front so for example "New Berlin" etc. if game runs out of "New City" names it starts with numberst at the end... "New Berlin 2" etc...

So yee... i was sitting and having war with 2 computers with 5 cities...
meanwhile one computer was able to build so many fking cities i would never be able to defeat him no matter fking what...


And searching for good spawn is so F annoying... 
 most of the time You are getting Snow, Desert, Jungle, Swamps...

Snow is just killing You... You can't do anything about that no matter what culture / tech... only way to build City on snow is building near coast so u can build Harbor asap and get food from water...

Desert is unplayable unless u play with Agriculture Civilisation that can actualy make use of desert... but its still better to play on Grasslands and have it for FREE

Jungle and Swamps are possible to be fixed to Grasslands...
 IN ONLY 20 TURNS / TILE OFC !...

20 Turns is worth ( in time ) 5 Roads ( +5Gold ) 
20 Turns is worth ( in time ) connecting two cities...
20 Turns is worth building Castle...

but ofc. You can also spend 20 turns to make your tile playable...

if You spawn in middle of Jungle like no single tile of grassland You can't even build settler ( unless u play agri / granary ) - unless u have banana or some other luxury...


Skill do help...
like for example if You first research Writing... then Philosophy and then switch to Math
 Math you getting for free ( not even single turn research )

or build order... many ppl don't know what to build and when...
 How corruption works etc... but even if they do... they can't rly do anything if having really terrible spawn...

this is a great game. incredible. but i cant recommend it. 

this appears to be an issue on modern systems and is only becoming more common over the years
the game wont launch or you may get into the menu and it will crash upon clicking anything. 

try the game on anything site, GOG perhaps or on disk. if that fails through less than legal means may be the only option 

windows 7 worked and i don't remember any issues with 8. the game launched ONCE perfectly fine on windows 10 and every time after that it was a instant crash upon reaching the menu or it would not open at all. validating files or reinstalling does nothing

author: {'steamid': '76561198139989914', 'num_games_owned': 16, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 26128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24599, 'last_played': 1676937119}
review:
My review is only going to be geared towards people who have played other Civilization games, since I think the odds of coming across Civ3 before the others is really low.

This game does not have the variety of effective playstyles that other games offer. However, the balance of thr game and the quality of the scenarios is as good as it gets.

Running an effective empire is far more micro-management intensive than in any other installment in the series. Resources like food and production are not stockpiled in cities, so they will have to have their yields carefully observed to be as efficient as possible. You also have to deal with and manage corruption draining away at your resources. This extra skillset is not completely necessary, however, unless you want to tackle the higher difficulty levels (Demigod+).

Additionally, there is less of a focus on diplomacy than you may be used to in later Civilization games. A lot of the disposition modifers are not explained in-game properly and you will need the wiki.

The highlight of this game is in the warfare and military-industrial complex. Being able to field and fund an effective army while simultaneously growing your empire tall and wide is the most important aspect of Civilization 3. Units stack on top of each other, so controlling chokepoints and defensive positions is far more effective. There are other nuances, but this is just an example.

Overall, I think this game is definitely worth buying if you enjoyed any other Civilization game. It is especially recommended if you enjoyed the turn-based combat of other games.

As a bonus if you read this far, I’ve ranked the scenarios in order of which are the most fun to play (or replay over and over, like I have):

1. Middles Ages — well-balanced scenario with new units and technologies
2. Rise of Rome — elongated version of ancient era, with a heavy focus on military and expansion instead of building tall
3. Sengoku - Sword of the Shogun — new tech tree and resources, fresh take on the game after you’ve gotten bored of vanilla
4. Napoleonic Wars — simulates regular game industrial warfare well
5. Wonders of the Ancient World — Extended “ancient” era, but fun map
6. Age of Discovery — Fun concept, but very short scenario
7. Mesoamerica — Extended “ancient” tech tree
8. Fall of Rome — Pay attention to the Elimination ruleset
9. WWII in the Pacific — It’s actually terrible. I don’t recommend playing it at all unless you are a completionist

author: {'steamid': '76561198204549563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 44441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36302, 'last_played': 1692216595}
review:
It's inexpensive if you like the nostalgia. The battle sequences are incredibly foreseeable... meaning that the computer wins pretty much every time. Be prepared to save and reload a whole, whole lot if you wanna win any battles in this antiquitous game.

Imagine the rules governing a battle almost ALWAYS giving the nod to the computer.

Also, as soon as you jump from the easiest difficulty you are immediately greeted with a FAR superior enemy capability and not just in battle. Literally every enemy on the third lowest difficulty will have four or five tech advances while you're struggling to do anything.

It's just rather absurd. I'd recommend buying newer versions of this game. It's not even the money, I simply don't recommend anybody wasting their time. For me this game is darn near unplayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055801446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 178686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1330, 'playtime_at_review': 96781, 'last_played': 1710893741}
review:
There's a new (unofficial) expansion pack for Civ 3 called "2021 EXPANSION". It greatly improves graphics and modernizes the interface. It can be downloaded for free from the CivFanatics site:    
 https://forums.civfanatics.com/resources/2021-expansion.28973/        

Some of the features:
   - Fresh colorful graphics that look more realistic
   - HD and 4K resolution possible
   - Mega maps with all 31 civs
   - 11 new units
   - Improved unit balance
   - Smarter A.I. that follows different research strategies
   - A.I. will use (lots of) artillery when attacking
   - Removes many bugs

  See the mod page at CivFanatics for more detailed info

review: When I was young, I used to play CIV II with my dad. We would spend long hours forging an empire and nuking Gandhi, just having a great time. One day, he came home from work late with a brand new game, CIV III. I remember being enamored by the new features and magnitude of this game. We quickly moved on from II to III in a heartbeat and I never stopped. III is my favorite entry into the series. Always has been since then and always will be.

review: Get ready for a non-intuitive hard mode even on the easiest difficulty.  If you want to do well you either have to look up guides and copy pasta the strategy (which feels like you are exploiting the game), or you have to ram your head into it repeatedly and learn by trial and error (which defeats the whole purpose of enjoying a game).  If you like self-torture, this is the game for you, and you don't even get achievements.....

author: {'steamid': '76561198015202184', 'num_games_owned': 525, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 27525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27525, 'last_played': 1647618301}
review:
A review from me to me

Decided to revisit civ 3 for one game after more than a decade.

Due to tech trading the AI will constantly breathe down your neck. They will have modern armies capable of waging war in the later eras.
Techs are also consistently used as bargaining chips in war declarations and peace talks.
The AI is acting irrational sometimes declaring suicidal wars when they have nothing to gain (except maybe raze an unprotected city deep within your borders).
Mutual protection pacts are very weird as they can be signed while you are at war, and will only trigger when your are attacked within your own borders.
You can pay other AI to join one of your wars (20 turn military alliance), and if you don't your opponents just might. You cannot bribe your opponents into wars you don't take part in, nor can you negotiate peace treaties for other civilizations.
There are no denouncements, friend declarations or economic alliances but you can at least sign trade embargoes.

Units are fairly cheap and expendable. They have to fight to the death unless they are able to retreat. You need a few dozen units to successfully wage a war. This leads to the game devolving to a few stacks of doom, as there is no 1 unit per tile limitation. An unchecked AI might attack you with hundreds of units while pushing dozens more per turn. Bombardment units are very strong when amassed. Airplanes can even kill units. Units need transports to travel across the sea. All units cost 1 commerce per turn, unless they are captured (workers, siege) so you are encouraged to maintain a modern military.

Slavery is weak for rushing projects (offering only 20 production per citizen sacrifice and lowering the city happiness for 20 turns). But it can be used as a tool for ethnic cleansing.
There is no production overflow (meaning you need to optimize the number of production a city is making to avoid wasting turns). There is also no research overflow, meaning you need to lower the slider before completing a tech.
The land grab by the AI in the early game is insane, and you need about 20 cities to prosper (too many cities to manage for my taste).
You can swap production at any time to any project, which means all wonders will disappear in rapid succession as the AI just swaps to the next available wonder. You can also prebuild with an expensive building before unlocking a new wonder. Chopping woods does not add production to a wonder.

The citizen ethnicity system is great (each citizen maintains their ethnicity on the map as free captured workers and inside cities where they will protest against war on their motherland. There is a small chance citizens are assimilated each turn based on your government. In the later game you can draft your population into conscript combat troops, but only your own nationals.

Cities need aqueducts and hospitals to grow past specific population limits (6, 12).
Infrastructure is very strong usually offering 50% yield bonuses.
Luxuries are very strong and fun to collect.
Since happiness is local and the settler cost does not scale up the only limiting factor to your expansion is higher and higher corruption.

The governments are fairly distinct and interesting. Revolution duration on the other hand is random and unfun (you lose 2 to 8 turns) if you're not religious.
Despotism debuff is awkward to work with as only a few resources are capable of providing more than 2 food. Republic and Democracy extra commerce bonus is not clearly described.
Your capital's location is crucial for your empire's productivity and corruption makes distant colonies almost unworkable. But at least it can be moved if you can afford the production.

Land is boring as there's only grassland, plains, desert, tundra, hills and mountains. Only flatland is able to support features like forests, jungles and marshes. They serve no purpose other than being removed (forests provide a measly 10 production, allow no improvements and protect somewhat against desertification)
Mountains are passable so it is harder to create choke points. The square grid also doesn't help. You need to make barricades in your border towns so that the AI cannot attack them in 1 turn. 
Improvements are boring, there are only mines and irrigation. Resources need only a road to be connected.
Roads are your empire's financial backbone due to their 1 commerce yield (especially under a Republic or Democracy). This means all land will have roads and railroads, making the landscape very ugly.
The land map is made out of squares which makes movement inferior to hexes.
Cities can only reach 2 tiles away from the city center (they can work at most 20 tiles), meaning there is rarely a reason to go over 20 population.
Late game you can fine tune the exact population number of a city based on its surrounding land (by turning irrigations to mines, training workers or drafting).
Since workers are so cheap you can force grow a new city by feeding workers into it.

Other than luxuries, strategic resources, techs and diplomatic agreements there isn't much to trade.
Espionage is somewhat useful. There is no religion.

Only one unit is required to capture/raze a city. (if undefended)
Units can freely trespass through your land opening you up to ugly sneak attacks. You can ask them to pull out but they might declare war (without being evicted from your lands).
You get a small return of production when you disband units in a city, making it possible to funnel production into it.
Re basing airplanes has unlimited range (OP). You can also re base nukes to submarines.
Armies pillage for free and can attack multiple times in a turn (OP).
Air bombing is realistic. You either damage/kill units, destroy city buildings, kill population or miss.

With the huge number of units in a war, it can get very tedious to control, especially since the game will annoyingly keep jumping between 'random' units. I get war weariness as fast as my population.
Pollution clean-up is annoying since you need to reassign the citizen to the tile.

The game is less complex than 4, 5 or 6. But still has an interesting charm and some unique features.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035093703', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2381, 'last_played': 1703465944}
review:
A pesar que los nuevos civs mejoraron casi todos los aspectos, los gráficos vieja escuela con pixeles de este siguen teniendo su magia. Además es el último en el que podemos ver nuestra ciudad en un zoom.
No es excluyente disfrutar de este y los otros, ya que quizás quieras jugar este por sus gráficos, la música (que es muy buena) o algunas mecánicas.
No olvides expandirte rápidamente con hartas ciudades, mejorar cada casilla de terreno de tu imperio con los trabajadores y rezar durante el combate, porque nunca puedes esperar que tu unidad de élite de una era posterior derrote al oponente más débil.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023974103', 'num_games_owned': 856, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1599345627}
review:
[i]Disclaimer: I own this on both Steam and GOG and play it only on GOG now, but I figured I should post a review here as well, since it's such a great game.[/i]

The 4X strategy genre can be a bit overwhelming and difficult to get into (though not as tough as grand strategy) but there are a couple games that have solid tutorials and less of a steep learning curve. Endless Space 2 and Stellaris come to mind at first, but...

... I'd be remiss to not talk about just how fantastic Civilization 3 is. Widely considered to be the greatest in the series, and one of the greatest 4X games of all time, Civ 3 is a brilliant example of why this genre is so fun. The progression design of the Civ series matches perfectly with the gameplay of the genre, allowing the player to begin at the start of a civilization and build their empire up through constant progression. That progression, however, is entirely up to the player. Want to be diplomatic and avoid wars? You can build your empire to do that. Prefer to just stomp on your enemies and conquer the world? Again, you can build your empire to do that. Want to isolate yourself for scientific progression or build a civilization upon trade? Those are also options.

In Civ 3, you never feel like you're being overwhelmed by a million gameplay systems but at the same time, you also never feel like you're being limited. In general, 4X is basically a sandbox take on turn-based strategy gaming and if you know me, you know I like my sandbox games. You may have heard that the Civilization games have always had that "one more turn" sort of gameplay and they are not joking. Every time I start up this game, I end up spending WAY more time than I planned to because it becomes addictive: you always want to take one more turn toward building your armies, or wonders of the world or progressing toward the next scientific unlock. You're always progressing to your goals.

I wouldn't say it's my absolute favorite 4X strategy game; that would be Stellaris. However, it is a landmark game that any strategy gamer should at least check out at some point. For that price point, really can't go wrong!

author: {'steamid': '76561198295255781', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 6249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6249, 'last_played': 1646874398}
review:
Un juego que tiene más de 20 años, todo un clásico, muy adictivo y tan divertido como frustrante.

Resumiendo: el juego trata de rellenar el mapa a base de ciudades e influencia cultural anticipándose a las civilizaciones rivales, hay que ser rápido explorando y fundando ciudades en puntos estratégicos donde tengamos acceso a todo tipo de recursos que necesitará nuestra civilización para su pleno desarrollo sin descuidar la fuerza militar, la economía, la ciencia y el bienestar de la población.

Es muy divertido siempre y cuando las cosas nos vayan más o menos bien porque la CPU es bastante rápida y acosadora, rápidamente nos irá cercando con ciudades alrededor de las nuestras e incluso cuando estamos llevando a un colono a un punto aparece un colono de otra civilización y nos planta una ciudad en un punto donde nos fastidia nuestra estrategia.

Podemos elegir entre 8 niveles de dificultad pero ese es el problema de este juego y es que cuando dominamos las tres dificultades más sencillas a partir de la cuarta dificultad se vuelve endiablada, no se puede tener ni el más mínimo fallo porque se arma una revuelta en la ciudad perdiendo el turno de producción en esa ciudad, la CPU funda ciudades, desarrolla la ciencia, crea maravillas y genera unidades a una velocidad tramposa, en la guerra no te deja de acosar con innumerables unidades asediando tus ciudades hasta tomarlas y en los enfrentamientos atacando por ejemplo con un espadachín con 3 de ataque a un lancero que tiene 2 de defensa te deja al espadachín para el arrastre o incluso lo derrota pero cuando la CPU ataca es muy raro que le pase eso, normalmente gana.

Conclusión: lo valoraría positivo por la nostalgia y por las horas de diversión que nos puede llegar a ofrecer en sus modos de dificultad más sencillo pero el hecho de que los niveles de dificultad se basen en que la CPU juega con ventajas y en que vaya siempre un par de pasos por delante hace desmerecer este gran clásico.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995594502', 'num_games_owned': 1265, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1761, 'last_played': 1646962916}
review:
[b][i]Resumo: [/i][/b][i]Civilization III é um jogo que vale a pena jogar se você gostou de outros jogos da série, mas ele tem uma sensação que se aproxima mais de um jogo de tabuleiro do que de um jogo digital. O jogo tem algumas mecânicas bem complexas que foram removidas nos jogos seguintes, então se você busca complexidade, você pode preferir esse ao invés de outros jogos da franquia. Entretanto, algumas mecânicas são nebulosas, então pesquisar sobre o jogo é parte fundamental pra derrotas a AI em dificuldades acima de regente.[/i]

Irei avaliar nos 4X de estratégia: [b]eXplorar, eXpandir, eXtrair, eXterminar. [/b]Deixo notado aqui, também, que as 30 horas de jogo foram apenas in-game, mas também passei um adicional de cerca de 20 horas explorando conteúdo fora do jogo.

[h1]EXPLORAR[/h1]
A exploração aqui significa que o jogo deve dar a possibilidade do jogador descobrir o mapa em frequência diferente de outros jogadores. No CIV III o jogador começa com visão de uma pequena área do mapa com todo o resto escurecido por uma névoa. Ao longo do jogo, cada jogador vai explorando e descobrindo recursos, que nos levam a etapa de expansão.

CIV III tem uma exploração ok, mas não é nada fenomenal, porque a maior parte das civilizações estão presas num mesmo ritmo no early game de explorar com guerreiros, que tem uma taxa baixa de movimentação. Além disso, as vilas que podem ser capturadas quase sempre são negativas. Agora, se você for uma civilização que tenha a característica de expansão, você ganha acesso a batedores, que tem uma velocidade muito boa, além de ganhar melhores rolagens nas vilas. Com uma civilização de expansão, a exploração é bem divertida.

[h1]EXPANDIR[/h1]
Expansão no 4X significa você ganhar controle e/ou influência sobre áreas específicas do jogo. No CIV III essa é uma das principais etapas do jogo. Se você demorar ou for ineficiente na expansão, você vai ficar pra trás o resto do jogo inteiro. Esse é um ponto de contenção muito grande que pode fazer você amar o jogo ou odiá-lo. Em muitos jogos de expansão existem duas principais estratégias que deve ser possíveis de acontecer pra aumentar a opção de escolhas nessa etapa: wide (largo) e tall (alto).

Em uma estratégia de expansão "wide", o jogador escolhe espalhar-se pelo mapa e conquistar a maior quantidade de território, mas isso faz com que todas as cidades sejam medíocres até a metade para o final do jogo. Em contrapartida, em uma estratégia "tall" o jogador escolhe se focar em poucas cidades, mas torná-las mais forte cedo. Como um exemplo geopolítico na vida real, a Rússia/China seriam uma estratégia "wide", enquanto o Japão/Coreia seriam uma estratégia "tall".

No CIV III é ineficiente você jogar com uma estratégia "tall", porque a taxa que as novas cidades crescem é absurdamente rápida, além dos limites impostos no jogo na quantidade de população que uma cidade pode ser até a descoberta de tecnologias mais tarde no jogo. Isso faz com que seja uma corrida pra construir o máximo de cidades possíveis pelo mapa, o que deixa ele muito lotado cedo no jogo e limita estratégias que você pode fazer de expansão.

[h1]EXTRAIR[/h1]
Aqui, extrair significa que o jogador tem a possibilidade de colher e usar recursos nas áreas que ele controla, além de melhorar a eficiência desse uso. No CIV III isso acontece em alguns recursos: ouro, recursos de luxo e recursos estratégicos.

Ouro você pode usar na diplomacia com outras civilizações, aumentar sua ciência, seu tesouro, ou até a felicidade da sua população. Recursos de luxo servem como moeda de troca pra outras civilizações e também para aumentar a felicidade da população. Por fim, temos os recursos estratégicos. Eles são recursos para utilizar na construção de edificações nas cidades, melhorar o exército e até mesmo atingir determinados tipos de vitória pacífica. Esses recursos são limitados e fixos, ou seja, é difícil uma civilização ter o controle de todos os tipos de recursos estratégico.

Em um jogo, por exemplo, estava buscando a vitória científica, mas para isso precisávamos de alumínio e urânio - dois recursos que não tinha acesso. Meu vizinho estava me fornecendo, mas quando eu estava perto da vitória científica, ele atacou e negou completamente meu acesso à vitória. Foi um momento único e muito divertido, que fez com que eu precisasse lutar pela vitória. O problema aqui é que esse meu vizinho venceu o jogo com uma vitória científica, porque enquanto estava em guerra comigo, ele ainda podia fazer uso dos recursos. Pareceu como se qualquer decisão que eu fizesse fosse barrada pela sorte do vizinho ter nascido mais próximo dos recursos que minha civilização. Pareceu determinístico.

Ainda sim, a parte de extração é a parte onde CIV III brilha.

[h1]EXTERMINAR[/h1]
Geralmente exterminar em jogos 4X significa eliminar completamente o inimigo do mapa. Aqui, entretanto, vou considerar o objetivo de vitória como um ato de exterminação do oponente. Existem um total de 7 formas de vencer em CIV III, mas dessas 7, somente 4 delas são realmente viáveis. As 7 formas de se vencer são: [b]corrida espacial[/b], [b]dominação[/b], conquista, [b]cultural tall[/b], cultural wide, [b]diplomática[/b] e histográfica. As formas em negrito representam as 4 formas viáveis de se vencer. As vitórias de conquista, cultural wide e histográfica são muito difíceis de acontecer, porque o jogo vai ter acabado antes de consegui-las.

O combate no jogo é okay, mas é irritante ter que controlar milhares de unidades acumuladas ao mesmo tempo. CIV III não possui um limite de unidades por espaço, ou seja, você pode acumular uma infinidade de unidades num único comboio. Isso faz com que o combate seja estranho de controlar, já que você precisa fazer esforço pra selecionar a unidade que você quer que ataque, além de também não ter controle sobre qual unidade ela vai atacar. Outro fator irritante no jogo é o fato de que cada combate é baseado em uma rolagem de dados. As unidades possuem ataque e defesa, mas se a rolagem for ruim, um tanque guerreiro básico pode ser eliminado por um guerreiro básico. Tudo bem ter aleatoriedade no combate, mas essa era uma ocorrência muito mais frequente do que deveria ser (cerca de 10-15% das vezes).

[h1]MECÂNICAS ÚNICAS[/h1]
[b]Construir estradas aumentam o ouro gerado por um tile[/b]. Isso faz com que você tenha que construir ruas pelo mapa inteiro removendo totalmente a estratégia de criar estradas em pontos importantes do mapa. A partir do CIV IV as estradas CUSTAM ouro ao invés de GERAR ouro, fazendo com que você tenha que escolher com cuidado onde quer colocá-las.

[b]Corrupção[/b]. Quanto mais distante uma cidade está da sua capital, mais corrupção ela gera. Essa corrupção faz com que parte da produção e ouro dessa cidade sejam desperdiçados. É uma mecânica interessante e que tem como propósito "punir" jogadores que abusam muito da expansão, mas no final do dia acaba não importando tanto. É uma mecânica que eu até gostaria em outros CIVs.

[b]Exploração naval[/b]. No CIV 3 você pode explorar o oceano mesmo antes de descobrir tecnologias. Entretanto, cada turno que você termina com uma embarcação no oceano, essa embarcação tem 50% de chances de simplesmente afundar. É algo que eu gostaria que existisse em outros jogos, pois abre um fator de risco/recompensa que fica à escolha do jogador.

[b]Controle de borda[/b]. Nesse jogo não existe algo que te bloqueie de entrar no território de outra civilização - ou outras civilizações entrarem na sua. O problema é que se você fizer isso, as outras civilizações começam a se recusar a fazer diplomacia com você, o que pode parecer estranho pra quem não entende essa mecânica. 

[b][i][u]Dica: quando for atacar uma civilização, declare guerra antes de entrar na borda, ou sua diplomacia vai pro ralo com todas as civilizações.[/u][/i][/b]

Por fim, o jogo não tem tanta replayabilidade, já que as CIVs são muito parecidas umas das outras.

[b]Civilization III: Complete: 6.5/10 - É OK[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198045680793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3407, 'last_played': 1678495896}
review: Played this game way before I bought it recently on steam. It was the first video game I ever played. Even before the Jumpstart games. I started playing it at 4 years old before I was even literate. Quickly became a gifted reader just because of this game. Before this I used to struggle with reading so it helped me alot. Since I got to play every single day 10 hours a day I have easily above 10,000 hours of play time with this game just from the age of 4 to 9 years old. It literally took me 2 whole years just to find out that you can make settlers so for 2 years I used to play this game with only 2 cities. The other settler I would get from a hidden village if I was lucky. Funny thing is I got back into it recently and I am worse now then I was at the age of 6. Much worse. 6 year old me could play on Deity. Present me is still struggling on far easier difficulties and I play alot of strategy games. So yeah it's a great game and has way more charm then the newer iterations. I especially love the soundtrack. It was so nostalgic listening to it for the first time in 14 years.

i'm currently at almost 4k hours on this game. I'm running currently on Windows 10 with a 34" curved monitor. The game is very accommodating to custom graphics settings. Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198260265613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1645908558}
review:
The game doesn't work with windows 10. Scaling issues ruin it 100%.

If you are lucky like me It will Launch the first time you try so you can play for a few hours, but then you try and play again later and the scaling is messed up forever game window is missing 75% and is jammed up in the top left corner of your screen. Nothing fixes it, I tried for hours looking through reddit, steam etc and nothing worked. Its a shame as  it's a great game like all Civ games IMO. 

So if you are thinking hey I'm gonna buy this game it's only $1.00 on massive discount  just save yourself the time and don't it's not about the $1.00 its about wasted time and unwanted frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004743261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10028, 'last_played': 1647661603}
review:
This is still my overall favorite civilization game. I've purchased and played Civ4 and Civ5, and they are good games, but they sacrifice strategy for tactics IMO. An annoyance to me, too, has always been that they no longer allow you to occupy mountains with with your forces, and it makes me want to yell at the developers, "Hello! Switzerland? Afghanistan?" The new games are flashier, more tactical, less strategic. That's my opinion. Civ3 is the deeply complex, tile-based, strategy game that I have been coming back to for years and years, even after playing full games of Civ4 and Civ5. Additionally, it is an OCD gripe of mine, I realize, but let me know when they get rid of the absurdity that your units can't fortify mountain positions. That's when I'm buying an new civilization game again. ;)

Cheers

review:
This is one of my favorite games of all time.

What this game lacks in graphics is overcompensated by being able to progressively optimize your strategies. 
Secure strategic locations and resources to better ensure victory. 
Refer to the Civilopedia in-game (assuming you already own this masterpiece) because it's incredibly helpful.
Sure, there are limitations to the AI, but the penalties for increasing difficulty become brutal by Demigod.
Oh and you can rewrite history.

author: {'steamid': '76561198812613563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4255, 'last_played': 1699409831}
review:
Pros: 
- Games are longer than the fast-paced CIV 4 and shorter than the time-consuming CIV 5 and 6 Titles
- Nations and Governments feel distinct (More so than CIv 4)
- Sprites still look great 
- Atmospheric soundtrack
- Easy to learn, hard to master
- Lots of charm

Cons: 
-Late game turns can take a ridiculous amount of time to complete
- Barbarians will sometimes have so many units that your turn almost never ends, and if it does, they take your city. Endless. Turn them to the minimum difficulty

review:
언젠지 모르겠는데 무료로 받은 게임.

문명5로 입문해봤던 나로서는 문명3을 해보니까 너무 안맞았던 게임.
문명 개발진에 후원해주고 싶은 사람이 구매한다면 좋을만함.

재미를 느끼기도 전에 UI가 마음에 안들어서 접음.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066147971', 'num_games_owned': 405, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1660950693}
review:
*CLEARS THROAT LOUDLY* AHEM

It's a bit more difficult than Civ 5, and requires you to have a standing miltary all the way through unlike Civ 5 where you can cheese production and such.

Now that I'm not being a salty person who is angry at being destroyed in my first game back to this game, I can truly appreciate why I had so much fun with this game back in the day.

Also its still so much fun upgrading the palace!

Though the score system is so strange, granted I don't think anybody really cares about "winning" by the generic time limit

review: This is the best Civ game ever made. I have around 50 hours of play that steam hasn't recorded and I can say this game is great. The base game is amazing as is (with some GUI problems). THE COMMUNITY! It is awesome! there are so many mods and online servers, and the game is so easy to mod! I love the map editor and making my own scenario's. I have played a lot of  LAN recently and It's awesome (the lag is kinda bad though.) The price point is great as well!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042928550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1662397900}
review:
In the last week, this game has pissed me off SO FREAKING MUCH.

Let me back up.

When I was a kid, I'd wake up every morning around 6am and play this before school. I was a kid, I played the lower difficulties and over a few years worked up to harder difficulties. I remember having trouble with the higher difficulties...it seemed like no matter what I did there was no way to keep up with how fast all the AIs expanded and they were highly aggressive.

I've found this to be the case. I normally play civ 5 and 6 on the 2nd or 3rd hardest difficulty and can reliably win. On this one, good luck. The AI seems to start off with a significant headstart on number of cities. Doing my best to build settlers and staff them with spearman, I could get a sizeable empire but could not keep up overall. I learned that I needed to keep my gold low or else the AI would bully me into taking my gold. If I ever refused to give them gold or techs, they would declare war on me. I've yet to win a war, even after a few pretty good attempts (barracks in the capital, pumping out swordsmen or horsemen, depending on what I had available). 

I'm beyond frustrated so I'm walking away from this for a long while, but if I had to write some thoughts on what is required to win at higher difficulties...
1. Succumb to their threats, never go to war. If possible, give any money that you have to the AI so you gain their favor, rather than wait for them to bully you for it.
2. Expand as far as you can, then build walls along the outskirts. Make sure you have 1-3 barracks pumping out good units.
3. Build up a supply of 3 catapults, and whatever your unit of choice is (preference for swordsman or medieval inf) and deal a decisive blow before they knew what hit them. Once you attack of them, be ready for every AI to declare war on you.
4. Strike a hard enough blow at 1 AI to be able to overwhelm them, and that may give you enough momentum to encourage the other AIs to declare peace, then let you push past them in tech. This strat does work in later civ games. If it works here, you'll have enough cities to gain a tech lead, and discourage the other AIs from bullying you, until you're ready to steamroll past them in the 3rd era or so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2558, 'playtime_forever': 1444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1444, 'last_played': 1641092326}
review:
"Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete" ist ein rundenbasiertes Globalstrategiespiel.

Die "Civilization"-Reihe reicht zurück bis ins Jahr 1991, als Microprose den ersten Teil der Serie veröffentlichte. Schon damals hatten wir sie Aufgabe, ein Volk aus der Jungsteinzeit durch die Zeitalter zu führen und dabei andere Völker zu dominieren. 

Dieser dritte Teil stammt aus dem Jahre 2001 und unterschied sich doch in einigen Spielmechaniken deutlich von den Vorgängern. Neu sind zum Beispiel Ländergrenzen oder auch strategische Ressourcen. Dafür sind zum Beispiel die Karawanen aus dem Vorgänger dem Rotstift zum Opfer gefallen. "Civilization III" kann man vielleicht vielleicht spielmechanisch als den ersten moderneren Teil der Spieleserie bezeichnen. 

Wenn wir das Spiel beginnen, müssen wir erstmal zahlreiche Entscheidungen treffen. Auf welcher Karte wollen wir spielen, wie ist die Landverteilung, welches Klima herrscht und so weiter. Auch in Bezug auf Schwierigkeitsgrad und Siegbedingungen haben wir zahlreiche Optionen. 

Da wir hier die Complete-Edition mit allen Erweiterungen haben, können wir aus sage und schreibe 31 Kulturen auswählen, die alle bestimmte Boni und eine spezielle Einheit haben. Dann wählen wir noch Anzahl und Kultur der Gegner und starten das Spiel.

Zu Beginn ist es wichtig möglichst rasch einen guten Platz zum Gründen der ersten Siedlung zu finden. Außerdem sollten wir die Umgebung nach Stämmen oder Gegnern absuchen und damit die Karte sukzessive aufdecken. Natürlich ist es auch wichtig, unser Forschungsprojekt, das mehrere Runden dauert, auszuwählen und in unserer ersten Siedlung einen Bauauftrag für Gebäude, Einheiten oder Weltwundern zu geben. 

Die Städte wachsen über die Zeit, zumindest wenn wir keine Unruhe zulassen, und erweitern so ihren Einflußbereich. Im Stadtbildschirm können wir Einwohner auf Stadtfelder verteilen, die teils unterschiedliche Ressourcen produzieren können. Der Bau von Straßen und Bewässerungsgräben kann Fortbewegung und Produktion verbessern. 

Mit anderen Nationen können wir handeln, Friedensverträge schließen oder sie auch angreifen und ihre Städte übernehmen. Beim Kampf kämpfen immer die jeweiligen angrenzenden Einheiten gegeneinander. Wir spielen übrigens noch auf quadratischen Feldern, Hexfelder kamen erst mit dem fünften Teil der Reihe. 

"Civilization III" ist ein komplexer und doch massentauglicher und zugänglicher Vertreter der Globalstrategie. Trotz der historischen Völker ist das Spiel meist sehr ahistorisch. Caesar kämpft gegen Bismarck oder Bogenschützen gegen Panzer. Es geht also nicht um eine historisch adäquate Darstellung - dafür sollte man sich lieber bei Paradox umschauen - sondern um ein unterhaltsames Spielerlebnis, das in vielen Punkten Brettspielmechanismen aufgreift und diese so komplex macht, daß sie für ein langwieriges Computerspiel taugen.   

Und das ist auch diesem Teil ziemlich gut gelungen. Das typische "eine Runde geht noch"-Gefühl treibt Einen gerne mal zu durchgezockten Nächten, auch wenn das Game ein paar Balancing-Schwächen hat. Die 4X-Formel (Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate) ist ohne Frage prinzipiell sehr attraktiv.

Natürlich merkt man dem Titel optisch an, daß er aus dem Jahre 2001 stammt, allerdings sind Karte und Einheiten durchaus detailreich und liebevoll gestaltet, so daß man stets gerne den Fog of War aufdeckt. Sounds und Musik sind nach wie vor für das Genre gelungen.

Gibt es denn einen Grund den dritten Teil heute noch zu spielen, wo wir doch schon den sechsten Teil haben? In gewisser Weise schon, denn die CIV-Reihe hat im Laufe der Jahre durchaus einige Änderungen erfahren. Und so bietet CIV III, auch wenn das Grundprinzip natürlich das gleiche bleibt, durchaus ein anderes Spielerlebnis als der aktuelle Vertreter. Jeder Teil hat seine eingefleischten Fans und jeder Teil hat seine Daseinsberechtigung. Mir gefallen die älteren Titel fast besser als die neueren, die oftmals zu sehr glattgebügelt wurden. 

Alles in allem ist "Civilization III" vor allem ein Globalstrategiespiel, das Spaß macht, ein angenehmer Zeitfresser und kurzweilige Unterhaltung. Und auch wenn mir Paradox- oder Slitherine-Titel wegen ihrer historisch korrekteren Ausrichtung mehr liegen, kann eine Partie CIV doch immer sehr amüsant sein. 

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
8/10 Atmosphäre
7/10 Story
7/10 Grafik
7/10 Sound
8/10 Spielmechanik
8/10 Balancing
8/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Nur noch eine Runde.

[h1][b]8/10 Gesamtwertung

review:
Топовая стратегия, с друзьями играть вообще кайф

P.S. Забыл сказать, что покупалась игра для мультиплеера (с друзьями), в одиночке даже на сложности РЕГЕНТ игра превратилась в КРОМЕШНЫЙ АД, ии в разы быстрее изучает всё, ВО ВСЕХ НАПРАВЛЕНИЯХ БЫСТРЕЕ РАЗВИВАЕТСЯ, когда я достраивал пирамиды был уже построен оракул, великий маяк, великая стена и даже кто то успел построить пирамиды на 2 хода быстрее меня (строить их я начал в самом начале игры - построил поселенца и сразу после него пирамиды)

P.P.S.
Возможно, мне казалась игра столь сложной из-за того, что я долго в неё не играл, но попрактиковавшись, могу сказать: играть можно и вполне себе неплохо развиваться. Но ИИ всё-таки сложнее, чем в других версиях игры.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135924252', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9896, 'last_played': 1691655450}
review:
Civilization III is my favourite of the series. It was the first to add culture, and the civilization borders associated with the amount of culture you gathered. (Although Alpha Centauri, another Firaxis game, already used borders before.) it also added strategic and happiness resources to the game. Additionally units are now supported by gold instead of production. The scenarios are OK, but the real lasting game play is to be found in the random maps.

The various civillizations in the game are now more distinct as they now all have a unique unit, and a unique set of civilization traits. This does impact game play as each civilization now has each own best way to be played. But all the civilizations are still flexible enough that you can play any way you want too, and it is possible to win the game with any one of them. 

The main reason I enjoyed this version above any of the others is that the maps the game generates feel much more natural compared to any of the other games, Civilization II had the strange snake continents, while the maps in IV and V felt much smaller.

I bought the original DVD (or was it still on CD) release of the game when it game out and I used it all the way until my computer was changed to Windows 10. After that I bought the Steam version, as the original release didn't work anymore for me while the version from Steam works on Windows 10. The exception is the sound of the game which now has a repeating tick in the game music and the game sound effects get into continues loops. So I now play without sound, but apart from that the game is still perfectly playable on Windows 10.

review:
The best of the CIV series. They jumped the shark in later editions trying to make it more like Age of Empires (etc), real time games instead of staying true to CIV. What happens when a new designer takes over from original - the original soul is lost. 

Would be SO NICE is STEAM would let you WINDOW THIS GAME instead of it taking over your entire computer.

review: I consider this to be the best Civilization game.  It's simple enough to enjoy, yet complex enough to master in detail if you want.  Easy enough to play and enjoy for either small segments of time or long haul games.  I've played up to 300 hours in one game, you can play as little as a few hours if you want.

review: As a great tip, it is always wise to lower difficulty level; turn "always peace" on, and "no barbarians." This creates a much simpler path completing all of the timelines technologies, and completing them all without worrying of the annihilation of your republic. I could only imagine how great of an outcome if following the technology timeline was followed, installing each new technology learned physically into a rulers city-states, as these technologies are learned in turn. Like ceramics, and pottery leading to Granary for food production as an example; or an Aqueduct as a prerequisite for Plantation which produces sugar as another. There would be such great results. Whats great about the game is you can always launch another campaign, increase the difficulty to say Warlord or Emperor, turn to war back on, and do your best to overthrow rival nations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198823449214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5985, 'last_played': 1701276588}
review: A bit buggy, but definitely worth it. If you're having issues during startup, just exit and open it again (in severe cases, may need to restart computer). If game freezes between turns, don't touch anything or you'll crash it (it's just making moves for the AI and takes a bit when the game gets complicated towards the end). I'd also recommend saving one turn before the mandatory retirement year since the last page of the victory/defeat screen will often crash the game when you exit it. If you have the option of getting the physical disk instead of downloading on Steam, I recommend doing so as it's a bit less buggy, but if you can't get the disk, Steam is probably the best place to download. Hope this is helpful :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198021053414', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 25605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24901, 'last_played': 1689721333}
review:
I've surely sunk more hours into this than is recorded here. Many nights as a teenager were spent going until 4 AM building cities for glorious empires. It is the best 2D Civilization game, without equal. The mechanics are simple and straightforward, for the most part. The GUI is very easy to read. The advisors are direct and helpful. This is classic Civ at its best. 

ESPECIALLY for the cost. The five dollars is easily worth thirty. I've enjoyed Civ III for 15 years, and I'm not done yet. And I've yet to even use mods, which should keep you entertained until you're in the nursing home.

Nota bene, though: this version does have sound glitches. There are fixes, if you want to get the full effect of the soundtrack. I am lazy and my memory compensates, but they can't be too hard to find.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009149050', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 81751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50713, 'last_played': 1656762402}
