author: {'steamid': '76561198089449132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1603, 'last_played': 1634512985}
review:
Civilization III känns en aning omodernt efter ett antal uppföljare och cirka 20 år, inte minst grafiskt. Det håller fortfarande men Civilization IV och V förbättrade en rad saker samtidigt som de tog spelserien in i 3D. Civilization III blir även lite enformigt eftersom man bygger så oerhört många städer och enheter för att fylla världen och ta territorium, sedan flyttar man oerhört många enheter på samma ruta i en slags "stack of doom" istället för lite mer taktiska strider som i uppföljarna. Diplomatin känns också simpel och jag saknar det taktiska spelet med city states från Civilization V som man antingen försöker muta och påverka, eller också erövra. Det påminner om när världens supermakter försöker utöka sin makt genom att vinna allianser med mindre stater. 

Civilization III är åtminstone väldigt snabbt även på en äldre dator, vilket antagligen beror mycket på att spelet är så gammalt och inte kör särskilt krävande grafik. Jag gillar också hur det går att erövra andra städer både med krig och med kultur, när en annan stad byter sida på grund av kulturell påverkan. Ett inslag som inte är så realistiskt men åtminstone gör att det finns alternativ till krig.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042160689', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1537896519}
review:
The world, once a peaceful place; full of culture, cultivation, scientific advancements, and marvels of engineering. But like all good things, this Utopia did not last.
The world is scorched and scarred from a war of unprovoked diplomatic strain and hostility. The air now hardly safe to breathe.
It is the year 500AD. The Roman Legion sends the first Martian colonists by shuttle to preserve their way of life before Earth is destroyed by total atomic annihilation at the hands of the villainous mastermind Gandhi.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995355816', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 4006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4006, 'last_played': 1633822548}
review:
[i]Civilization III[/i] seems to have been the first game in the series to get a divided reception, the common denominator of which is friction between its strategy and simulation components. The most controversial feature appears to be the strategic resource mechanic, which is argued to give geography a lopsided tactical significance. It’s a reasonable thing to complain about, but it also happens to be historically and sociologically accurate. Similarly, the use of rigidly-defined eras prevents nonsensical arrangements like developing cars before developing the wheel. Personally, I’m a fan of anything that shakes players out of complacency, especially in this genre where fans tend to gravitate to a couple of optimal strategies. The other additions brought by [i]Civ III[/i] are more putatively worthwhile, including air missions, bombardment, and especially culture, which allows a faction to expand its borders and overtake cities via overwhelming media presence.

More than just adding new features, [i]Civ III[/i] also removes some annoying old ones like universal zones of control and generally cleans up the gameplay of its predecessors with better mouse support and more direct access to the in-game encyclopedia. The pacing and micromanagement are still weak links, as they drag matches out long after their outcomes have been decided, but that’s arguably inherent to the formula. The aesthetics, on the other hand, would be problematic in any genre. The music is terrific, and the visuals are more appealing than before, but they still utterly fail to cleanly display the gameplay information they’re expected to. Meanwhile, the sound effects range from acceptable, to annoying, to just plain odd. Nevertheless, this is my favourite of the first three [i]Civ[/i] titles. The [i]Complete[/i] version is appropriately titled, too, as it combines the content of the two expansion packs with multiplayer that actually works.

[b]Score: 8/10[/b]

https://www.imlgames.com/sid-meiers-civilization-iii-complete/

author: {'steamid': '76561197972319454', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 23016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 93, 'playtime_at_review': 16731, 'last_played': 1710585973}
review:
It's a classic of the strategy genre that even today will work on pretty much any system or platform you try to run it on, is simple to learn yet has astonishing depth to it when it comes to the in game economy, diplomacy, combat system, and more, and quite frankly it can be a lot of fun, both in single player, and multiplayer if you can find people who'll play it with you, and don't mind that to use that multiplayer function can require a third party fix or direct connection to a shared network. I personally consider this the defacto best game in the entire civilization franchise. 

So what are you waiting for? Buy it already if you haven't tried it yet. You'll be glad you did. Especially if your introduction to the series was Civilization IV, which I'm sorry to say is definitely the weakest entry in the franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198323079151', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1710042027}
review:
I'm 22. About to be 23 in a few months. Here's my story.

When I was 14, I got struck down with depression. This led to me missing a lot of school in highschool and ultimately finishing 9th grade with a single credit.

I spent the rest of my teens trying to play catch up, finally receiving my high school diploma by age 19.

But when things seemed to be going well at 19, I was attacked and nearly raped. By the same relative who molested me my entire childhood. I became suicidal and was diagnosed with PTSD a year later.

At age 20, my mom died from cancer. She was a single parent and raised me all on her own since my deadbeat father left when I was 1.

I was now suffering from daily flashbacks due to my disorder.
Grieving the loss of the only parent I ever had.
And sobbing regularly thanks to the horrific things my father said to me while my mom lay dying in her hospital bed.

At 21, I dropped out of university.
I spent the rest of that year taking odd jobs at factories to pay my bills.

When I turned 22, I thought for sure it was my time to shine and begin living my life...

And then COVID happened.

I turn 23 on Dec 11.

I know I didn't waste my early 20s since I was suffering from so much traumatic shit in the span of a few years that others experience over a lifetime, some never at all.

But as I begin my 23rd year. I feel lost.
My PTSD has been in remission for over a year. And I've healed from the loss of my mother... but I'm struggling to shake the feeling that I lost so much time, and will always play catch up with others in the same life arena.

I don't really know why I wrote all this down, but I guess if there's any other lonely soul out there who happens to see my comment, I just want you to know that you got this.

We didn't choose our life circumstances.
We didn't ask for our lives to go off plan.

But we are alive
We're healthy
We've been blessed with another day

If you're the same age as me, our lives are only just beginning.
If you're older, you too can realize your dreams, escape the rigid safety found in your daily routine, and live the life you thought could never be possible.

If you still got a pulse, God still has a purpose.

If you're still hurting, talk to someone about it.

If you feel bored, get lost in a good book.

If you feel lost or confused, reconnect with that inner child and find time to spend doing the things you loved so much as a little one.

I hope to revisit this review in a few years, perhaps before my 20s are up so I can update how my life has gone since then. Til then...

Take care internet stranger. You got this. :)

i've logged over one year of gameplay on a different system, but currently run it via Steam on my newest one.

highly recommend.

review: This one is still beautiful. If you enjoyed original Civilization and Civilization 2, this is the pinnacle of the evolution of Civilization series. From here on it goes downhill. Following games like Civilization 4,5,6 don't give the same feeling and as the number gets bigger it loses more of its spirit. It works well for a game of its age, I didn't face any crashes. Its price is real cheap for a game like this. If you are looking for the fancy graphics this one doesn't have it, but it has the best gameplay in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032387023', 'num_games_owned': 1891, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1615459501}
review:
I chose Civilization III as my first Civilization game because I wanted to see how the series evolved over the time. As a newcomer, take my review with a grain of salt since there may be some concepts I did not fully comprehend.

Civilization III had big ups and downs. It’s an aesthetically beautiful time sink and similar to Heroes of Might and Magic and X-COM (although mechanically I would say Civilization is more similar to Settlers), it hypnotizes you every time you play it. You lose concept of real life and time and end up playing for several hours non-stop. I’ve had the feeling it plays very much like a board game and I wouldn’t be surprised if Civilization series were heavily influenced by them.

There is no real campaign. You decide the rules (map, weather, victory conditions etc.) and start your custom game which can easily take dozens of hours. There are many civilizations to choose from but they are diverse enough to offer unique gameplay. You start in ancient times, build cities, research technologies, conquer other civilizations. 

There are some aspects I did not really like though. Firstly, some early strategies have too much influence on your fate. Don’t build enough cities or invest enough in technology, you may find yourself in an unwinnable state. AI obviously cheats in harder difficulties so you’ll have to play in specific strategies in order to win rather than a flexibility on strategies. Diplomacy is pretty much broken and the AI never accepts your fair proposals, making the entire game mechanic obsolete. Corruption may sound like an interesting idea but in the case of Civilization III, it does more harm than good. Also, in mid to late game, you end up micromanaging hundreds of units and one turn can take quite a long time. I think it would be fair to say a game in Civilization III takes way too long with plenty of downtime. 

I would say Civilization III aroused my interest to the series and I will definitely be playing other titles. On the other hand, I can’t ignore its flaws and I’m pretty confident I won’t return to Civilization III specifically. 

[b]8/10[/b]

review: É um jogo que dá muito trabalho de administrar, o que é fascinante para jogadores que gostam de otimizar tudo. Há muita liberdade para "trapaças" diplomáticas e comerciais. author: {'steamid': '76561198338840776', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 258, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1563829520}
review:
Легендарная цивилка.. Суть этой игры, я думаю, ясна большинству. Так сказать "из грязи в князи")
Сам я о ней не многое могу сказать, играл я в Civilization III недолго, моё детство каким-то боком миновали такие игрушки жанра "стратегии"( Но одно я знаю точно: если вы не равнодушны к подобным творениям, то эта игра уж и подавно стоит вашего внимания.
Я и сам думаю зайти как нибудь в это чудо и попробовать всё-таки познакомиться с ним поближе, ибо как-то смотришь, и вроде даже интересно становится XD.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986781352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1601716846}
review: Civilization III is a 4X game (Explore, Expand, Exploit and Exterminate) and is both the sequel to the very successful Civilization II and the spiritual successor to Sid Meier’s Alpha Centauri. Back in possession of the Civilization franchise, Sid Meier improves Civilization II in several ways; graphics were upgraded to be less pixelated and have a hint of 3D and several new victory conditions were added. As the leader of one of several real civilizations of earth’s history, the player is tasked to take over the world and be the dominant civilization on a randomly generated planet. This can be achieved by either winning the space race before 2050 AD (the game starts in 4000 BC), defeating the other civilizations culturally or militarily, or being the diplomatically elected world leader. While the gameplay is deep, the game suffers from a random and frustrating resources and battle system and a terrible UI which makes the game hard to control. Bland music and a long and sometimes boring learning phase don’t help this game that really didn’t age well.

review: The AI cheats on hard difficulty, and the game is too easy on normal difficulties. Its kind of hard to make an effective strategy or decide what to do when your enemies can just spawn in troops and resources. Seriously, it completely ruins the games, and cheating AI is why Civ has never really gotten popular since the 90s. The whole point of games like these is to be smart, and to think things out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114929937', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1707097875}
review: My 10 hours on steam playing this game are no representation of just how much I goddamn LOVE this game. My parents got an original boxed version way back when, and I played it for HOURS on a yellowing Compaq home computer running Windows ME. This game, its animations, soundtrack, icons and UI are all genuine "Madeleine de Proust" for me. It might be surpassed by Civ V and VI in terms of gameplay and approachability, and honestly, you'd probably be better off playing the more modern versions, but Civ III still holds a special place in my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301928491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 14734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11723, 'last_played': 1689204667}
review: I like Civ 2 Test of Time better but this Civ gives a new look as well as a new feel while keeping the hardcore civ play style alive. The newer civs feel like a child's game while the older versions seem like you have to know what the heck you are doing or you won't go anywhere. It has some very specific units and troops that makes it really awesome and the new builder systems is nicer in my opinion than the old settlers do everything mentality.

review: I grew up playing Civ III, and this iteration is what I consider the "Classic" Civ game before the series began complicating the system. The UI is user-friendly, and the Advisor system is the simplest yet most intuitive compared to later games. Even running on a potato this game runs smoothly! Highly recommend if you want a simple and casual turn-based strategy game with a healthy dose of nostalgia from a time before modern PC gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144345791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1629851209}

review: A lot of AAA games nowadays can't get even close to Civ 3's complexity and replayability. Great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198181925654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 38669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2937, 'last_played': 1692978811}
review:
Civ 3 is the foundation of all future titles in the series, and just as good as when it first released. All the bugs from previous titles have been worked out, and it is a solid game with a great replay factor. The additional civilizations available in the Complete edition only enhances that. Diplomacy and combat are nuanced without being complex, and there are plenty of ways to plan your cities depending on your priorities. 

All told, a good solid game despite its age, with enough depth and subtlety to keep it interesting for the veteran player while remaining simple enough that the rookie will not feel overwhelmed.

13/10. Would buy (yet) again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158105637', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9844, 'last_played': 1664142902}
review: I played this throughout high school. I was a bit addicted really, having my game saves on a usb drive and a installation of the game on several computers throughout the school, I would play this game any chance I got. I still play this to this day and would certainly recommend it. I know there are newer editions out now but civ 3 for me is where it all started, and has yet to end. It has one bug that is quite unfortunate, for me the space race victory isn't an option because when I launch the spaceship it almost always freezes the game. Aside from this I haven't experienced any issues. You will need to edit the config file for higher resolutions. I think 1080p and up. Have fun spending too much time on this, relic. :]

author: {'steamid': '76561198440493937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 16255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9036, 'last_played': 1687042642}
review:
Game focuses on getting techs before others and domination. The newer Civs are more of a city builder, this is more of a divide and conquer. Pitting AI against each other. Game is a bit old so the AI are a bit out dated and tend to work together and seem to cheat a bit. Late game is a bit overwhelming with all the tasks and unit controls, it takes a veteran to be able to sit through a whole game and continue to manage every unit. 
The thing about this game that beats every other Civ. Advancing through the ages and seeing change in scenery is unmatched by any of their games. Getting steam power and modernizing is the most satisfying thing imaginable. Limited resources and being reliant on saltpeter and rubber is frustrating but also super rewarding. Wonders have a huge impact on the game but also don't limit the player. The balance of the game is there, it is just is a little outdated with the AI being behind the idea of the creators of this game. Look at my play time, I wouldn't have played this game if I didn't enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11090, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1707640654}
review:
Civilization 3 was one of the greatest of all time 4X strategy games.  Based on Sid Meier's Civilization game, it featured a broad number of generational improvements over the original.  Starting with a small city in the stone age, develop technologies and culture, expand your borders, build your military until you conquer the world, or reach for the stars, or both. 

A couple of problems, sadly.  First, the game is now effectively spyware as Take 2 admit in the EULA to data harvesting including significant amounts of personal information, presumably for them to use to profile you and sell your personal data to third parties.  This is completely unacceptable.

Secondly, the game has aged far too much.  It's been superseded by Civ 4, 5 and now 6.  If you do persist in trying to play the game, you'll find the resolution is locked, and the game only displays 4:3 stretched, it's just too old to be recommended to gamers on modern PCs.  As the old saying goes, you can't go home again.

review: Started to play this while waiting for the release of Master of Orion 3 (there's a picture of that game on the backcover of the original manual). CIV 3 is one of my favorite Civilization games. I mostly like the first two Eras of the game (ancient and middle age). It has a nice exploration element as the maps can be fairly large. I really like the artwork and the music. It's a classic game and still fun to play.

review: This is the first Civ game I remember playing. It is your typical strategy game: build cities, research technology, create military units, conquer. Decide the size of the map, decide how many enemies, decide the requirements for victory. All these are features that can be found in all the civilization games. Should you play this instead of one of the newer versions of the game? Probably not. But still a fun game if you can tolerate how slow the units move.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979953970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 487, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1617710513}
review:
Reviewing games I played a long time ago:

The last 2D isometric Civilization and possibly the best one in the series. I played this, alongside Alpha Centauri, an ungodly amount of time in my teen years. A must buy.

I managed to get it working after messing up with some config files, but supposedly there's issues to run it in modern systems, so beware.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179624186', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1707228568}
review:
This game is fun and cheap to buy on steam. It is the last of the 2d games so it is good for those who want to play a civ game on older hardware. The game often sold for cheap on Steam.

Pros: The graphics in this game are better then Civ 2 and it does not take long to learn it.


Cons: There are many problems with the game. The first being lack of Steam Play/Proton support with this game. As the GOG version works there is no reason for it not too. One of the advantages of this version though is that online now works as they have patched up the game. The issue is that there  is no one online to play the game though. The game also is worse with AI and trading is worse in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081602355', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1901, 'last_played': 1641175610}
review:
Apesar de ser um jogo muito antigo ele continua sendo muito bom.
Lembro de quando criança meu pai jogando esse jogo enquanto ficava em seu colo, entao claro, tem uma nostalgia muito forte.
O jogo tem muitos bugs, inclusive sonoros, que estragam muito a experiencia. Provavelmente, são causados por falta de compatibilidade com os novos Drrvers.
Daria uma avaliação de 7/10 pra quem gosta de jogos 4X!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067541317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1216, 'last_played': 1609627444}
review:
This game is a classic and still have the original CDs and book. since I no longer use a DVD-ROM drive, I decided to get it on Steam. 

 I have literally THOUSANDS of hours on Civ3 before Steam. Civ3 remains one of my favorite Civ games of the franchise. I was also heavy into modding and editing my own versions of the game back when it was popular. I played it before I was deployed and picked it right back up when I got back back in 2001-2002. 

 The newer Civ games offer a lot of other features, but Civ3 still has that great foundation for long (and sometimes boring) gameplay that I used to love. I still fire it up once in a while for nostalgic reasons...hearing the sounds and music in-game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199007334408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 45819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31766, 'last_played': 1682552230}
review: I played this game for years on an old XP vista up until 2013. The tower stopped booting after a while. Me and my dad would stay up till midnight playing. I was ecstatic to see it launched on steam. I miss the gold version with some of the mechanics it had but the complete Civ 3 edition is better then Civ 6. I have not played 5 but it looks just as good as 6. I played 4 and the best part about it was the music. Overall the best game I have ever played. Obviously 6 has newer and graphics and some cool mechanics but Civ 3 was not broke and they tried to fix it. If Sid sees this I need civ 3 mechanics with religion and civics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049498441', 'num_games_owned': 5235, 'num_reviews': 434, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1615722269}
review:
정치 제도를 바꿀 때 마다 바뀌는 부패도 등등 현실적이게 신경써야하는게 더 많은 게임...
일꾼이 엄청 중요한데 자꾸 전투민족들이 약탈해가서 고통받게됩니다..
사치자원을 개발하는 걸 문명 5나 6처럼 타일 개발이 아니라 길을 뚫어서 개발해야해서 길만 파다가 시간 다 갑니다
내정에 신경 쓰기도 전에 AI들이 나를 무시하며 자꾸 전쟁을 걸고 돈 내놓으라고 하고 깡패짓해서 승질납니다.
전투지형에 따른 우세를 모르기 때문에 맨 평지에서 싸워도 캐릭터가 가끔은 이길 때도 있고 한대도 못 때리고 질 때도 있어서
어떻게 전투가 산정이 되는지 모르겠구요.. 이쯤되면 저는 타일류 전략게임에 재능이 없는게 아닐까 싶습니다.
난이도 겁나 어렵네요 누가 족장난이도 해도 이긴다고 했나요 적들이 기마병 가져와서 다 뿌시고 약탈하고 돌아버릴거같아요;;
문명 입문용으로는 비추천입니다.. 그래도 왠만한 타일류 전략게임의 신같은 존재라서 추천합니다
난이도는 어려우니 평화적인 캐릭터만 설정해서 싸우세요 제 이웃나라 자꾸 아즈텍 나오고 몽골나와서 때려칩니다;;

review:
I have spent so many hours playing this game... Love the strategic challenge.  Love that every map spawn creates a completely different set of challenges.  The AI in my opinion is excellent and obviously gets appropriately tougher with the level you choose.  Mostly just really enjoy the game concept -start with one settler and worker and build an empire.
My only disappointment is that when I finish a game there is a glitch (maybe with Steam?) that doesn't let me see my final rating/ score/ history.  It says I won and then I'm unable to access the last few score pages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198795903423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 833, 'last_played': 1708224082}
review: I have played every Civilization except the first one, and III is probably my least favorite of them all. In most other Civ games finishing a wonder means you get a video, a nice quote, or some music or something. In Civ III, you get a boring screen with a picture of the wonder. Just like all the Civ games before Civ V, combat is randomly decided which can get frustrating. III can also get a bit boring because unlike later games, you must watch every single unit in your line of sight move one at a time. This game is about 20 years old, so some of the leaders look very creepy due to the way they are animated. However, Civ III also has some redeeming features. First of all, it's only $5, or a little over $1 when on sale, which means you get the base game and the two expansions they made for it for far cheaper than trying to buy old game discs on eBay. The leaders dress differently for each era, which is a nice feature that no other Civ game features. However, there are also only four eras in the game, which is how all the Civ games were before Civ IV. III was also the first game to feature unique units and the last to feature the view city option, albeit a bit broken because some of the buildings are invisible in the city view. Resources are also very scarce in III for some reason. In most cases there are only one or two sources of a particular resource on the map, and the vast majority of the units and buildings in the game require certain strategic resources which makes this very inconvenient. There are some Civ content maps included that rectify this issue, so I especially recommend the map "Ten Bands" if you want to actually be able to build most of the units. Overall, Civ III is worth it mostly for the price, it's obviously nowhere near the level of the Civilization games that came after it. If you want to play an older Civilization game I would personally recommend Civilization II, but that is not on Steam and will not work on anything newer than Windows 7. III is the oldest Civ game on Steam, but is does work very well, except that it seems to reliably crash every single time I am about to win the game. Other than, it is definitely worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993406224', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1614618277}
review: Civ III might be the best version of the entire Civilization franchise. It was the first version that introduced so many of the features that just made sense to me, like resources being necessary to build things. I loved Civilization 1 and 2, but it always irked me to see Viking War Elephants, especially when the Vikings were coming from nowhere near elephant territory. The introduction of strategic resources was a double edged sword, I have often lamented the computer placing my civilization with a unique unit that requires horses in an area completely devoid of horses for instance, but overall their addition to the game has made a more realistic simulation. Late game fights for coal or oil just make sense. Now on to the bad parts - the graphics are dated, it's just a reality of playing older games. It's not as bad as a lot of older games, but it is a noticeable thing. It is also kind of a pain to play on a newer system. Higher resolutions make the entire interface too small to read, lower resolutions do weird things to the rest of my system. Widescreen monitor support is basically non-existent. I get it, why put a lot of effort into an older version of the game? That said, I'd probably pay close to full price for a remastered edition of this version of Civilization. I played this for thousands of hours back in the day, and I would not have upgraded to Civilization 4 if my wife hadn't bought it for me for my birthday.  Civilization 3 also lacks a few features from newer iterations of the franchise. I am cool with it's lack of religion mechanics, I thought I'd want them, and I enjoy them in Civ 5 (Civ 4's implementation was poorly done), but keeping things more generalized seems to make for a better play experience, unless holy wars are really your favorite thing. Civilization 3 is probably the best in the franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004610521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 4145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2993, 'last_played': 1659806839}
review:
Всё так же невероятно затягивающая, как и 20 лет назад.

Перепройдено на Linux посредством Proton (SteamPlay).
На Proton 5.13-6 есть проблема с отрисовкой ряда элементов интерфейса, что приводит к перекрытию чёрной пеленой террейна, меню советника торговли и иностранных дел, а так же расширенной статистики государства. Проблема "чёрного" террейна решается снятием всех отметок в Main Menu / Map / Clean Map References. Это приведёт к тому, что плашка с информацией о городе (название, количество жителей и так далее) не будет отображаться, но с прочим всё останется в порядке. Перечисленные неудобства незначительно мешают в прохождении.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100007931', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 53929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53865, 'last_played': 1624141516}
review: If you're looking for a classic turn-based strategy game then look no further. Firstly it's important to state that playing CIV III is a major time investment. Games will go anywhere from 35 Minutes to 16 Hours depending on the settings (Mainly Map Size/Difficulty.) To this day I have not been able to complete a game on Regent difficulty, so if you've got AI level IQ then this game could be a breeze. Playing on Settler difficulty however will allow you to calmly coast through your game and provide you with many avenues for victory and immersion. Although CIV III mods are hard to find due to the old forums going down, you can still find some of them. Couldn't recommend this game enough, it has a special place in my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050488139', 'num_games_owned': 2858, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1612301987}
review:
Классическая часть культовой серии, которая, к сожалению, не дружит с современным железом и софтом (проверены версии для Steam и GOG). Если вы собираетесь купить проект, дабы предаться ностальгии за игровым процессом — убедитесь, что игра у вас нормально запускается, не крашится каждые 5 минут, а скролл карты работает как положено, до того, как истечет возможность рефанда. В противном случае, советую обратить внимание на четвертую или пятую часть серии: проблем с совместимостью в них не замечено, а стилистика и основа игрового процесса не претерпели существенных изменений. 

P.S.: редактирование ini-файла, фанатские фиксы и прочие "танцы с бубном" с Civ3 не прокатили.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31260806]Моя полумертвая кураторская страничка на русском[/url][/b].

______________________________________________

The classic part of the cult series, which is, unfortunately, not friendly with modern hardware and software. (Tested versions for Steam and GOG). If you are going to buy a project to indulge in nostalgia — make sure that you could launch the game, that it won't crash every 5 minutes, and the map scroll works as expected before the time to refund it expires. Otherwise, I advise you to check the fourth or fifth part of the series: there are no compatibility problems, as far as I know, while the style and gameplay basis haven't changed too much.

P.S.: Editing the INI file, fan fixes and other magic tricks didn't work with Civ3 in my case.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35095872/]My half-dead curator page on broken English[/url][/b].

author: {'steamid': '76561198279339011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1746, 'last_played': 1613937929}

author: {'steamid': '76561198193737125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4848, 'last_played': 1656885740}
review:
I have played Civ II, III, IV, and VI. III is my favorite.

Here's some of the reasons why:

- The graphics/visual display are just so clear, everything is so easy to see. It can feel like a lot is going on on the map, but this art style makes it really easy to take it all in.
- While I always felt this base game did lack things like religion, civics, and city-states, I never felt it was implemented so well in the other games that they rise above Civ III.
- Although you can manipulate the pacing of the game, the actual pacing of the game-play always felt great to me. Things like world size, how far troops move, how long it takes to start a war, conquer an enemy, grab a new resource, etc. 
- The soundtrack hits the themes of your scientific age really well. Whenever I was in the modern age, I really felt like my civilization had culturally & emotionally matured, and knew their place in the world. I felt the soundtracks reflected this journey.
- Wide range of civilizations, unit choices, wonders, structures, etc. Without feeling overwhelming.
- The AI are actually pretty challenging. On max difficulty, almost no one has beat the game, especially without trying "cheap" tricks. But, that actually makes it really fun for role-playing as a less powerful nation, trying to hang on to its identity throughout time without being wiped off the planet, or technologically backward. It's almost like they bundled "The Sims" for cities/civilizations into this game too!

The mod support for Civ III can really extend its shelf-life too. I have sparingly played the multiplayer, I was able to be perfectly satisfied with just the singleplayer. Like all Civ games, it may have a slight learning curve, but you can jump in and start having fun playing immediately. The learning curve is more about how you might play really well against harder AI. Finally, note that this game is not heavily about combat, or visuals relating to combat. They exist, but the excitement of something like a large tank-battle in Red Alert 2 would not be present in this game. It's more about calculated, strategic decisions and movements, similar to a board game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198379437591', 'num_games_owned': 432, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1613903023}
review: Отличная и незабываемая классика. Да, в эту прелесть на современных мониторах играть весьма проблематично "но лично мне пофиг. играю в оригинале на с экраном 1920х1080", но уж точно не скучно! Старик Сид своей третьей частью доказал всему миру, что в одну компанию в какой-нибудь стратежке можно рубиться сотни часов, а по сети так и вообще заходить под 1к часов!Да, музыка на данный момент чутка устарела, но её классическая графика может таки радовать глаз не придирчивых к этому элементу игроков. В этой игре вы создавали юниты, делали стеки из бойцов "оборона в виде трёх лучников... эхх... как же я тебя любил...", строили города ориентируясь на имеющиеся ресурсы, развивали технологии, и главное - могли посмотреть на свои достижения по застройке просто зайдя в город "к сожалению это убрали в последующих частях". Да, тут нет ООН, такого продуманного шпионажа, более развитая система боёвки и отображение Чудес Света на глобалке, но уж точно она не оставит равнодушными тех, кто любит расслабиться и отдохнуть после тяжёлого дня "или как в мои времена - после физры в 1-4 классах". Как писал автор ниже - она таки в основном для любителей коллекции, но и для тех кто хочет познать историю серии "или просто любителям стратегий" крайне рекомендую. Если вы к ней привыкнете и дадите ей шанс, то точно пропадёте на десятки "а то и сотни" часов пытаясь "выбить этот проклятый Стек Копейщиков Ганди, что "Маньяк проклятый" поставил у границ, и что он уже достал наезжать на твой приграничный город который ты построил пару-тройку ходов назад)

author: {'steamid': '76561198061621467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1690561854}
review:
Merci à Steam pour son travail formidable. 
Nous donner l'opportunité de rejouer à un jeu du passé est génial.
D'autant plus qu'un bug récurant fait son apparition. La difficulté du jeu. Peu importe celle qui vous choisissez. Si l'IA engage le combat vous pouvez être certain que son unité à 300 % chance de vaincre la votre.
Merci de nous laissez pleins d'espoir lorsqu'on commence une nouvelle partie sans pouvoir progresser.

Pour ma part, troisieme partie réalisé (pour un adepte des Civilisation), je suis à 10 pour 1 en taux d'unité perdue pour une victoire. Peu importe si présence de Bouclier/Muraille/Grande-Murraille ou tout objet augmentant les stats des unités. L'ia est juste buguée comme jamais.. !!!

Je recommande ce jeu mais en ne passant pas par Steam ! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198097322047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 519, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1613262844}
review: Третья редакция видения Сида на развитие цивилизаций. Для своего времени была отличной игрой и множество игроков оставляли дни и недели своего времени в игре строя цивилизации. Сейчас, на начало 2021 года геймплей безнадежно устарел… После активной игры, например в 5ю часть, уже нельзя вернуться в 3ю так как сразу ощущается острая нехватка тактического разнообразия, которое имеют поздние редакции игры. Интерфейс кажется неудобным, графика "подустала", звук можно сразу отключить. В общем, игру можно сдавать в исторических архив. Заинтересовать она может только коллекционеров и тех, кто ностальгирует по былым временам.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009992090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1612844603}
review:
Only supports two resolutions, the game default and the desktop resolution; and you must do this manually by editing a config file or by changing your desktop resolution. The VideoMode command did not work for me so I was stuck with only 2 resolution options. Resizing desktop before and after every play is extremely unrealistic to me with all the work. I'm fine with modifying files, I'm a bit old-school so easy to do. But when my monitor does not support the games default and it give me no way to "select" a resolution for the game itself, I'm left with no choice but to move on and get refund.

I've played older games which offered far more graphic options than this game, which offered none in-game surprisingly. I can not recommend if your monitors don't play 1024.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124690481', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1613116311}
review:
Restarted 6x as of review, the russians, chinese, zulumen and so on are really destroying my american civilization 50 minutes in on 5/10 difficulty. 

To be fair on myself, I've also got all win conditions on or most of them besides for the princess in the castle and the AI civs are really super fast. 

Over each iteration I've changed my play style according to how I'm destroyed in the end, so hopefully in another 2-3 I'll have games longer than an hour! hoping for a good 6-7 hour sit down! 

Really difficult game, first game I remember having on one of my old pcs with a CRT monitor and it was just great!

Ah right, if you put a price on the hours you'll get out of civ, it's definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199111553614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1612459967}
review:
The game runs particularly glitchy on a regular basis, often throwing prompts that the program is not responding, usually happens when clicking during character movements, and often when clicking through the end game prompts after completing a run. The program not responding prompts aren't a huge issue in game when you click during a character movement, being that the program will usually respond and get you back to the game. It rarely will respond if it happens during the end game prompts, which means the couple of hours you spent attaining whatever victory status you grinded out is null and void, being that the game won't record these wins, unless you complete the end game prompts. 
I love Civ games, but this particular one just does not run well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110946937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 24517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13139, 'last_played': 1704765379}
review: Es un juego atrapante, tiene una atmosfera envolvente producto de la excelente banda sonora, y si bien los graficos pueden haber envejecido lo complementa perfectamente con su complejidad, considera muchisimas mas variables que cualquier juego de ultima generacion, lo que hace que la victoria se disfrute mas. Si le das el tiempo necesario no decepciona, personalmente es el unico juego en la vida que me ha hecho sentir poderoso por manejar tantas variables a la vez, se asemeja muchisimo a la politica internacional del mundo real jaja

author: {'steamid': '76561198012786527', 'num_games_owned': 4290, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1610660854}
review:
As others have mentioned, Civ 4 is pretty much superior in every way, unless you really like micromanaging a ton of workers while the AI proceeds to try and fill every available space with cities it barely develops.

I played this because I owned it and wanted to see how it differed from newer games, and I accomplished that, but if you want a good civ game there are better choices.

review: Civ é uma série de jogos muito boa, no entanto, Civ 3 é tem um sistema complexo de organização das cidades que fez falta nos jogos posteriores por ser algo a mais e mais estratégico. Sua maior falha, ao meu ver, é sua inteligência artificial que independente da dificuldade posta, ela é extremamente difícil de se combater, no primeiro turno ela já cria a primeira cidade e já começa a querer expandir mais e mais e mais até não ter mais espaço.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087178004', 'num_games_owned': 921, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1352, 'last_played': 1609708410}
review:
Так вышло, что Sid Meier’s Civilization стала моей самой первой игрой на ПК. До сих пор помню свои первые впечатления, перевод Писаренко и Мисовца, даже пароль от компьютера, на котором стояла игра.

В общем, к моменту релиза Civ3 я был большим поклонником первой части. Вторая Цивилизация как-то прошла мимо меня, поэтому я тогда удивился, что новая игра имеет цифру три в названии. Помню, с каким упоением я играл в оригинальную третью часть. Потом были Play The World и Conquests. Даже не представляю, сколько часов я провёл за ней.
 
Потом уже вышла четвёртая часть, но это была другая игра.   Несмотря на то, что третья довольно-таки отличалась от первой, по духу она была к ней ближе всего (как минимум в плане существовавших механик). Собственно именно поэтому для меня третья Цивилизация и осталась максимально трушной и любимой частью серии (кроме первой, конечно, она просто вне категорий).  

Особенность серии — лёгкость в освоении. Несмотря на то, что у неё куча нюансов, чтобы играть и получать удовольствие от игры, разбираться в них совсем не обязательно. Если же копнуть в правила глубже, можно заметить насколько Civilization детальна (что в общем-то логично для игры, которая сделана по настолке) и увлекательна. В этом случае можно перейти с расслабленных партеек на Вожде на более высокий уровень сложности.
 
И в том и в другом случае игра дарит офигенный опыт 4X-стратегий.

review:
It's not my first Civ, nor is it my favorite, but it's still Civ, and I love it. If you don't like Civ, then you probably won't like this. That said, it's older and therefore somewhat simpler than more recent Civ games, so if you want to try something smaller, try this... Or Polytopia.
My biggest, non-actual game mechanic based, complaint is that the game is somewhat unstable on Windows 10, at least in my experience. It crashed three to four times just trying to start a new game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153017756', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 21414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21414, 'last_played': 1550623492}
review:
My first Civilizations game, and can safely say that it's one of my favorites.
I've spent hundreds of hours within this game and barely made a dent in the full content of the game.
Something I definitely prefer about Civ 3 over 4,5, and 6. Is the map size, a regular map on Civ 3 is a large map on Civ 4 and Civ 5. I've never attempted the largest map size (Containing 16 players compared to Civ 4-5 having 11 and 12), but on just a large map it will take at-least 30+ hours to beat one game.
Strongly recommend if you like long term strategy games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036248793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4116, 'last_played': 1643516587}
review:
This game is obviously more simplistic than the later entries in the series, but that gives it a bit of charm in my opinion. My take on this game is that there is more going on on the board due to unit stacking and free tile enhancements (including roads and railroads), and less going on in the background due to lack of religion and civics trees. I personally like this game more than later entries in the series, but that may be due to nostalgia since I probably put 1000ish hours into the game on disk.

Fair warning for anyone thinking of jumping into this, the downsides compared to later entries are more micromanagement (cities will straight up shut down if there are enough unhappy people in them and you need to fix that on a case-by-case basis), unit stacking can get annoying to some, especially if playing pvp (you can bring 10 knights to a city and your opponent may have 50 spearmen in there), and a lot of the tool tips and advice online is vague. For example, corruption is very vaguely explained, but basically production and commerce will be thrown away to varying degrees based on government type, generally proximity to your capital (though Communism gives an exception), and number of cities in your empire (the more cities, the more corruption will become a factor up to a certain unspecified cap). Also, if playing pvp, if someone gets large enough, turns start taking large amounts of time, so I believe there is a timer feature, but depending on how you look at it, it could be an unfair penalty to someone doing well with a military approach, or it could be a handicap on a player that is doing too well to make the game more balanced.

Also, this may just be me, but the game can and will crash on Windows 10 (usually fairly predictable, though, at victory screen and potentially at startup). Also, there is a feature that's supposed to show events on the world map at the victory screen, but that entire feature was bugged on my last playthrough (the cities appeared on the map prior to their founding, and pointers to events didn't appear at all, though cultural boundaries showed up properly). I haven't had it randomly crash mid game, so it at least seems very stable there.

Still, really enjoy this game coming back to it. Highly recommend if you think that the newer civs feel slow due to little map movement or if you just want a bit of nostalgia or some context on how far Civ has come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053280003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1608312668}
review:
This is obviously a classic. It's a great game and it will go down into history. Also, I didn't like it.

Why? Because once I've played other Civ games I can see it's shortcomings and to be fair I cannot find an excuse to play it other than a newer one. It's not only about missing features or clarity, either.

Firstly, I hate the strategy necessary to beat this game. It's always expanding like a madman leaving everything behind but rushing settlers and workers with enough military to defend them while trading techs to the AI. That's it. You have a wide territory, you have a tech lead, and with so many  towns that you can effectively have hundreds of units out. That takes hundreds of turns and it's kind of boring and repetitive.

It was groundbreaking and incredible when I was younger, but after being spoiled by having to actually think very hard about funding new cities and having everything in order or risking falling behind; and having all of my builds make a difference instead of crapping out settlers... I'll sadly have to say the Classic was improved upon in my subjective opinion.

That said; it's pretty cheap; and still probably better than Civ VI (again, my opinion); but not better than Civ V or IV. It definitely deserves being bought and all of its positive reviews; I simply can't leave a positive one without being a liar.

review: i played this game since i was back in early grade school. my brother and i saw this game for the first time while our dad was playing it and we fell in love with it. Its hard to jump in right away but its like any other cid game out there. However, i believe this games npc are really thought out well and to achieve total military rule against the opponents are the hardest cid has come out with. i would suggest taking the time to read what each building or achievement does before doing so. it would seriously help you in the end when its just you and couple of other nations left.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035127891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1557020024}
review: I've played Civ 2-6 and still return to this from time to time. There's a straightforward, addictive "infinite expansion" element to Civ 3. It strikes a nice balance as it fixes a bunch of the annoyances of Civ 2, has a bunch of victory conditions, and it's not  weighted down by a bunch of other mechanics that are introduced in 4-6.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987281453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1457317916}
review:
First off: it's a classic. It set the stage for many to come and has for the most part held up over the years.

The best part of this Civ that sets itself apart from the others is the ability to stack units endlessly. This allowed you the ability to take over cities that normally would be too hard for the level of tech you have. The game play is smooth. The maps seem bigger back then compared to now. The movement however could have used some fixing up for pc.

All in all, its worth the money even today.

review:
If you had a pickle and an egg and were expected to make a good video game you might try your hand at crafting a game about kings and science and dynasties and stuff. You could pour all of the time you have left on earth into this bountiful feast of a game... but in the end you have a shit game and a pickle and an egg. 
Just toss it out and get yourself Civ III, the game that destroyed an empire and then rebuilt it for kicks. Seriously, it's $5 for a moments you will remember for the rest of your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009962850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2159, 'last_played': 1636937536}
review:
6/10 (edited)

Seriously hard version of Civ! Like music, I think if you played this when younger you need to come back. Younger players will probably avoid the dated graphics and miss the challenge.  

I bought this when it came out, tried it, and got side-tracked by life and Civ IV, which I assumed must be better. Bought it again, cheap, on Steam and just got back into it, and WOW! This is a much tougher game than any other Civ I have yet played. How tough? I have been playing different Civs since Civ I was new. I am used to usually trying to maximize my cities, population, etc., and running up my score. Just to get a viable civ, I had to set AI aggression to the lowest level, even while playing at the lowly "Warlord" level. And I am still behind in several areas. Even at such a low level, enemies seek any weak cities to attack, establish cities in any open space in your continent, and are generally aggressive. Even Gandhi is psychotic! 

OK, what about the game? Lots of changes. One is the increased role of random luck. Now certain resources are needed to build units and wonders, even after you discover the tech. No Iron mines in your land? So much for swordsmen, legions, tanks, etc. No horses? No cavalry, chariots, etc. No saltpeter? No firearm units at all (including naval.) Get lucky and have Ivory early? You can build the Statue of Zeus and generate super-cavalry centuries before your enemies have anything close. To get resources you can now build "colonies" away from cities. The diplomacy is unforgiving. Also, strategic resources only emerge when you can use them, again if you are lucky. So cut-down your jungles and marshes and your chances of oil and rubber go way down! Also, barbarians re-spawn if you leave any territory undeveloped. 

Each civilization also gets its own special units. Ancient civs get them early, like Aztecs, Incas, and Hittites. Modern ones have to wait for Panzers and F-15s (by which time they may not be around or have the needed resources. Characteristics also determine starting tech and advantages in science, exploration, industry, etc. So picking your starting civ is no longer just a beauty contest. 

Downsides too: Graphics are 19 years old and not much improved on Civ 2 (some versions were better.) City view and wonder animations are pretty dull, as is your palace. Automation is terrible. AI workers always want to build mines not irrigated farmland. So you need to be very hands-on in city management, etc. And, as mentioned, the AI is really almost way too hard. This game is NOT for the casual player who just wants to build a nice civilization and a Hall of Fame score. Even lowest difficulty settings feel 'impossible.' There is an actual 'Impossible" level which is then superseded by the "Sid" level. I doubt I will ever make it to that one. I am not even sure Sid can win at that level! 

Since playing through, I have discovered a serious flaw, at least for me. When I reached the end, only once did the somewhat lame victory screen process. Since then I cannot get to a final screen, HoF, etc. Must lower my rating. This seems be a an issue with this version as it did not happen with CD-ROM. 

Bottom-line: $5 (or less on sale) buys you a whole lot of game for your money with hours of gameplay and even frustration. This is not for the casual gamer, but don't let the age and graphics fool you. This is a great challenge for hardcore 4X gamers! Don't be fooled that 4-6 must be harder than 3. This game makes Civ 4 look easy!

review: This was the first Civ I ever played and after all these years its still my favorite. Sure the newer ones have fancy features and events and are still great games. But I stand by the idea that limiting the game to 1 unit per tile ruined warfare. Gone is the rush of breaking a defensive line and charging through, no more strategically using artillery and air power to slaughter a doomstack before it reaches your city. And the mods for CivIII truly made it an even better game with the custom and historical scenarios.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970806841', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1605397249}
review:
Ho giocato al primo capitolo di questa saga sul mio Amiga 500, troppi anni orsono. In quell'occasione il gioco mi è piaciuto e mi ci sono trovato abbastanza bene mentre non posso dire altrettanto per questo terzo capitolo.

Non ci ho capito un tubo, il gioco è eccessivamente complesso, specialmente all'inizio, e non c'è uno straccio di spiegazione di quello che è necessario fare e come si debba iniziare ad ingranare.

Dulcis in fundo il gioco va in crash spesso (forse perché quando è uscito girava su Windows 98).

Pur piacendomi un sacco i giochi di strategia questo proprio non ha fatto breccia, mi spiace.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000186720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 57388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27811, 'last_played': 1705278796}
review:
Jogo muito viciante. Como é estratégia em turnos, sempre da pra gastar o tempo necessário para decidir o que fazer. Trilha sonora bem agradável. Achei bem difícil e pouco intuitivo, mesmo nos níveis mais fáceis, e tem pouco material na internet. Fui aprendendo sendo amassado pela AI. 

Por ser antigo tive alguns problemas do jogo relacionados a compatibilidade: 
1) Ao criar novo mapa, com frequência congelava no escrito "configuring barbarians". Para isso não acontecer, o programa deve ter sido iniciado sem modo de compatibilidade.
2) Ao ter uma batalha, a tela congela por alguns segundos e destrava quando a batalha termina, o que é muito incômodo. Pra isso não acontecer você deve jogar em modo de compatibilidade com Windows 8.
- Ou seja, abra o jogo, crie o mapa (NEW GAME), salve, feche o jogo, inicie em modo de compatibilidade windows 8, vá em (LOAD GAME) e jogue sem problemas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961852910', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 8101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7488, 'last_played': 1620575220}
review:
Having recently played Civ 2, 3, 5, 6 and Beyond Earth. I can say that Civ 3 is second only to Civ 5, and not by much.

Civ 3 plays very differently from the newer versions. The game does not punish you for being at war and the AI has no problems declaring war. You can expect to lose many units while at war. Early in the game it feels like a land grab trying to settle everywhere you can. Happiness is more interesting to deal with than simply nation wide happiness. Choosing what to build where and when feels easier to decide, giving more time to consider what to do next. Corruption is a thing.

The game is all around simpler than the modern games. The only thing you have to manage is the cites, your units and your relations with the other nations.

I wish it were easier to explain how a simpler Civ can make a better Civ. 

I highly recommend that everyone who enjoys Civ 5 or 6 play Civ 3. You will gain or regain, a love for Civilization.

also feel I must say, Civ Beyond Earth although beautiful, was by far the worst.

review: per me il civ finale, tutte le altre versioni non hanno che appesantito il gioco, nel 4 l'introduzione delle religioni ha complicato di troppo la costruzione nelle città, dovevi costruire più templi, minareti che altro. nel 5 hanno equilibrato la cosa ma ridotto il numero unità, nel 6 hanno complicato la costruzione delle città in generale la gestione delle guerre è irrealistico nei nuovi civ. se si vuole un civ da giocare senza fine è senz'altro questo. la grafica sarà datata ma il motore di gioco il migliore

review: I have owned this game since its release many years ago, this is simply the best civ game, completely addictive and a little bit boring, i have put hundreds perhaps thousands of hours in to this game, to be honest its too good, i have often wondered why i never played certain games in the past, to realise it was probably this that distracted me, this game is very good, but too addictive and if your one that struggles to put a game down,  leave this one alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198286097485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 24061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12488, 'last_played': 1696873445}
review: I love this game more than the other Civilization games. I watched my dad play this game when I was a kid and I am still playing it today. People say it does not work or res does not work. All it takes is a simple line of code you imput and boom res is just fine. Otherwise the game is perfect. Never crashes, is harder than any of the other Civ games. I love the art style a lot I would pick it up and give it a try. If you are having issues with the res look up a quick guide takes 2 mins max to fix. And everyone saying it's bugged or the AI cheats. They are wrong and probably are not good at the game or don't understand how everything works. I keep beating the game and slowly getting to harder difficulties and have found no problems in the game play or functions.  Give the game a shot and if you are someone who gave it a bad review maybe try and read up on how the game works :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198182364070', 'num_games_owned': 1099, 'num_reviews': 493, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1602022149}
review:
Bu sıralar nostalji odaklı takılmaya başladım. Kütüphanemde bulduğum iyi oyunlardan sadece bir tanesi bu.

Yine zamanının efsaneleşmiş strateji oyunlarından birisidir. Her yazımda belirttiğim gibi strateji türüyle çok aram olmasa bile gayet keyif alarak oynamıştım. Serinin yeni çıkan oyunlarıyla uzaktan yakından bağım yok ancak eskiden bu oyunu saatlerce oynadığımı çok iyi hatırlıyorum. Age of Empires 2 ve bu, çocukluğumuzu çalan oyunlar arasında yer almakta :D

Ama Windows 10 uyumluluğu haliyle rezalet ötesi. Oyun çok zor çalışıyor, tam ekran olmuyor, kasıyor, donuyor falan filan. Belki 10 kullanıcısı olmayanlar daha rahat oynayabilir. Fiyatı da bana gayet uygun geldi. Ama uyumluluk sorununu dikkate almanızı öneririm.

[b]Puan: 77 / 100 [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198095917598', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 1793, 'playtime_forever': 3586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1665911660}
review: I grew up playing this game, 15 years later I'm still learning more. Stacks of doom, pollution, anarchy, civil disorder, roads everywhere, right of passage tricks, and the ever expanding AI. I once heard about the AI building a railroad to another AI before declaring war. It doesn't get better than this. Old but gold, classic best strategic beast. Civilization III was one of my childhood' timetraveller machine. I started to play at the afternoon and i finished the game next morning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198298182801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4056, 'last_played': 1705282333}
review: There are new, better, and more exciting games out there. So if you prefer that, then this game isn't for you. However, if you really like old classic games, then this is a good one to have. What I like about this old relic is the simple, slow paced, and somewhat out-dated game play. The graphics and special features are no longer advanced by today's standards, but they're still good enough to capture your imagination. The game starts of slow, but gets more exciting as the game advances. Interestingly, the beginning and most boring part of the game is the most critical. If you're like me and prefer to dominate through military force, every action matters. The most satisfying part of the game is proving your superiority by conquering other civilizations, especially when the AI gangs up on you. Be warned: Don't start what you can't finish. AI players love to gang up on human players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120519011', 'num_games_owned': 1113, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1601568051}

Но пока что не судьба. Не рекомендовать, конечно же, не могу, т.к. классика. Но минус за оптимизацию. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198160495995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1601454779}
review:
Nope, sorry. I liked the original Civilization from the early 90's. This effort though technically better with a lot more content, just falls flat. It has none of the charms of Civ 1, in fact I found Civ 3 to be dull and tedious.
The UI simply stank. One simple reason for this is it not allowing you the standard "right click to DESELECT unit". So you always had a unit selected - and as a result often clicked somewhere on the map and off it went, moving to that spot when you did not want it to. So you go to correct it. You click said wrong move unit, but no...... can't select it because of "this unit has already moved", BUT what then happens is ANOTHER unit has become active, which the map did not autocentre on (so you had no idea it had automatically selected another unit), and it then starts with unwanted movement!
You probably don't understand all that - it's hard to put into words. But the terrible UI had me constantly wrong moving entire chains of units all over the place.
The UI is very "non-standard" and it is difficult to get any information regards anything conveniently. There isn't even a proper world map view - the only one you get is a tiny thumbnail sized map that is just a jumbled mess of colours.
You never know where the enemy is. You never know where anything is. You never have the "big picture". You never feel in control. You are constantly fighting your own ministers who are obsessed with building unneeded and extremely expensive "wonders" in every city!
Then comes the AI sides. Even on easiest level and lowest aggression, they just all gang up on you. They all stroke each other peckers, but give you the cold shoulder, refusing all diplomatic requests you make - and never offering any treaties or trades to you. They only contact you with one or two unfair tech trades at the start, and from then on it's only to make bullying demands and declare war. They all share techs and treaties with each other though - with great gusto!
Once one inevitably decides to go to war against you, ALL the others follow suit within the next few turns. They never go to war with each other.
All AI civs are also BRUTALLY, profanely cheating, expansionists. This kind of AI is anathema to my usual style and I loathe and detest it. In Civ 3 this AI style is *all* you get....... every game ends the same after 100-200 turns, no matter how aggressively you try to expand, the AI teams just fills up the whole world with one giant "anti-YOU" alliance and all declare war and crush you.
This unfairness ruins Civ III. I just had to quit/uninstall in frustration. 
The graphics are also rather bland, nay, downright ugly - the civ leader portraits are a joke - and the music is awful.

Extremely disappointing, I expected so much more from this game. Lets not mince words, I loathed it.

And as for 99% of the reviewers around here thinking the sun shines out this game's arse, well they're wrong! It shows how intelligent these reviewers are when hundreds of them are spam that just say "relaxing", "gud game", "is fun", "classic" - hell, one spam review even just said "."! Others tell outright LIES such as "every game is different"...... no every game ends in the cheating AI civs all ganging up on you.

It's reviews like these that fool people into wasting their money on dog shit like Civ 3!

author: {'steamid': '76561198120392422', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2869, 'last_played': 1695049690}
review:
Civilization. Series, that I knew only from stories. And now I am here, writing a review about one of many entries to this series. Civilization III, was my first game from Civilization series which I got for free from Humble Bundle about year ago I suppose. Decided to give it a try, and I loved it. 
Civilization III, is third entry of Civilization series- games, that defined 4x genre. And this game also defined, what modern Civilization games are.
Thirst of all, this is first game in this series, when factions got something, that made them special. Not to the point, where it went down made them totally unique, like in modern titles, but factions were discreided by limited number of strenghts, which all other actions had in diffrent combinations. 
It is also first Civilization game, where you were able to win through you culture. 
The rest, is nihili novi nothing new, but all already exeisting mechanics works so well, that these small additions are perfect to the another step in progress.
Is it worth buying this game for its full price? If I knew ealier, that this is so good. I would buy it.
Does this game has prooblems on modern OS? On Windows 7 works well, beside one problem, which is soemtimes gamedoesnt open and shows only intro. In that case, you had to unistall form Steam. It will not unistall opened game, but it will "crash" to the point, where it will properly work again.
On Winowds 10 some people have problems and for some it works just fine. Ask in Internet for clues.
I highly reccomend it. Also the graphics is nice. It sparks Joy :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198016365353', 'num_games_owned': 1032, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1599225760}
review:
Non ho molto da dire se non che è stato il mio primo titolo della serie: amore a prima vista e l'inizio di una lunga storia d'amore fatta di turno, spazio, turno, spazio, turno...
I ricordi di infanzia, un po' sbiaditi, tornano a galla vividi già dall'introduzione, dalle musiche, dai menù e, infine, dalla prima schermata di gioco. Non è invecchiato male, ma credo che il mio tempo con lui ormai sia finito: è un piacere averlo in libreria e lo consiglio a chiunque voglia giocare una pietra miliare della storia degli strategici/gestionali, nonché uno dei migliori capitoli della fortunata saga.

Cheers...a Sid!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076965868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6249, 'last_played': 1481221065}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021099938', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1604699176}
review:
The best game of the series for me. I've played in my childhood in a non-Steam version, and I am confident that I played more than 300 hours of it. First 4x strategy I've played in my life, and still the best one. This game made me fall in love with Civ series, made me play every part (except Civ 1).
I've tried to play steam version once with friends, but we couldn't even start the match. So beware of the issues, which can be related both to the Steam specifics or just sheer age.
However, singleplayer is still playable.
Even these technical issues can't turn me into giving a negative review - that's how much I love the game.
Unique game, which will remain forever in my memory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119716627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2475, 'last_played': 1637795452}
review:
Very easy to get into, not too basic but not too complex and is very fun for first timers, all the extra maps and scenarios provide a lot of extra gameplay past just the default "New Game" option. If you try to just use intuition and not rely on guides or videos, it can be very rewarding when you raise the difficulty bar from "Easiest" to "Warlord"!

What I don't like about it is the mild RNG aspect but that's like reality, you're not always going to have favourable conditions in your country and it's your job to find a work-a-round. Sometimes it works in your favour though, I consider it a challenge. Games can get pretty slow late game though and can be a big time investment but if that's your thing, that's all the better.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198880157656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4035, 'last_played': 1696689013}
review: Not as good as civ 2.  All the AI's follow the same pattern of growth, goals and personality.  Whether they like you or not they will attack you if their army is better than yours so diplomacy is redundant (and they know the exact details of your army).  The AI's also know the full map including where your cities are and where is best to build, so that's annoying.  However I like to run this in the background when I'm playing other games so I don't get board.  Worth about the 0.79p I paid for it.  If you liked civ 2 don't bother buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198397923950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1598371480}
review:
- 도대체 얼마나 재미있길래 사람들이 자꾸 문명하셨는지 궁금해서 플레이해봄.

- 몇몇 리뷰어님들의 시간을 잊은 듯한 어마어마한 플레이 타임을 보자니 내가 감히 감상을 써도 되는지 모르겠으나.. AOE, Warcraft, Cultures, the Settlers, Caesar 등 겹치는 요소들이 조금씩 들어있는 작품들을 이미 플레이해본 입장에서는 딱히 신선하거나 혁신적이지 않았고 훌륭한 고전 게임이란 느낌.

- 평화주의자라 가능한 전쟁이 벌어지지 않게끔 세팅해놓고 마치 1930년대 유럽 주요국가들이 독일에게 했듯이 appeasement 정책이나 펼치면서 조용히 관개하고 광산 짓고 궁전 세우고 기술 발전시키다가 끔.

- 게임성은 좋으나 개인적으로는 실시간적 요소가 없는 삼국지류의 전략 시뮬(물론 삼국지 시리즈도 9는 half real-time에 가까우나)이 더 잘 맞는 듯. 죄송해요 시드 마이어님. 잘생긴 사람이 만인의 취향은 아니듯이 잘만든 게임이라고 다 제 취향은 아니더라고요. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198329876551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7118, 'last_played': 1705885866}
review:
While I have not yet played the sixth installment in the series, Civ III is, to me, the pinnacle of this great franchise. Having played the original and Civ II before this, it took a while to get used to... there are so many new features, so many new potential win conditions, and so many outmoded strategies (for example, the Great Wall, once a royal "screw you" to your AI opponents regardless of play level, is now just shy of completely useless).

Not only is the game itself a gem, but there is still, to this day, a thriving community of passionate players who have devoted thousands of hours between them to analyzing the game, sharing their tactics and stories of epic victories and crushing defeats for new players to learn from. In particular, the folks over at CivFanatics will be happy to help you get your feet wet if this is your first venture into this classic game. Not only that, but many people have created incredible mods for the game as well, which all add a new dimension to play.

More balanced and challenging than it's predecessors, and (IMHO) more fun than it's first two successors, Civ III is a deep strategy game that will keep you merrily planning space flights, cultural domination, or global subjugation for a long, long time. There is, however, one glaringly irritating feature that does need to be discussed. 

The AI. Like most strategy games of it's era (and even many modern ones), the computer does not play any more intelligently on higher difficulties. Instead, artificial difficulty is created by invoking TCIACB (if you don't know that trope, look it up). As you progress to harder and harder difficulties, the AI opponents get MONSTROUS bonuses to production, research speed, starting units, etc. The only ways in which the actual playstyle of computer opponents changes as you progress is that civs are more likely to be aggressive at higher difficulties, and are more likely to trade amongst themselves (which is, admittedly, a very high-impact change).

Despite that one flaw, I would highly recommend this game to any fan of turn-based strategy and management games. As well as anyone who doesn't ardently hate them.  Heck, even if you DO hate them, pick it up; if any game can change your mind about the entire genre, I'm gonna go out on a limb here and say this is the one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059691076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8232, 'last_played': 1704682790}
review: This was one of the first regular PC games I use to play almost 2 decades ago when it was released.  The game concept has changed dramatically over the years and graphics have gotten considerably better but this original has still stood the test of time (pun intended).  If you have never played a Sid Meier's Civilization game before, I'd recommend Civilization III Complete.  Again, it doesn't have all the graphics and intricacies of the latest edition but it can be played on virtually any computer and provides the basic theme on how other, new versions will work.  I highly recommend this game.
