author: {'steamid': '76561198120567690', 'num_games_owned': 938, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 11860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11860, 'last_played': 1588854487}
review:
At first, [i]Civilization 3[/i] seems like the ideal turn-based city building strategy game and an improvement over [i]Civilization 2[/i] (let's not talk about Civilization 1, it was very primitive and full of flaws). It has everything a game of this genre needs: relatively free control over our cities, lots of buildings, interesting technologies, advanced diplomacy and so on. Despite the undeniably enjoyable gameplay however, its numerous shortcomings become immediately apparent as soon as we start playing. And no, these problems are not related to the fact that in the time of this review it has become obviously obsolete, these problems were and should have been annoying back in 2001, when the game was released. What makes things worse and the main reason why I disapprove of this game is that it's a step back from its 'predecessor', the amazing [url=en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sid_Meier%27s_Alpha_Centauri]Alpha Centauri[/url].

There are 24 different nations altogether (the maximum we can set is 16) and besides having different animated portraits of the given leaders, each of them start the game with 2 traits. But since there are only 8 of these, the game fails to make the nations diverse and unique enough (as they were in Alpha Centauri). The starting technology is set by the given traits and to add some variety each civilization has an own, special unit. The Aztecs for example have the Jaguar Warrior, which is as strong as a regular warrior (which other nations have access to), but can move 2 tiles per turn instead of just 1 - making it very useful right at the start of the game; while the Americans have F-15s instead of the normal jet fighters, that are capable of lethal land bombardment, but they can only be accessed in advanced eras.

The core basics remained: we start the game in 4000 BC with a single settler (with which we can establish our first city) and a worker. The resources around the starting location are abundant so we should found our city immediately. A road network around our city is mandatory - this should be our worker's job. Then we need a warrior, who can explore the surrounding area to discover hidden technologies, find money or even convince native tribes to join us (we receive another settler or warrior). After this, our main goal is to expand by establishing more cities and to research new sciences to become more effective. The placement of new cities is very important (something the AI don't always care about): when fully grown, they all have a maximum area of 6 neighbouring tiles (2x3) in each directions, so it's imporant to have at least 4-4 tiles between each city, this way they won't interfere and slow down the growth of each other. When establishing a city it is important to have valuable resources within its reach (some will only appear later in the game, when the related tech is researched.)
On the city screen we can set the production (even multiple ones) and gather information about workforce, taxes, happiness, food, culture, etc.. It may appear confusing at first, but after some experimenting, it won't be. Happiness (smiling portraits) and production efficiency (little blue shields) are the most important since if our citizens are in a bad mood, they'll riot and refuse to build or train anything.
The little text bubble in the upper left corner opens the Domestic Advisor screen, where we can adjust whether we want to spend our income on general happiness or scientific research. We need money to upkeep our buildings and military units plus to hurry the actual production (we can't hurry the production of Wonders).
Wonders are probably the most important things in the game: without having the most useful ones, we [u]can't win[/u] the game. Each wonder can only be built once and the nation who builds it first, gets it exclusively. They are linked to certain scientific discoveries (the game's encyclopedia gives a good insight about them). As soon as we have the technology, we must immediately start building the given wonder in our most advanced/industrialized city, preferrably our capital (the Colossus for example gives a bonus income to the city that builds it, basically throughout the rest of the game). Building a wonder can also initiate a golden age for 20 turns, providing a production boost to ALL our cities.
Wonders and religious or educational buildings provide culture points to the given city which can convert nearby foreign cities and make them join us peacefully. The effective range of this 'cultural conversion' is rather limited though, it worked better in Alpha Centauri.

Fighting others will cost plenty of money, taking it away from useful researches and improvements, so I suggest taking out the nasty and aggressive neighbours as early in the game as we can.
The AI is VERY agressive (I had many problems with the Americans and Zulus): they will betray our trust as soon as the size of our military isn't large enough to scare them off, so having a moderately powerful (and modern) army is ALWAYS necessary.
Although military units have separate offensive and defensive values with hitpoints as well, the problem of insane results (like a tank gets defeated by a musketeer, usually in favour of the AI) known from the previous games may still occur. To make things worse, all these manipulated results seem to be pregenerated, so if we reload the game, we're still going to lose just like before... This was also done better in Alpha Centauri.
Diplomacy is the same as it was in the previous game (yes, Alpha Centauri) and works pretty well, although it has its faults. If we are in a military alliance with a nation and we make peace with another nation we fought against together previously, our ally will take it as an aggressive act (even though they have already called truce themselves). Advanced diplomatic actions require an embassy in the capital of the given nation.
There are several ways to achieve victory: through culture, annihilation (takes an eternity, good luck with that), diplomatic means (UN) or space launch (this one is by far the easiest, the AI seems to have problems reaching this). We also have to be careful to establish the United Nations headquarters, because if one of our enemies does, they are going to make us lose the game by voting against us.

The only resolution the game supports is 1024x768, which looks stretched out on a 16:9 screen. There is a way to make it fullscreen, but I'd vote against it as it can cause other problems (as it was in my case where I had to launch the game separately from the steam launcher :/)
Later on, when there are hundreds of units on the map, enemy turns and loading times can take entire [b]minutes[/b] to complete. This technical failure was also present in [url=store.steampowered.com/app/3900/Sid_Meiers_Civilization_IV/]Civilization 4[/url].
There are many small details that improve the game, but almost every one of these are flawed or don't work properly.
What truly shocked me, that there was no EARTH world map in the core game, only randomly generated ones. There are custom fanmade maps where we can find some, but... really? Also when we set the given nations, they don't always start where they are supposed to (Ottomans in America?).
When playing on monarch difficulty (which I chose) or above, the game shamelessly cheats, corruption doesn't seem to affect the AI while this will be a major hit for us (every city that isn't close to our capital takes a huge penalty at everything) and also seems to suffer no ill-effects of having vast armies while having democracy...

There are many problems with [i]Civilization 3[/i] which spoil the gameplay and make it inferior to either [i]Civilization 4[/i] or [i]Alpha Centauri[/i]. Go and play those instead of this one.

PROS
+ plenty of improvements over Civilization 2

CONS
- buggy, many things don't work as they are described
- no Earth map amongst the official map set
- insane loading times
- cheating AI

RATING
2/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198302056432', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6282, 'last_played': 1693146516}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III: Complete jest jedną z najlepszych gier swoich czasów i moją ulubioną z serii Civilization. Jest bardzo dobrym symulatorem rozwoju cywilizacji, której celem jest takie kierowanie rozgrywką, by nasza cywilizacja była potężniejszą od innych. Podoba mi się mechanizm zwycięstwa w kilku różnych opcjach, dzięki czemu możemy wygrać na kilka sposobów jednocześnie zapobiegając, by zrobili to inni gracze (komputerowi lub realni). Zaczynamy jako pojedyncza jednostka, ostrożnie planując ruchy w pierwszych turach, tworzymy pierwsze miasta, pierwsze jednostki wojskowe dbamy o rozwój i ekonomię, podtrzymujemy odpowiednie relacje z innymi, prowadzimy handel i budujemy drogi. Potem prowadzimy pierwsze wojny lub skupiamy się na innym sposobie na wygraną np. wyścigu kosmicznym. Rozgrywka trwa zwykle kilka godzin, czasem kilkanaście dzięki czemu mamy dużo czasu zabawy. 
Mechanika gry nigdy nie została do końca doprecyzowana, zdarzają się sytuacje w której zwykły wojownik z epoki starożytnej w pojedynkę niszczy dwa czołgi, albo potężny krążownik jest zatapiany przez małą drewnianą łódkę barbarzyńców. Komputerowi gracze grają często na cheatach, a transportowiec, który pomieści 6 czołgów, nie zmieści już 7 cywilnych pracowników. Do dyspozycji mamy również edytor, ale włączenie rozgrywki na mapie stworzonej w edytorze wyłącza część funkcji w grze np. podgląd miast z lotu ptaka. Mimo tych drobnych nieprawidłowości gra jest warta polecenia, szczególnie dla graczy lubiących budowanie.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041109784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 7011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5699, 'last_played': 1651344729}
review: Classique du genre, indémodable malgré son age, souvenirs de mon enfance. De bonne qualité, très complet, jouabilité avec de bonnes possibilités, bien pensé, difficulté pour tout le monde (j'ai fini des campagnes en empereur, mais en divinité ca devient compliqué, on a l'impression que l'ia est unlimited ammo lol) qualité sonore d'époque qui peu buguer mais qui est sympa. Certains trouvent dommage que le portage steam ne se fait qu'en anglais, pour ma part je n'y fait même pas attention, mais il est vrai que cela peut être incommodant pour ceux qui ne sont pas a l'aise avec l'anglais. Il peut arriver des plantages et certains points de l'ia ou de la gestion sont exaspérants. Cela dit, il tourne très bien sur mon pc et je ne m'en lasse pas (il suffit de constater le nombre d'heures). Je le recommande surtout s'il est en promo, d'autant qu'au vu de son age, les ressources nécessaires sont accessibles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198820648358', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1614005462}
review:
Не скажу, что отношу себя к так называемым "олдфагам", но эта игра просто божественна именно потому, что с ней связано невероятное количество приятных воспоминаний. Стабильно каждые 3 месяца , возвращаюсь в эту игру, и постоянно нахожу что-то новое. Эта игра реиграбельна как никакая другая. Конкретно в этой части на Стим нет мода Warhammer, который меня и зацепил, но эта проблема исправляется несложно. Найти и установить в папку игры.
Для меня игровая сессия короче недели не получается, и именно это, а не что-либо другое делает эту игру, спустя почти 20 (!) лет игру живее всех живых, и не собирающуюся на покой.
Для 2001-го года 10 из 10. Для 2018-года 7 из 10. Глубокая, развитая, интересная, запустится даже на калькуляторе. Что для счастья нужно?
Сид Мейер! Ты сделал моё детство!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042745242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 25743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13321, 'last_played': 1700181043}
review: The perfect game to keep your hands busy while listening to a podcast or something. I loved this game as a kid, even though I was terrible at it, and I'm still terrible. I think this game has a good amount of detail without being overly complicated. I'm usually not into strategy games, but I love the sense of mystery as I discover new areas and resources and find the perfect spot to place my next city. I also love how subtly cruel the AI characters are, but it's a little sad that it usually turns to war in the end. Lately, I turn off the domination victory so I'm less stressed about building my population and wiping out enemies, and so I'm more inclined to build diplomatic relationships. I also love the vast number of options for countries to play as, and the unique bonuses they each get. An absolute banger of a game.

review: I love this game, it's a great way to kill time and it's very addictive. Figuring out how to play and building a strong strategy is what makes this game fun and the battle animations make you feel in control. The game play reminds me of Risk the board game and I am a very big fan of it. I would highly recommend this game for all Turn based strategy PC gamers.

review:
Я потратил лет 10 в этой игре, до сих пор валяется диск с ней, но она не идёт на 7ке, а отдельно заводить машину с ХР пока лень, но если накопится куча старых любимых игр, которых нет в Стиме....
А вообще то, что Русик зажали - обидно) Но сторонний хорошо встал и ничего не глючит.
Если вы фанат Цивы и начали не с 3 - мне вас жаль. Остальные даже не пробовал, только смотрел обзоры и испытывал "Испанский стыд", это как Цезарь 3, после него уже тлен))) 
Да, ИИ - просто злой. Даже не пробовал играть выше 3 сложности - комп читерит. Это, наверное, своеобразный баланс... Но всё равно я люблю эту игру! Сажусь играть на 10 минут - и ухожу на работу не спав через 10 часов)))

review: If you like turn-based strategy games, any of the Civilization games are right for you. I personally like this installment better than the later additions to the series because I feel like it's not overly complicated for new players to get into, but certainly has enough depth to keep old players coming back and finding new challenges each time. It's not a perfect game, but I think it's worth your time and money still.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062861198', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 4880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4880, 'last_played': 1595963757}
review: "Являясь жоским" фанатом всех Цив, не мог не пройти и 3 часть. Хорошая часть со своими приколами и уникальными функциями, свои чудеса света. Перейду сразу к минусам. Сильный AI, приходится по сложности отпускаться до низов. Много я игр прошёл, но на эту очень трудно было найти русик, и поставился он очень криво, из-за этого пришлось мучатся. Ну и чтобы настроить разрешения,режим окна,приходится лезть в конфиг игры, что я думаю не допустимо для игры 2001-2002года. Онлаин в игре жив,можно найти англ. пати на сайтах или просто в игре. Ставлю лайк, хорошая часть

author: {'steamid': '76561198805427167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 37164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 614, 'playtime_at_review': 14918, 'last_played': 1710894966}
review:
So I first want to preface this that I am baised against this game. This is one of the very first game I ever watched some one play and I have very fond memories of sitting next to my dad watching him play this game for hours so it has a very special place in my heart.

Now that being said this game is the Civilization game you should play if your interested in a aggressive empire building strategy where you want to win through domination or by conquering every other nation in the game. From what I've heard civ six and five kind of drop the war aspect and I can tell form experience that Civ fours military strategy is kind of lacking when compared to civ three. This is in part due to later games kind of getting rid of the "special unit". In civ three every nation has a unique unit that only they can build and each one of them is differrent and offers an improvement over the regular version any other nation can unlock. These units can be a complete game changer for you and your conquest and thus choosing which nation to play as is beyond important as you have to decide about important factors such as what do you wan as a special unit and does it come to late for it to make a differrence in my game.  This game has solid graphics for the time it came out and very good music. 
As all other civ games it's a very good and fun strategy game where you can sink hours into with out even realizing.  
To sum up I would recommend this Civilization game for two reasons one its currently the cheapest on steam and it has to best combat strategy. The later game kind of abandon this part of the game. So if your looking for an empire building game and are interested in nothing else then conquering and destroying every other nation then this is the civ game for you.  If not I would recommend you look at the later civ games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004624916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 32391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18938, 'last_played': 1707934737}
review: I think this is my favorite civ game.  Difficult to win (unlike civ II).  sure graphics, etc. not up to later civ games, but the initial exploration phase is better than  every other civ game, the learning curve is much less than civ IV, V, or VI. (still trying to figure out how to play civ 6).  Custom units for each civ in this game can make a HUGE difference, one of the factors that makes your choice of a civilization very important. (also true in civ 4 and 5). Plus the fact that now this game is super cheap and runs on anything.  Also one of the most stable games I have played.  Can't remember the last time it crashed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012800086', 'num_games_owned': 1196, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1554695778}
review: The civilization games are all, fantastic products. the new ones always build upon and add to the old ones. this was a fun game to play growing up, and i would recommend it to anybody who is looking for an empire building game. 4.5 out of 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198342609458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3877, 'last_played': 1705229350}

author: {'steamid': '76561198125012817', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 40345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 14, 'playtime_at_review': 26913, 'last_played': 1710110876}
review: This is the quintessential turn-based strategy game of my youth. So much has been said and loved on the newer Civilization games, but I find myself always gravitating back to this gem. It's older, not as shiny, and certainly buggy at times, but man does it nail the world building, gameplay, and joy that comes from building an empire from the ground up. Please, please, PLEASE don't ever let this game lose support for more modern Operating Systems. The world would be a sadder place without Civilization III.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042452973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1040, 'last_played': 1690480068}
review:
I have been offline and away from most gaming for a few years with work and all, but recently, I carved out some time to get back in the game.  I am starting with some of my old favorites, so Civ 3 was an easy choice. The turn-based strategy games takes lots of consideration and moves at manageable pace (think family or work needs something right now, so you can temporarily stop or save and come back in an hour or the next day.  The AIs are good enough to be present unpredictable challenges and opportunities.  A great game to make you think about all the things that make a winning strategy or a sorrowful second place.

It is a great break from a FPS (first person shooter) game, or is it the FPS is a good break from the strategic thinker game?

review: I like this more than any of the later games... It is a relaxing game you don't have to micromanage for every single thing. You still can of course, but you don't have to. When I play I want to relax, micromanagement is not the key to relaxation in my opinion. I like that you can also turn off all the "running around" so you don't have the dizzy effect. This is my favourite of the Civ collections, including Civ City Rome. (I have played civ since the first came out, and have tried all the latest ones, for reference).

author: {'steamid': '76561198038479524', 'num_games_owned': 46, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3404, 'last_played': 1671621258}
review:
I've played this game on and off for years, ever since the 'Gold Edition' launched in 2003.

It's easy to pick up, and absorbs your time as you race to expand your civilisation through a combination of growth and military conquest. Various civilisations provide different bonuses which cater to different play styles and strategies. For example, you can gain military bonuses to build large armies, scientific bonuses to facilitate technological advantages, commerce bonuses to offset whatever costs you decide to incur, as well as others.

You can customise the game such as map size and type, AI difficulty, types of victories and accelerated production for a quicker game. Note that large maps often end up taking a lot of time and turns become longer and longer as you manage large numbers of cities and units. Also on harder difficulties, rather than implementing optimum strategies, the AI receives bonuses and becomes ridiculously hard.

If you get bored of the standard random maps, you can load various scenarios that come with the game. There is even a quite comprehensive map editor which allows for custom maps and rules. You can create your own custom resources, units, techs, governments and civilisations. It's even possible with just the map editor to build cities on water.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096024796', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5115, 'last_played': 1591508435}
review:
I poured hundreds if not thousands of hours into Civ III before I got it on Steam. It's a classic game that still stands strong, though there are some odd graphics problems from time to time considering it was made to run on Windows XP.

If you buy it, do yourself a favor and download Rise and Rule Revisited, a wonderful mod from CivFanatics: https://forums.civfanatics.com/threads/rise-and-rule-revisited-epic-mod.549166/

RARR adds countless new units, nations, and technologies to the game. It adds a lot more variety to a simplistic game but fun game.

review:
On one hand, I had huge clip rate issues, particularly later in scenarios as the computer animated faster than the game. 

On the other hand, there's something satisfying for a player who normally goes for Scientific or diplomatic victory to lead Xerxes on a successful campaign to take down DC and Tenochtitlan within a few turns.

review: I love this game, I have played it since it came out all those years ago and am thrilled to have it here. It is one of the best turn based strategy games i have played with an in game Civepedia that gives you some historical facts about almost every part of the game. So if you like history and creating unit stacks of doom to roll over your enemies this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960532969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 1408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1621375275}
review: The AI cheats, a bunch of bits of the game are so opaque no one's sure how they work 20 years after release, and certain civs are overpowered in general or in specific ages.  It's still a great game with all the depth and variety of a Civ game.  As a follow up to the legendary Alpha Centauri it can feel like a bit of a letdown at first, but it has a unique charm all its own.  A solid 4X, and well worth the purchase price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198435698366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 59784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4180, 'last_played': 1707360917}
review: Gra, w której nowoczesne czołgi potrafią przegrać bitwę z antycznymi łucznikami. Bo tak! Na dodatek granie z komputerowym przeciwnikiem to granie nie ze sztuczną inteligencją, a ze zwykłym cziterem, który na start ma odkrytą całą mapę, gra cały czas zespołowo mimo osobnych nacji, nie musi się martwić o finanse i morale, a jednostki i budowle potrafią mu się budować w pół rundy. Jakby było mało, to bug bugiem pogania. Krótko mówiąc - jak nie jesteście fanami prostej, izometrycznej grafiki, to lepiej już sobie nie psujcie tym tytułem nerwów.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277662078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2419, 'last_played': 1590743938}
review: A classic masterpiece.  Never gets old.  I would play the newer versions but lack an advanced graphics card.  Logged 1000's of hours on civ3.    My many X gf's hated it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078096426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1166, 'last_played': 1594532529}
review: Antes debo aclarar que este juego es muy inferior a sus antecesores. Mi primer Civilization fue el segundo de su entrega en PSONE. Aquel juego me fascinó en todos los sentidos. En su contenido histórico(lleno de textos explicativos y detallados), en sus vídeos, en su música, los consejeros etc etc etc... Un juego que a día de hoy hace más de 20 años, en mi opinión, no ha sido superado por ninguno de los que le han precedido. Es muy triste. Ya que si, muchos le superan en gráficos. Pero ninguno tiene ese encanto, esa lección de historia después de cada descubrimiento... Aun así este juego esta bien para ser un juego de estrategia por turnos y lo recomiendo. Pero no es digno de ser un Civilization igual que no lo son las 4 entregas siguientes

author: {'steamid': '76561198119453561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 69063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1686187237}
review: When I (or another) Civ discovers a new advance that unlocks a new Strategic Resource (Iron Working), I noticed that I don't get the resource in the area that I control/explored.  This can be really crippling when you reach the Industrial Age.  Especially when your opponents get the Strategic Resources right away.  Is there a patch available that can fix that?

author: {'steamid': '76561198123901980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3937, 'last_played': 1654142857}
review:
If one likes games that have a real world sense of actions and impacts, and gives insight to the how the larger world around them operates this is a great game. I use Civ III because later versions such as Civ V got too complex and cumbersome. III is simpler, whiles still challenging.

I can guarantee one thing, if Bush & Company had played Civ III long enough they never would have invaded Iraq, let alone Afghanistan. Invading is one thing, occupying is completely different. Could have saved a lot of lives and treasure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198293799888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 50985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25182, 'last_played': 1652742717}
review: I love this game more than any other game, but playing on Steam is so frustrating. There are so many problems I cannot even begin to talk about them. In a nutshell, be prepared to never enjoy a multiplayer game unless you want hot seat because as soon as you do, a crash occurs. I have had this game on Steam for a decade; trust me, there is no fix.

review: Very very addicting and time consuming. Once you get the game mechanics down by either playing for more than 40 hours or watching 5 youtube videos on the mechanics (I reccomend Suede Civ III) then you'll be ready to play on Regent (the normal game mode). A lot of good mods already come preinstalled and there are hundreds more to download off of the official website. Fun game if you like strategy games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074567556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1588802971}
review:
Несмотря на то что сам фактически являюсь фанатом подобных игр и Цивилизации в частности (начинал с 1 части в мохнатые года), сейчас обычным игрокам в них играть не рекомендую. В целом по 2 причинам.
1. Нереальное читерство AI, даже на простых уровнях сложности у них все делается в разы быстрее, из-за этого игра либо превращается в нервотрепку, либо в избиение.
2. Итог боестолкновения между двумя юнитами настолько рандомен, что имея атаку например 5 можно проиграть юниту с защитой 1, реально. А потом победить юнита в крепости на холме с защитой 4 и бонусами в районе +150-200% к защите, т.е. фактической защитой 10-12.

Игра только для фанатов.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030792209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2321, 'last_played': 1706337947}
review: If you want a simpler version of Civ, I can't recommend CIV III enough. It is quicker to learn, and much easier to pickup than modern civilization games. Perfect for beginners, and as you can see, I go back all the time when I need a break from other strategy games. The AI isn't too timid and there are trading options that make some of the other Civ games seem lacking. The trading system's simplicity is a big draw, and the lack of other peripherals such as religion and city states allow you to focus on building up your cities and armies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271121216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1588105814}
review:
I failed to take heed of other commenters who warned about the incompatibility issues. I regret making the mistake of purchasing and installing this game, believing that I would not suffer the same problems. Not the case. The game, in its current condition, is severely bugged (but it is also specified in "System Requirements" section of Steam that the game is compatible with Win2000/XP only).

Second problem: The game's AI settings apparently have been changed greatly since when I was playing the basic version of it from a CD, many years ago. I distincly remember how the difficulty would scale in a reasonable manner as you went up in difficulty settings. Not anymore. Probably due to the influence of the modding community, which I suspect would be hardcore gamers, even at the easiest settings the AI is completely focused on spamming cities and units, without a thought for developing their cities. I remember playing around the hardest difficulty settings before. In this version, even at the easiest settings any other civilizations you play against gang up on you from the get go.

I was still greatly pleased with reading the many civilopedia entries and visiting the nice memories of the old appearance of the game. However, I believe it is a broken piece of software now. And considering that it is almost an ancient game today, and that it has had 3 more sequels so far, I don't think any improvements will take place.

I do not recommend this game in its current condition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070969747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 6847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2158, 'last_played': 1589979064}
review: For about $1.30 you can't go wrong. The game is fun, addicting, but also can be very frustrating. The small map on the easiest difficulty is very easy which is fine especially for someone learning. However the same easiest difficulty on the largest maps are not even fun. They enemy AI is garbage at times. They team up against you and there is no way to keep up. If you make more troops it just costs more to support them all and you still get out numbered. I want to play a big game with 16 countries but I can't because of this. The game also crashes a lot but the auto save feature keeps the game easily playable. Another thing I don't like is the enemy is always mad if you walk on their territory. However it's okay for them to walk on your territory. Then when you complain to them too much they declare war. Small map it's not so bad because you can keep up with defending. Large map the other civs team up and it is not fun. I don't really enjoy the small map. Game had so much more potential. Especially being a remake. There is a lot to this game and I have much to learn myself. The amount of customization is the game is amazing. Multiplayer can be a lot of fun with friends. The graphics are good enough for an older game. Sound is great. Expect your knowledge in ancient history to grow the more you play. This game is actually very educational. I give this game 7/10.

review: This is a great quarantine game!  Steam breathed new life into it with updated internet play since the old gamespy internet play was gone.  So you can grind your friends' civilizations into the dirt for hours of fun :-)  Watch out when some of them claim they're just going past to look somewhere else- they may be gathering for a sneak attack without honorably declaring war first!  Plus truly anyone can play, probably ANY Windows machine alive today can run this old game and with the price dirt cheap no one can whine that it's too expensive.  Google for the "KeepRes" ini setting for better screen resolution.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125968650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1588583150}
review:
Решил все таки поиграть в, так называемую, классику.
Играли по сети вдвоем против двух ИИ.
Сразу начали обмен технологиями, что позволяло нам развиваться в 2 раза быстрее любого из противников (ИИ), что прослеживалось и по очкам.
У нас были и чудеса света, и лучшие ученые этого мира, кругом культура и процветание, войска кратно превосходящие противника (который, напоминаю, ИИ)
Один из ИИ объявил мне войну, пришел ко мне одним мечником и В СОЛО перебил всю армию моих воинов и копейщиков.
Напоминаю, это при двукратном отставании по технологиям. Т.е. у него чисто теоретически не могло быть более совершенных воинов, чем у меня.
4 часа игры коту под хвост.
Вышли из игры и поклялись больше никогда не заходить в этот нелогичный, забагованый кусок дерьма.
10 читерских ИИ из 10

p.s.
понятно что игра древняя, но все же хочется упомянуть максимально неудобный, кривой, недружелюбный интерфейс и отсутствие обучения в самой игре.
если вы впервые, как и я, решите ознакомиться с этим высером, который почему то многие восхваляют, то у вас нет шансов

author: {'steamid': '76561198069171011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3783, 'last_played': 1659063467}
review: This game can be finicky in the intro and end cut scenes (sometimes freezing the game up from continuing), but the game allows for some intricate victory conditions, and even map setup, to give your chosen civilization either an edge or a challenge. With a gamut of nations, from Rome to Japan, to play as, each with their own unique units and traits, there is never a shortage of replayability and fun. This, and Alpha Centuari, are good choices for those who want to dip their toe into the TBS genre from the genius of Sid Meier without having to spend a lot of money. Overall, this is TBS at its finest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287803632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 56156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 77, 'playtime_at_review': 3528, 'last_played': 1710600041}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012473463', 'num_games_owned': 4062, 'num_reviews': 417, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1587092500}
review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Sid Meier's Civilization III holds classic status for a lot of people, and for good reason. Given its age, it holds up suprisingly well. If this review was only comparing it to its contemporaries, Civilization III would get a perfect score. Unfortunately, when compared to later Civilization games, it begins to falter. The biggest knock against Civilization III isn't really an issue with the game, its just that later games build on its foundation so well. Now that we are on the 6th game in the franchise, there is an entry for everyone. If people want the most modern, sleek, and optimized version of Civilization, they can play 6. If they want an old school feel they can play 4. And if they want a sort of middle ground, the 5th game does a great job balancing those 2 elements. For Civilization III, it plays a lot like Civ 4 but with some pretty popular mechanics missing. To me, Civ 3 doesn't really have a niche that it excels at, and that's why I can't recommend it. Every feature is done better in a different Civ game, leaving little reason for me to revisit it 20 years later.

5/10
[quote]
Visit our [url=https://www.mmmreviews.com]website[/url] for more in-depth reviews and recommendations
[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198303321708', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2877, 'last_played': 1600310653}
review:
Es buen juego. Para empezar a jugar los CIV no lo es, no sé si fui el único que se salteó el tutorial o directamente no había, y con el plus del juego en ingles se me hizo mas difícil jugar. Aún así me gustó y me enganche a jugarlo, es unos de los pocos juegos que me incitó a buscar guías en Youtube y aprender a jugarlo mejor.
Es recomendable comprarlo actualmente? No. El único motivo que vea para que lo compres es que seas fan de los CIV o de los juegos de estrategia y los "colecciones" o simplemente factor nostalgia.
El juego envejeció bien, los gráficos me siguen gustando y me parecen aceptables para la saga CIV.
Si aún así decidís comprarlo o jugarlo por que lo hayas agarrado gratis, descarga un patch para tenerlo en español y hacete un favor y no dejes espacios libres cerca de tus ciudades, la IA lo va a querer colonizar aunque sea un espacio de 2x2 en medio de tus ciudades igualmente lo querrán conquistar

review:
Цива - это когда ацтеки отправляют армию из 50 устаревших юнитов на пограничный город с гарнизоном из пехотинцев
Цива - это когда османцы суют тебе броненосцы в обмен на стандартизацию
Цива - это когда твои кавалеристы не могут пробить пикинера
Цива - это когда майя отправляют копейщика на взятие города
Цива - это когда американцы наклепали овер50 броненосцев дабы попугать твоего советника. У тебя 40 бмп
Цива - это когда американцы, видя твою скорую культурную победу, начинают строить КК. Впрочем, они не успели
Цива - это когда ацтеки вконец тебя задолбали и ты бьешь по ним ядерной бомбой. Так ацтеко-египетская война стала мировой

review:
Terrible. Game crashes and hogs memory still after doing so. Critical failure, continues to hog memory when Steam is rebooted. I could look up how to get it to work, but don't feel like doing that for a 19+ year-old game. Fuck this noise. 

My 12 hours of playtime are mostly from me trying to play other games and thinking my computer was scheistting itself. I played 2 turns then remembered it was 2020 and I can do more with my life. 

Tried to get a refund but whoever runs 2K doesn't care about me (or you). Enjoy!

review:
I'll be honest, I only play this on the easiest difficulty because I like building cities all over the map in much the same way some people enjoy coloring in coloring books. The newer Civ games have more complexity to them but don't let you do that as easily, and this is the one I grew up playing the most, so I like it. 

If you feel the very specific urge to paint the world your color, then pick this up, I guess.

review:
As good and funny game as always but so bad input controls for the user, I wish it would be easier to build and move by using groups of workesr and troops, certainly stack system  helps a lot but it is still not enough, despite of that it's a Classic of Strategy for me and I could play it always. 
The real problem was after installing it and trying to play it at a suitable and good resolution on Windows 10, fortunately the answer was given by noikeee on this post: https://steamcommunity.com/app/3910/discussions/0/864979455450106599/?ctp=3 

Post Quote: 
Hello, i just fixed the problem for me with 1920 res monitor.

I use windows 10. Videmode=1600, Playintro=0.

I think the trick for win10 users is to :
rightclick civ3conquest.exe, preferences, Compatability, Overide high dpi scaling behaviour. Scaling performed by Application.

review:
I like the building aspect of the game mostly. I prefer cultural wins the best. Well and of course Alpha-Centori SPACE WIN is the ultimate win. 
I don't like when you get ganged up on and can't progress because of war. 
Or if you can't get at least a couple Wonders built.
I also don't like when the game is like 1890 and we have machine guns.  I prefer the advances stay in pace more with the age period/

author: {'steamid': '76561198355525302', 'num_games_owned': 872, 'num_reviews': 542, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1585764812}
review:
Да ну на xep.
Игре нужен хотя бы простенький ремастер (но его не будет, скриньте). А сейчас я вижу перед собой мем "китаец с бумажкой": да, на весь экран, но всё очень маленькое. Русификатор донный: видимо, любительский; нужна человеческая локализация. В общем, в нынешнем состоянии игре не помогут даже фанаты. Лучше играйте в пятую часть: так хоть будете играть, а не глаза ломать и безрезультатно ковырять конфиг.

review: Wonderful turn based game, if not for the glitch I'm about to talk about it'd be 10/10 from me, even with the glitch it's still a 7-8/10. The only problem with the game is that if you attempt to click during a cutscene the game will not work and you will be forced to close the game, which wouldn't normally be a big problem except if you get into the game and forget to save for a long time, then win (what happened to me), if you don't click on the x then the wheel of death will appear and the game will be unresponsive and you'll be forced to go all the way back to your last save, which again isn't a big problem if you remember to save often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313270715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 11675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1597440132}
review: Civ 3 was the breakthrough for this classic turn-based strategy franchise. It's just detailed enough as to be intuitive, while not getting overly complicated as the later games in the series. Easy to pick up; hard to put down. Civ 3 was a childhood favorite that occupied hours at a time, and picking it up again after 10+ years is a real treat. It takes small storage and downloads in minutes (hooray for old games!). The graphics and AI are poor, but the nostalgia stands strong. As long as you can bear with the occasional crashes (it maybe didn't age so well? save often!), you'll get a great experience with a most excellent game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198798153901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 77263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3764, 'last_played': 1690609673}
review:
There really should be a neutral option for whether or not you recommend a game, this one is ok, and if it's on sale then maybe you should get it.
It can be fun building cities and expanding to build a vast empire, but the strategic turn based combat is seriously broken.
The game has 8 difficulty levels and on the easiest it's too easy, but if you're one notch above the lowest setting you're REGULARLY going to lose a lot of fights that you really shouldn't be losing, and by that I mean you'll have veteran 3/2 units losing to regular 1/1 and 1/2 units, it completely kills the fun factor of the game for me when my superior units keep losing to inferior ones.

review: I grew up playing Civ III so it's nostalgic for me. Has all the core mechanics of later civ games, but it's boiled down to just enough that you can jump right in. I like that you can stack combat units (not a feature in Civ 5) which felt more realistic than battles spread across a dozen tiles, but the stacks are easier to manage than the 'stack of doom' mechanic present in Civ 4. Very fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158630769', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1584304823}
review:
Pfff.... El juego es bueno. Tiene detalles muy interesantes y siendo uno de los primeros de la saga hay que tener en cuenta el legado que ha dejado pero la realidad es que se hace increiblemente tedioso. El hierro y los caballos (los dos principales recursos que debes encontrar si quieres hacer algo en early) son tan jodidamente escasos que puedes llegar a recorrer el mapa de una punta a otra sin encontrar ni uno ni el otro. Esto provoca un problema serio dado que no puedes enfrentarte en combate a civilizaciones que si tienen estos materiales, ademas de dejarte tecnologicamente estancado y el hecho de encontrarlos o no es pura suerte, yo por ejemplo he empezado 6 partidas seguidas tratando de encontrarlos al principio y no ha habido forma. 

Añadido a esto no hay forma de customizar la partida para hacer estos recursos tan basicos mas comunes, sinceramente me parece un fallo de diseño serio dado que te da otras mil opciones para personalizar el mapa que son completamente inutiles.

3/10  Es triste que por un detalle tan simple el juego se vuelva tan aburrido.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 1294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1294, 'last_played': 1583583390}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#267 out of 612)... it's time for Sid Meier's Civilization III.

Arguably the most important, if not the best, entry in the venerable Civilization series. While today Civilization 5 may be the definitive version of Civilization, Civilization III used to claim that spot, and is still very much worth revisiting today--especially if you're looking to play Civ on an older PC that might groan and creak under the strain of modern games.

Civilization III is incredibly polished and boasts an enormous amount of content, especially with regard to mods. The 2D visuals still look gorgeous today and a modern CPU can bruteforce its way through that usual murderer of Civilization playthroughs, the late-game slog. Be warned, however, that Civilization III is a very old game, and it shows its age. Mostly this manifests in the UI, which is considerably less intuitive and clear than we're accustomed to these days--and, perhaps most problematically for new players, there aren't any tooltips. If you've never played a Civilization game before, you're in for a steep learning curve. And if it's been a while since you've played Civilization III and you're looking to revisit an old favorite, well, unless your memory is much greater than mine, odds are you'll have a fair bit of a learning curve to muddle through as well. Who'd've thought the most important innovation in the 4x genre over the last 20 years would be something as simple as tooltips?

Well, anyway. It's Civilization III: one of the finest turn-based strategy games ever produced. In many respects it falls short of its successors, most notably the wildly imaginative expansions of Civilization IV and the perfectly polished systems and mechanics of Civilization V, but it remains an excellent title nonetheless.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116287864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 35269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 221, 'playtime_at_review': 13051, 'last_played': 1710894989}
review: Civ III makes you feel like you're actually in control of everything. It's also pretty cool, how despite that, it also depicts a realism in the defenses of others, no matter how small they may seem. Projecting how our intellectual war, space race, politics of keeping people happy within our own country, are much more of a conflict for us all than an external attack. True freedom, comes when one realizes that God puts no burden on us at all. It's only when we strive after the devil's world of greed, riches and badness, that the act of doing things we know are wrong are what put boundaries and chains on ourselves. God never limits us. You can do anything and all things good until you're blue in the face and pass out, and he's cool with that. But when you start doing bad things, the limitations come because it's not acceptable by the others around you, even others doing bad themselves. They don't like an unfair advantage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322515962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1844, 'last_played': 1624766362}
review: 如果有空闲时间的话    我非常推荐孩子玩这部游戏    主要就是里面涉及的各个种族   文化   奇观   城市的名字   外交的诡诈   商业的交易利弊关系    军队作为保障发展先后的问题    都需要一个人全面考虑    文明3    我已经玩了快20年了    当时我高中会考   当然也包括初中历史地理    没怎么学   就很容易考到最高的A级别    跟这个兴趣开发有关系    STEAM没有汉化     可以在自家3DM上找一找   强烈建议   官方重做一下地理环境     这一部绝对是最正常    最有意思的一部     另外吐槽一下像宙斯神像这种奇观   造了在城市里面也看不见     BUG？

author: {'steamid': '76561198936698845', 'num_games_owned': 24, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1582404139}
review:
The game is very clunky and the 'tutorial' mode offers no help with most of the issues. The biggest problem i had were with an apparent unbalanced scaling in how the AI nations behave, even in the easiest mode. THey expand continuously with apparently no concern for territory or money. This further creates a problem when they settle cities between yours and comlain every time your troops move through the region as they HAVE TO DO to go anywhere. 
Another issue is lack of clarity in how to or ability to deal with internal issues such as civil disorder. The corruption mehanic doent mke a lot of sense and there doesnt see to be anything the player can do to minimize it except literally build all your cities directly around your capitol, which while strategically may be ideal, seriously limits expansion prospects. Building roads is a suggested mitigation move, but it doesn't appear to actually do anything. it's also apparently impossible to actually maintain or affect where the money in your cities goes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100098549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3138, 'last_played': 1514640413}
review: A classic 4X game and a good product of its time. A bit outdated in graphics (though it still holds some charm!) and mechanics, but it's fun nonetheless. I would recommend it to fans of the Civilization franchise that wish to play an older game for whatever reason; it is definitely outclassed by its more modern sequels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127777663', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 100068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93121, 'last_played': 1674533112}
review: Greatest game ever.  Only 2 real issues that I have ever had problems with.  #1  Automated exploring is idiotic.  If you send two units out they always end up in the same area or retrace their steps for 10 turns to make it back to one overlooked square they missed earlier instead of continuing into unexplored areas.  #2  Sometimes battles against vastly inferior opponents ends up with them winning.  E.G.  4 units with attacks of 4 go against 3 units with defenses of 2.  The attackers are wiped out.  This consistently happens in Civ, where a vastly superior unit is defeated by a vastly inferior unit.  I just sing a diddy, "the impossible last stand, the spearman defends his land, against waves of swordsmen, it's the impossible last stand."  That's how often it happens, I made up a silly song.  Other than that, I've never played a game more in my life.

review: A classic - frustrating with the stupid AI, but enjoyable all the same. This comes from the start of the great franchise but somehow I keep coming back to this one, don't know why, it blends simplicity with fiendish complexity, I just loving finding out what sort of world the AI has made for me and my "people".

author: {'steamid': '76561198030955137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 199846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1590, 'playtime_at_review': 79284, 'last_played': 1710882385}
review:
This is an old school game written by one of the greats in the industry. It is heavy on strategy and number crunching capability. Less so on cute graphics. I tried the newer versions, but find they are stuffed with flashy high res graphics and animation, but actual game decisions and movements are very slow. 
Not for everyone, you should probably skip this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198425637852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 22320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1707693202}
review: Amazing Game! Best instillation in the franchise if you ask me! A fun RTS with many factions to pick from (I believe it's 31 to be exact)! Enjoying making my own maps and playing them. Accessing the editor is a little difficult at first because you don't open it through steam, but your file browser instead (There's forums for this if you're interested)! The game is built upon many aspects which gives it a unique play-stile where you get to manage your Economy, Culture, Military, Diplomacy, Science/Technological advancements throughout the Bronze age, Midieval era, the Middle ages, The industrial era, the Modern era and beyond! Definately a 5/5 for me! And it certainly takes it's place among my top 10 game franchises along with The total war series, Halo, Call of Duty, Fortnite, Tomb Raider, Uncharted, Resistance, Men of War, Command and Conquer, and Star wars Battlefront! Definitely worth the money! Enjoy folks! Oh, and also, the difficulty varies significantly with the eight or so different levels, so for those of you who love a challenge, this game's for you! For those who want to easily walk all over their opressors, this game's for you! And for all of those who love their games so hard that all they ever do is get their butt's whooped, This games for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198089472337', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1579142090}
review:
I wish I could recommend this game, but it has changed so much. I played the "normal" edition (less playable civilizations, simpler mechanics, etc) of Civ 3 for 100s of hours as a kid. This game was a big part of my childhood. But, I do believe there must have been some digression and tweaking done for the "complete" version. 

The game seems very unbalanced, there are some bugs when talking to other civilizations (Windows 10), and it was just genuinely harder than it used to be even on the easiest settings. The combat mechanics bring a lot of unbalanced struggle to the game, unfortunately. It is frustrating to lose a majority of your army to one or two enemy units. It didn't used to be like that.

review: This is still my favourite iteration of the Civilization franchise. It may not be as deep or flashy, but it has the aesthetics and epic atmosphere that I expect from a game of Civ. This Complete edition offers the most broad and fine-tuned edition of the game yet, and all passionate Civ fans owe it to themselves to give it a try.

review:
You Are Free to do what you want, where to build cities and so on
It is game from years when still there was respect for you as a person
You can play offline comfortably and you can play it week by week an hour per day
Online gaming is tough, cause you will meet like really experienced killers, masters of the game
First you need practice offline
It is step by step game like chess and it is cool
If you need something to relax after hard working or switch your head off from daily routine maybe it  is your way to do it

author: {'steamid': '76561197966014743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 48970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23588, 'last_played': 1701719336}
review:
Nach dem fulminanten ersten Teil der Rundenstrategieserie wurden im zweiten Teil die Qualitäten verbessert. Civilization III übertraf beide Teile durch die komplexere Diplomatie, liebevolle Grafiken und unzähligen neuen Optionen. Gerade die Erweiterung Conquests ist sehr gut gelungen, durch Kampagnen mit veränderten Spieloptionen, mit dem Fokus auf historischen Schlachten.
Auch heute - trotz drei weiterer Nachfolger - ist das Spiel immer noch ein Blick wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017792109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 225604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92450, 'last_played': 1704762975}
review:
This is a fantastic strategy game against "fair" AI player, until one of the civilizations suddenly acquires "cheat" level power and wealth. All countries were similar within reason. I just quit after a long "building process". One of the opposing countries suddenly advanced to high level mechanics. My horse cavalry was being attacked by aircraft, automatic weapons, and tanks. No fun. Very disappointing. Happens every time. Too bad, otherwise a great game with simple, responsive graphics. Later versions have "silly", cartoon-like  graphics and are not as responsive.

Tried once again. After advancing into the industrial age, my AI opponents suddenly gained huge advances. Once again, found my horse cavalry defending against mechanized armored units and aircraft. When I viewed their technology, a few rounds earlier, we were almost even in terms of advancement. Very frustrating to work so hard, only to have the AI civs cheat! May try the cartoon style later versions, but they are not as nimble as the older version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163737903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 102370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22932, 'last_played': 1701053670}
review: You can change the variables of the size of world, the climate, the hostility level of barbarians, and so much more.  Lots of strategic turn-based fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198820886609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1605999135}
review: This is NOT the Civ III that you used to play. The "complete" version turned the game even on the easiest setting into an impossible mess. As soon as any AI meets you, they instantly hate you and turn on you, regardless of the settings, even least aggressive. No such thing as "friendly" or "polite". It's just "OH! It's YOU!!!", then they usually demand something outrageous, and then they declare war and attack you with swarms of units there is no way that they actually built. You can have units that are 3 generations ahead of another player, and it will take 3 of them to make even a dent in 1 of theirs. 1 of their warriors will take out several of your medieval infantry without a problem. Doesn't matter what land your tile is, you get no defensive bonuses. You could have any fortified units on top of a mountain, and a warrior will happily tear through you like you're made out of tissue paper. Not to mention they can build whatever they want regardless of resources, and they don't have to fund or pay for units, so 1 city can create dozens of units every couple of turns. No matter how good you are, you can't withstand a swarm of several dozen units that are overpowered, and have the strength of industrial era weapons, attacking your cities each and every turn from the very beginning. And that's on the easiest settings!!! I'm all for a challenge, but at least make it a realistic challenge that is even remotely in the vicinity of fair. Might also be nice to be able to focus on other areas of the game like culture or science, as opposed to the game just always being one big, neverending melee set to the tune of Slayer's War Ensemble. So go find a disc version that's not this Complete one. The "Complete" means "Complete Garbage".

author: {'steamid': '76561198444031442', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1763, 'last_played': 1649787896}

author: {'steamid': '76561198202260368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1702585299}
review:
Timeless and perfect.

Much different from the newer Civs in my opinion. Civ 3 feels like an epic board game: ridiculous numbers of units (on the same tile!) and sprawling empires with dozens of cities. A great option for micro-managers, but you don't have to make it complicated to have fun. The soundtrack is phenomenal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198341572113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1579368807}
review:
...Well, on a sale of 1 to 10 in difficulty, I place it roundabouts a 8.5, because, and I actually have played longer on another account, in the 3 years I've been attempting to beat "Easy" mode, I have done so exactly 0 times. Maybe Im a terrible player, but, warning issued. Prepare to be stymied.
 One complaint I might have is the balancing mechanics between AI and the Player. Unless you go aggressive expansionist, or seclude yourself from the rest of the AI, you will be dominated swiftly. Is there really any chance of success if you spawn next to an AI? No. They will get out 12 Archers before you can build One measly Warrior.
 Otherwise, it's a great game, but If you'd want more winnability, try out CIV5. If you're a "do or die" Masochist who wants to prove their strategic genius, may the odds be ever in your Favor. This is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115243927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5915, 'last_played': 1591027590}
review:
Definitely viable in 2019, at least for a person who never played the newer ones. Combat can be extremely annoying in that its outcome is sometimes way more random than it should be, but apart from that Civ 3 is very entertaining. The game is relatively simple after you understand all the little details, but it offers great strategic depth with how everything is interconnected.

Do not approach if you don't have much free time! A single game can take twenty-something hours if you're the type who plays slow, analyzes, and wants  to micro-manage a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025491854', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1135, 'last_played': 1649564716}
review: The AI is a cheating bastard, Spearmen can beat tanks in battles, Hannibal has muttonchops in the modern era, the late game music has a serious 90s vibe. This game is my childhood; even all these years later it's still one of the best, if not the very best 4X game ever made in my opinion. Sure, it lacks some polish (no put those hussars away, I said *polish* not *Polish*), but it is still immensely playable even 20 years later.

review:
Pas cher mais fait passer, pendant le temps de jeux, la version windows installée en version xp/vista (tu quitte le jeux = tu reviens en version installée).
Il faut passer la cinématique le plus vite possible sinon ça crash.
Les scénarios ne permettent pas d'avoir toutes les recherches mais le mode custom si (normal).
Bonne initiation à la série Civilization.
Enjoy !

author: {'steamid': '76561197982231182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 1748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1748, 'last_played': 1551470876}
review:
Awesome Civ game from before they got too mixed up with stupid add-ons: no religion, no princesses etc. Just the core aspects to make a really fantastic game...

Also, Play The World is incredible: a massive map with a huge number of nations, all modded to be slightly different. When the game first came out it would take my old computer about 20 minutes to work through the computer's moves but on a modern computer it plays like a dream.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014621350', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 2330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 737, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1709742397}
review:
Самая первая Цивилизация из мной игранных входит в троку первых игр на ПК. Если бы Стим появился ещё в 2001 году в том виде, что сейчас, то эта игра была бы самая долгоиграемая по часам из всех.
Даже сейчас по внешнему виду можно сказать, что не сильно устарела, да и в плане реализации считаю её самой лучшей из всех, хоть и дополнений к ней выходило очень мало (хотя возможно это из-за ностальгии, так то пятая часть куда разнообразнее). Изобилует некоторыми багами, но играть сейчас в неё одно удовольствие лишь тем, кто с неё возможно и начинал.
Саундтрек, знакомые сердцу звуки сражений и перемещений юнитов, отличительные разные юниты для каждой из страны давали некое разнообразие и погружение в геймплей, хоть и не сильное. Построить в одном городе все чудеса было одно удовольствие и наблюдать за развитием города при его полном просмотре. Накидать современных танков в катер и увидеть, как его потопила простая галера было болью, а уничтожить вражеского стрелка простым копейщиком считалось большим успехом.
Дополнительно в игре присутствует множество дополнительных карт – сценариев, со своими интересными правилами.
Почему то нет возможности использовать Стим-оверлей и делать скриншоты, хотя они доступны от других пользователей в достатке.
В общем, одна из бессмертных классических игр.
10 сбитых бомбардировщиков в средневековом городе из 10’ти.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262313033', 'num_games_owned': 46, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 32726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 672, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1710541770}
review:
CI gioco da 20 anni e non smette mai di piacermi. A differenza degli altri CIV che magari hanno una grafica molto buona e molte piu tecnologie e unità. Mi rendo conto che CIV 3 è quello fatto meglio. Perchè permette battaglie assurde e da veramente l'idea del numero e della sostanza di un vero esercito. Poi ce maggior controllo della mappa e si riescono a capire piu facilmente certi concetti.
La pecca è la ripetività delle partite, a volte manca un po di novità. Con le mod ci si diverte ma sono difficili da installare. Ho sempre sperato che Sid Meiers riuscisse a rifare un CIV 3 HD con piu potenzialità, perchè la base era veramente buona ma temo non succederà mai. Ormai da CIV 4 in poi i modelli di gioco sono cambiati radicalmente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067201396', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1576416724}
review:
The gold standard for Civilization games. I've put in many hours in the newer versions and this one (Civ3) still delivers. Graphics are dated, but it runs on everything including the newest Windows 10. I lost my old cd, so it is nice that you can pick it up on steam.

First ten minutes:
- lost my worker to a barbarian.
- Incas wanted a tech. I refused.
- Incas declared war.
- Incas warrior kills four spearmen.
- Civil unrest erupts in Rome.

Oh baby, we are back.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198272085658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 14967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9952, 'last_played': 1704690234}
review: Civ III is simple, some of the game mechanics are broken, but for a 2001 grand strategy game, this is right up there with the best. Some incredible mods go a long way -- Worldwide (for general gameplay balance) and MEM II (for an amazing Crusader Kings style game) are my favorites. I've probably logged well over 1,000 hours back when I owned the disk version. Love it quite a bit.

review: An excellent turn-based city building game that is nearly always fun, outside of standard maps such as Earth there is a random seed. Be warned though there are some issues with some of the cinematics that can lock up the game. Personally I have had issue with the space-race victory and need to skip the victory summaries or risk the game freezing, there may be some fixes just haven't spent the time to check. Also there is an excellent selection of mods for the game ranging from textures to maps and scenarios although they must be sought out on  other sites. Now if only there was Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri on Steam always wanted to play it atleast once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043023267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1604012203}
review:
Desde que compré Sid Meier's Civilization II en una tienda de segunda mano soy un fan de la saga Civilization y me he propuesto jugar todos los juegos de la saga poco a poco. Habiendo jugado a Civ II, Civ 1, Civilization Revolution y Alpha Centauri, decidí adquirir el Civ III cuando salió de oferta en Steam. No me arrepiento de la compra, pero tengo claro que otros juegos de la saga me gustan más. Para mí (de mejor a peor de entre los que he jugado): Alpha Centauri>Civ II>>>Civ Revolution>Civ III>Civ. Tengo entendido que el Civ IV es muy bueno, y será el próximo que compre.

PUNTOS FUERTES:
-Gráficos. Los gráficos 2D han envejecido muy bien, y son mucho mejores que los del Civ II y Civ I.
-Música. Tiene la mejor música de los juegos de la saga que he jugado. La música del Civ II es muy básica y se hace cansina, mientras que la del Civ III es más elaborada y resulta mucho más agradable.
-Fronteras. En Civ II es muy molesto cuando el enemigo construye sus ciudades en tu territorio. Esto fue corregido en Civ III con la adición de fronteras para delimitar los territorios controlados por cada civilización (aunque esto ya existía en Alpha Centauri).
-Diferenciación de civilizaciones. En Civ II todas las civilizaciones tenían las mismas características y se jugaban igual, pero en Civ III cada civilización tiene sus ventajas y desventajas (otra vez, Alpha Centauri lo hizo primero).
-Diplomacia mejorada. El trato con otras civilizaciones en juegos anteriores era muy básico. En Civ III hay muchas más opciones (derechos de paso, embargos, protección mutua, ...). No obstante, los líderes no parecen tener tener personalidad propia como tenían en Alpha Centauri.
-Interfaz poco intrusiva. La interfaz ocupa poco espacio en la pantalla, tiene todas las acciones a mano y muestra toda la información necesaria. Es mejor que la de Civ II y, sobre todo, que la de Alpha Centauri.

PUNTOS DÉBILES:
-Combate. Al igual que en Civ 1, una unidad tecnológicamente atrasada puede vencer a una mucho más avanzada (no es lo más probable, pero aún así ocurre bastantes veces durante una partida y resulta muy molesto). En ese sentido, Civ II era mucho mejor.
-Ritmo lento. El juego parece tener un ritmo más lento que los juegos anteriores, aunque la cosa mejora mucho si se desactivan las animaciones.
-Mejoras del terreno. No hacía falta tener tantas opciones como en Alpha Centauri, pero es que Civ III tiene menos mejoras del terreno disponibles que Civ II (donde después del regadío se podían hacer granjas, además de tener las tecnologías "supermercado" y "autopistas" para mejorar la productividad). La consecuencia es que cuando la partida está muy avanzada, hay poco que hacer en el terreno con los trabajadores.

CONCLUSIÓN:
Para jugar un Civilization en 2D, Civ II y (sobre todo) Alpha Centauri son mucho mejores opciones que Civ III. Si quieres un Civilization más complejo que Civ II, quizá Civ IV sea mejor opción, salvo que Civ III esté mucho más barato.

author: {'steamid': '76561198435484650', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4460, 'last_played': 1629055861}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025260266', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 8738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3142, 'last_played': 1672257355}
review:
Recensione dell'installazione con Steam:
Il gioco presenta GRAVI PROBLEMI DI RISOLUZIONE, di malfunzionamenti e di crash improvvisi. Assolutamente urgente da sistemare. Problemi da Windows 10 in poi, problemi con schermi di risoluzione 2k o 4k.
RECENSIONE NEGATIVA PER QUESTO MOTIVO.

Recensione del gioco
Assolutamente il miglior civilization di Sid Meier. Nonostante la sua età rimane un pilastro della serie. Gli altri successivi hanno perso molto rispetto a questo, sia in dinamica che in funzionalità. 
Nonostante la sua miglior semplicità, rimane un gioco godibile e longevo. Sicuramente migliore di tutti gli altri civ successivi, che io tra l'altro posseggo ma che non mi hanno mai entusiasmato. La differenza più marcata è che nei civ successivi hanno ampliato tutti i menù e le opzioni di scelta di ogni cosa (militare, economica, politica etc.) ma il tutto è risultato un minestrone inutile. C'è davvero bisogno di avere ulteriori effetti e opzioni  premendo dei pulsanti in più per avere un'influenza politica sugli altri leader? Voglio dire, in civ 3 con la cultura puoi mostrare la tua magnificenza agli altri e quindi avrai rispetto, sugli altri civ successivi questa è diventata invece un'operazione molto più complessa dove richiede costantemente l'attenzione del giocatore per riuscire ad avere successo. Sommate poi tutte le altre cose che vanno sempre seguite in civ 5 e 6 in particolare, la finirete a non riuscire a ottenere granchè. 

Critiche:
Per l'epoca ci sono pochissime critiche. 
Sarebbe bello se riesumassero questo gioco rendendolo moderno senza l'uso di dlc o altri pagamenti aggiuntivi.


Il gioco:
Il sistema si basa sulla fondazione di più città possibile sul continente per poi decidere, a seconda del popolo preso, se condurre una partita culturale, scientifica o militarista. 
Prima di avviare una partita, che vi consiglio di mettere tutte le impostazioni su casuale, assicuratevi di avere su "Limiti gioco" le regole che vanno bene per voi. Altro consiglio è di mettere "Regicidio" attivo. 
La CPU è molto audace e intelligente in guerra, assicuratevi di entrare in guerra solo se strettamente necessario e ponderate questa mossa molti turni prima. Manovrare un impero su Civ 3 può essere un'operazione complessa che richiede molti turni. 
E' importante che controlliate tutto e che il vostro esercito sia ben equipaggiato e forte. Per quanto riguarda il sistema di combattimento ho notato che bisogna fare estrema attenzione a quali truppe far attaccare, perchè rischierete spesso di perdere la guerra se sbagliate poche battaglie. 
Comunque, altri modi di vincere sono di costruire una fiorente civiltà scientifica con appunto le tribù votate alla scienza, inoltre il gioco da la possibilità di concentrare gli sforzi solo sulla scienza senza toccare gli edifici che danno felicità e cultura.
Ci sono poi i forti, utili per bloccare l'ingresso a eserciti indesiderati.
Questo e molto altro regalano le partite su Civ 3. Assolutamente il migliore, ma da capire.
A riguardo infatti potrete trovare in internet il manuale in italiano Civilization 3 Più Civ che mai per imparare a fondo il gioco.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967989833', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1575201963}
review: Gut, das Spiel ist jetzt schon ein bisschen in die Jahre gekommen, aber wer zum Beispiel ein PC der älter ist hat, hat bestimmt grosses Gefallen an diesem Meisterwerk der Spiele - Branche von Sid Meier. Ich habe schon in den 90'er Jahren Civilization gespielt und kann es nur jedem empfehlen. Dieses Spiel hat nicht die beste Grafik von heute und die neueren Versionen  (VI - 6 ist denk ich verfügbar) sind bestimmt aber empfehlenswert für heutige Spieler mit modernem System und den nötigen Ressourcen (CPU, Grafischer Durchsatz etc.). Da kann sich manch ein Entwickler von Computerspielen wirklich was abgucken, den Civilization (hier III) ist auf jeden Fall die Norm. Hoffe, meine Bewertung hat euch geholfen!
