author: {'steamid': '76561198049265487', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 27412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 71, 'playtime_at_review': 25250, 'last_played': 1710697162}
review:
This will be an update to my original comprehensive review of this game, as before I will split the review for newcomers to Civilization III (Civ 3) and those that have played both played modern civilization games to this point. Hopefully this serves as a clearer introduction and review of this game I have loved since my teenage years. 

For Newcomers, I would not recommend this as a first civilization game to get into for the following reasons that should be noted. This game has some complications for some to play the game, most can be resolved with a bit of file management, but most remaining and introduced bugs (mainly sound bugs) must be self-remediated and through self-experience some can be painful, i.e.  “The Diplomacy Menu Sound bug”.  However, if you have the know-how or willingness to learn, there are helpful guides and threads on both Steam and CivFanatics to resolve these issues. 

Additionally, for newcomers to both Civ 3 and 4X games in general, Civ 3 is rudimentary in its design, but at its time served as a novel concept. Civilization III was the first Sid Meier’s Civilization game published outside their MicroProse days. It brought graphic and visual design innovations including more emphasis on their 2.5D graphic sprites while keeping with an isometric layout. That being said, the graphics in vanilla setups have not “Stood the Test of Time”, but as with many things, this game maintains a faithful modding community with thousands of available content additions provided freely to the community. 

For all its faults, it does keep to its promise, it is a fully complete game, which in this modern gaming scene, a complete game can be a refreshing breath. And it is a game that you can get into fast, with a descriptive Civlopedia that can teach you core fundamentals of the game, however no tutorial exists for this game. It can be a game that can be easy to learn for strategy game-lovers but will provide a challenge all the way into the higher difficulties, though at the expense of AI just being given powerful bonuses as the difference between difficulties. 

Now onto the review for those coming from other Civ games and other 4X games. Should you get this game, keep the following things in mind. The games UI can be un-intuitive for some, most of it is done through right-clicking on cities and units to interact with their drop-down menus that pop up. However, there are plenty of hot-keys available for units’ available actions. This game solely favors “Wide-Builds” and so you will always be incentivized to continue expanding and producing vast quantities of units, which can be a drag in the endgame when micro-management becomes exhausting at times. 

Game speed is something that can’t be altered within the game and instead is dependent on scenario-based games. And once the basics are learned and you are proficient with the game, a single player game can be played out completely within a few hours. It really has served as one of those plug-n-play strategy games, and for a 4x game, is still exemplary in that role. 

I mentioned micro-management, this game is pretty neat in the sense it feels extremely city based. Happiness and discontent are based on population solely and is dealt with on a per-city basis. Additionally, science and gold production are one and the same, with a national budget slider controlling your science and treasury growth, as well as, money spent on your citizen’s happiness, while culture is often based on the physical development of your cities. With such a simple rule-set, games are straightforward and feel extremely grounded. 

The last thing I want to high-light but was mentioned repeatedly already. This game has an extensive modding community, and while it may not be as active, it maintains a large archive of files, use at your own risk, but many overhauls and noteworthy mods have installation guides and more. Finally, this game has many files found in the file browser, just right-click the game on steam to access those files. Play the World and the original Civ 3 (no-dlc) can be found, each of these with their scenario and rules editors. Modding is extremely easy for this game (barring overhauls) and the guides are really amazing, big shout-out. I have made my own unpublished modifications myself, with little background in modding previously. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

So is this review a little too wordy and you need that zoomer brevity, no worries I break down the pros and cons here as bullets.
Pros:
-	The game is straightforward, with player guides and an in-game encyclopedia of rules, concepts clear and concise. 
-	A Potato could run this game, but if you take the modding route, RAM and CPU power will be your friend. Late Game Lag is also a phenomenon found in this game. 
-	Combat Units are very clear, and fill classic niches in games, Offensive, Defensive, Maneuver, Ranged and Siege Units, with Aerial Units being added much later with rules similar to Siege Units. 
-	Science, Culture and Gold Production is straightforward with majority city-based empire management. 
-	Wonderful CivFanatics Community and Modding Community, as well as Steam Guides

Cons:
-	Combat is outdated, with most Units fighting until their own destruction or the enemy unit’s. Additionally, based on simple dice-like combat, so expect the classic Civ 4 Catapult kills Tank scenario on rare occasion. 
-	Diplomacy is easily exploitable, especially for the AI to cheat together and gang up on you, namely through alliances and Tech Trading. 
-	Difficulty scales based on AI cheats and bonuses.
-	It’s an old game, bugs arise, and the graphics aren’t the prettiest. Additionally, it used to be very difficult to get the game to start on Windows 7 and 8.1. Issues minimized with Windows 10, but no experience with Windows 11 installation of the game.
Note: Many of the Cons can be minimized by altering values in scenario/rules editors available in the game files or larger community. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
This final section is for Multiplayer and personal history with the game. Multiplayer is not something I am familiar with any expertise. To my understanding, it exists and still has old veterans of the game. Multiplayer guides and strategies exist and are probably your best bet to getting into Multiplayer. I believe, Steam allows you to play MP directly nowadays, or it’s hosted through GameRanger (though this was back in 2018/2019). I have been playing this game since 2010 or so (on physical copies of the game), it became my introduction to the Civilization series and separately 4X games outside the old retro Warlords III/IV games. Now in my late twenties, this game still serves as one of my fonder memories and game I find myself returning to. Whether you get it on sale or you pay its already cheap price, it's completely worth it in my eyes! 

Feel free to comment on this review if you have other questions about this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119824744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1448157449}
review:
General - 8.0
Sid Meier's Civilization is one of the greatest game franchises ever, it's a landmark for every turn-based strategy game. The name itself tells what the game is about, you pick one civilization, select a location to start, select CPU controlled civilizations and settings for that specific map. Your job is to make your civilization meet any of the victory conditions, which can be through science, military, culture, diplomacy, points, etc. The first game of the series I played was Civ II, back in 2001, which instantly made me a fan since then. However I skipped Civ III at its time, and that is what made me buy it many years later. I paid around 1USD for the game just to see what I missed, and unfortunately, not much. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game, but if you played Civ IV, in my opinion, there is nothing in Civ III that will be better than in the later game. It's only worth playing for saudosism purposes. It's heavily outdated.

Content - 8.5
Steam version is a complete version, which includes both expansion packs released. You have a vast number of civilizations to pick and you can adjust some major settings for a location, like temperature, umidity, geological era, water level, etc. You can also chose the victory conditions for a game, which you can fit into your play style, along with difficulty level. The Civilopedia is a tool of great educational value, it contains real data about the civilizations, technologies, unities and almost everything you can find in the game. There is a highest scores table too, but I believe it only displays single-player scores. I don't know if steam is providing some sort of multiplayer support at this time.

Gameplay - 4.0
Like most Civ games, you start with a settler, a worker and/or a warrior in most cases, from this you have to build your city and administer it's growth with the resources gathered around it, which can be selected in the city radius. Each unity you create in a city has a better use, and through the years (turns), as long as your cities and citizens are productive you'll eventually discover technologies which improve your unities and your cities buildings. You can focus your whole civilization in a few aspects or diversify your knowledge. Every civilization on the map have it's own personality and choices, from warmongers to pacifists. What you have to do is to secure your civilization a place in history. But why I give 4.0? It won't help you get started at all. I'm not asking for a strategy guide, I just wanna learn the basics of the game, what's unique to it, what options I have and what they do. I couldn't find a tutorial or at least a checkbox to display tooltips, even the options in the main menu don't have a basic description. It's one of the less intuitive game I've ever seen, unlike it's predecessor ou sucessor. Of course after sometime you'll start to get used to the controls, but they still feel weird. The UI is not friendly even for games older than it is, Age of Empires II is older and has a much more friendly interface and controls.

Graphics - 2.5
The game looks very bad even for its generation, Age of Wonders and Medieval Total War had much better visual quality. Civilization III looks so bad that if affects gameplay, you need to often take a closer look to identify some terrains and unities. There are no options for good graphic enhancements, you can not adjust resolution, it's based on desktop resolution, and even tweaking can't get satisfactory results. I know it's an old game, but the ones I cited are old too and are from the same genre. At least the game showed an improvement compared to the previous title, texture quality is better and there are movement animations for the unities.

Overall - 5.8

Current specs
Intel Core I7-4770K at 4.2ghz
Nvidia PNY GTX 770 2gb at 1201mhz
Kingston HyperX DDR3 8gb at 1600mhz (x2)
HP 1TB SATA III 7200rpm
Windows 7 Premium SP1
Sony Bravia KDL-42W655A at 1080p

author: {'steamid': '76561198108664657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1005, 'last_played': 1403404913}
review:
Civilization es un clásico, y el civilization III fue para mí uno de los mejores. Es incalculable la cantidad de horas que le hemos dedicado en su momento con mi hermano. Claramente los gráficos han quedado un poco obsoletos, pero están suficientemente pulidos como para seguir siendo jugable e interesante.

Cuando uno lo compara con versiones más actuales del juego puede extrañar ciertas mecánicas del juego (como por ejemplo la religión), pero volver a jugar unas partidas, es genial.

Sin duda es una ventaja sus bajos requerimientos, que permiten jugarlo en cualquier computadora.

Lo recomiendo para los fanáticos de la saga y para aquellos que les gusta la estrategia por turnos, no obstante, por la antigüedad del mismo, es mejor esperar hasta que este en oferta (no vale la pena pagar el precio completo).

review: Un classico. Magari povero di grafica ma uno dei giochi di strategia più completi di tutti i tempi. Ogni partita sarà diversa grazie al fattore delle mappe casuali. Ore di divertimento assicurate per gli amanti del genere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141912441', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2651, 'last_played': 1630228480}
review:
Exquisite game, and for me will always be the best of the series.
Back when empires were mighty and wars brutal.
The final score represents the lifetime of a nation, not a solitary point in time, and all aspects of that nation, whether it be an inspiring culture, a veteran military or arcane technology, contribute to that end.

History, truly, is made here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014913462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 252, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1419386962}
review:
At the price of $1.50, this is an absolute buy for any CIv fan, and a strong recommend for turn-based strategy fans.

The proper ranking of Civ titles is 4, 2, 1, 3, 5.

Civ 3 is worth playing just to appreciate the other games in the series, but it stands up on its own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106320166', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 10254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4721, 'last_played': 1551302840}
review: My first real video game, being brought up on all those educational "Leap Start" games from way back when, never getting any real games until this one, I loved it from the very first turn. This game is quite possibly one of the best strategy games ever created. It has perfect balance, great gameplay, its very hard to win but you still have fun with it because of the flawless design, the units are all unique and each one is cool in its own way, from the days of stones and swords to fighter jets and skyscrapers, you'll have fun forever. I still remember my first victory, so many years later. I remember just how proud I was, looking at all those beat up other leaders, mine staring at them with a shit faced grin of complete pompus superiority, I felt like I was god. When you actually win, which I've only done once, it feels SO FUCKING GOOD. You feel like you just took over the world in real life, especially with all the other leaders sitting there, cowering before your might! Its just awesome, please please buy this game, it is a classic that will never die, and everyone should get it, try it at least once. 9001/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198035390276', 'num_games_owned': 1010, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1418426647}
review: For a 13 year old game, I didn't find much replay value in it. I knew the rules, but found everything confusing and didn't find the control intuitive. I found everything really clumsy, which is great that they have come so far in a decade of making civ.

review:
Started a war with America. Took half their cities, destroyed most of their counterattacking troops, and decided I'd let them rebuild a little. Lincoln has the nerve to refuse a peace treaty unless I give him a city. So I wipe them out.

Next turn Ghandi declares war for no reason and destroys me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055188171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 26695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12359, 'last_played': 1689570593}
review: This is my favorite civ game by far. Civ V is great and all, but my biggest complaint about it is that you can only have like 20 nukes tops. Civ III lets you have as many as you so desire. Plus, you get ICBMs (as many as you want)! Civ V doesn't let you have ICBMs. However, in Civ III, I've got ICBMs in at least 20-30 cities, tactical nukes everywhere, subs (with tacticals) spread all across the map targeting all coastal and inner coastal cities. I can start WWIII any time I want, and I can be sure that I will have no shortage of nukes. Plus just painting some island in that b, e, a, utiful orange coat is just a pleasure. Get Civ III, don't waiste your money on Civ V.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056400256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1417384621}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021953887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 15096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15080, 'last_played': 1417726052}
review:
The game is old. The game is definetly recomented from my part.

I had to lower the screen resolution to avoid the 'tiny-litle-units' making my ayes go into pain. :-) But after all these years, I really enjoyed again the struggle to build a sivilization. There are newer versions of the same game nowdays. But I really believe that each of the Civilization games has its unique satisfaction to offer the strategy gamer, even if Civ IV is my prefered one.

I definetly recoment CIV III, especially moded with mods like "Rise And Rule", which add many new units, technologies etc.  The problem is, I can not clearly identify what is this 'different gameplay aspects' that kept me playing CIV II all these hous and not starting a CIV IV or CIV V campain... The differenses on units, wonders, railway inprovements etc, should not be enouph to get me playing a game as old as this one... On the other hand, I got myself missing the real-movie councelors of CIV-II, but I don't think I will play that old love again :-)

In any case. Considering the very low price that you can purchse this old game (Civilization III), especially in a bountle together with the newet versions, I definetly believe that any gamer that likes turn -base build-expand strategies should give it a try. Even for the shenarios of the 'complete' edition, a CIV-V fun could find in CIV-III a way to further expand his Civilization gamepleasure.

Have a good game everyone :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198093442102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1641417550}
review:
My friend introduced me to this game a long time ago, and I can't thank him enough! although I only have 2 hours on the steam version I happily spent hundreds ( at least) on the disc version he loaned me ( back when you could do that). 
   But anyway the reason your reading this is to learn weather or not this game is worth 5 bucks to buy. To answer that you must ask  yourself some questions.
1) do you like running your own country and mercilessly clicking other countries to death?
2) do you like exploring randomly generated worlds and clicking other countries to death?
3) do you like sending hundreds of units at enemys to make them fight to the death with other countries units by clicking?
4) do you enjoy classical music while clicking other countires to death?
5) do you care that there are 3 newer versions of the game?

If you answered yes to 1-4 and no to 5 BUY THE GAME
If you answered yes to 5 don't buy the game you nostalgia hater
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 3 of the first 4 questions then BUY THE GAME
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 2 of the first 4 questions you may want to consider waiting untill the game goes on sale
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 1 of the first 4 questions you may be looking at the wrong genre of games 
If you answered yest to 5 and no to the first 4 questions you ARE looking at the wrong genre of games


           - TheCanadianGamers Bman 
youtube.com/gamersofcanadaeh

author: {'steamid': '76561198012263700', 'num_games_owned': 1843, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 72905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 11859, 'last_played': 1710687005}
review:
Aunque para mucha gente es el peor de toda la saga, sigue siendo un gran juego, de hecho en su dia las criticas y puntuaciones no bajaban del 9.

Esta edicion desgracidamente no se encuentra en castellano, pero si que hay parches para cambiar dicho idioma, pero sin duda es todo un reto y tiene suficientes modos de juegos y mods para darle una vida infinita a este juego.

Basicamente este Civilization a diferencia de los anteriorees, se basa en una guerra por los recursos, dado que ellos son parte esencial para que tu civilizacion prospere.
Seguramente este juego se le considere el peor de la saga porque su manera de jugarlo es diferente o muy particular, pero una vez que lo conoces todo cambia.

Su modo multijugador online esta desactivado pero se puede jugar usando el tungle.

Comparado con los civilization mas modernos el juego se queda muy basico, pero eso no quita que la diversion esté asegurada, ya que tanto los rivales como tu mismo tendreis que luchar opr conseguir los recursos que te falten en tu civilizacion, tanto recursos militares como los lujos se haran indispensables para tu superviciencia.

El sistema de comercio y la diplomacia son parte fundamental, ya que como mencionara antes este juego gira al rededor de los recursos y no siepmre vas a ponder conseguirlos por la fuerza bruta.

Sin duda, para los amantes o los primerizos a este saga, el juego es ideal por su sencillez pero a la vez diversion, y solo los civilization posteriores han podido mejorar esta ultima.

mi nota es un 9/10 puesto que los posteriores juegos avanzan en la profundidad de este juego, si no tendria mas nota.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065228440', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1389, 'last_played': 1678414177}
review:
(ignore how long it says I've played; I got this game when it first came out for MacOS 9, and actually have a couple hundred hours sunk into it.)

This is the first Civ game I've ever played, and even after IV and V, it's still my favorite. There are a number of wonderful features that don't exist in the later games that I miss whenever I play them (palaces, roads across mountains, subtle references to Civ I bugs, actual in-depth physical documentation, etc). If you can stand the dated graphics and hard-to-set-up multiplayer, it's a 10/10. If you can't, it's a 10/10. Get this game. It's so good.

Rating: 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197991546193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3537, 'last_played': 1349161200}
review:
Vincent Price's most helpful reviews: Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete. 



Civilization III (or Civ III for short) is an argricultural war simulator, in which you build wheat, farm iron, and thresh people in a significant battle over land and cities.


Should you take too long to murder your foes, the game may decide to just let you win by saying you're so cultural that there's no way they can challenge you, and they automatically forefeit. Which is stupid, because a rich culture like that is not as likely to have the vast killing potential an uncultured brutish army nation would, but alas, not everything in life, or Civ, is logical.



10/10 with a friend, 6/10 by yourself, 2/10 when you spend hours trying to port forward to get it to work properly on multiplayer. Recommended for people who want their lives consumed entirely.

review: Civ3 is the best turn-based strategy game ever!  I originally bought this game when it was released in 2001 and I still play it in 2014.  I have played the sequels on both console and PC and they just don't have the depth or variety that this masterpiece offers.  The graphics are dated and 2D but that isn't really a bad thing because this game isn't about eye candy; it's about strategy.  This is definately a niche game and not going to be for everyone.  If you are a fan of turn based war games then you must give this a try.  The game starts slow but before you know it you are hooked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123412640', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 3302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3030, 'last_played': 1427237174}
review:
I'm new to Civilization games, and pretty new to turn based strategy games in general. However, I still enjoyed this game a lot. I'm awful, I lose pretty much every time, and I still have fun. This game has you building a civilization from scratch, trying to expand city by city to become the best civilization possible. At the start, you are given TONS of options. Picking what civilization you want to be to determine your starting perks, climate, weather, the age of the world, difficulty, barbarian options, AI agreesiveness, the ratio of water to land, and a whole bunch of customizable options for the rules and game limits. It's a lot to take in. And once you start, you can work towards whatever kind of civilization you want, from city structures to your units to your research... there's just a lot of options. But, what makes this game so cool is that there are not only a lot of options for starting and working your way through the game, there are also multiple ways to win the game as well. So you can replay lots of times trying to win in all the different ways available. If you are being severely outmatched in one area by another civilization, perhaps you can salvage your game by switching to another goal for victory. It's really very clever.

However, there ARE some issues with this game. It can be a lot to take in at first, especially since the tutorial mode is defaulted to off. I learned everything by winging it but not everyone will have the patience or luck for it. It'll take a while just to get used to what everything does and understanding how to navigate the game. Also, games tend to take hours to complete, which can also be rough if you don't have much time to play. It'll take A LOT of time to get acquainted with the game and to play in general so it's a HUGE time suck. I just wanted to get that point clearly across. Also... it's really hard... or I just suck... or both. Also... the online has been shut down, making this single player only. There ARE some complicated and iffy ways of working around it to play online, but they aren't worth the risk or hassle. The online is supposedly coming to Steamworks in the future, but until it comes, online is not a viable options, which is the whole reason I got it in the first place and that's diappointing, but it's my own fault for not looking into it more I guess.

Despite the issues, this game is VERY cheap. Five bucks for hours and hours of gameplay, including the two expansions to the game. Easily worth it, especially if you're looking to get into the Civilization series or TBS game in general. Just be aware of the time it will take to enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082784258', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1415111393}

author: {'steamid': '76561198092319413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1360, 'last_played': 1606111628}
review:
I’ll say this right off the bat, this game is flawed, VERY flawed.

But at the same time fun, VARY fun!

At the start, this game seemed perfect. Micromanaging is kind of my thing, but as the game progressed, is started to meet new civilisations, and all of them where dicks.

Especially the Inca’s, in two games I have met them and in both have tried to destroy me. Why, Is it because there militaristic? No. The Greeks tried to attack me and there also scientific, are the Byzantines just shit? It was Same problem with the English.

I’m not above a challenge, but when everyone else seems to be researching at a far greater pace than me, and as a result have fucking guns when I still have bows and arrows? That’s just shit. Also enemy troops must be covered in fucking kryptonite because it takes 3 to take down 1.

They must have been high when they programmed the AI.

In conclusion, good game. Up until you meet someone else

author: {'steamid': '76561198002608541', 'num_games_owned': 6122, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 6471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4188, 'last_played': 1544608400}
review:
I played this game way back in 2001. The problem I faced was at that time, I had an ancient Pentium II 300Mhz PC. So you can imagine how I felt as the game was nearly unplayable for me.

Coming into the present time of 2014, I was glad that Steam offered Civilization III for sale. I quickly bought it and played on my modern top of the line laptop. It sure brought back the memories. 

This game can be considered a classic in the turn based strategy (TBS) genre. TBS fans would most definitely love this game despite the dated graphics. I must also like to add that the Steam version of the game works perfectly fine in Windows 8.1. A TBS haven to say the least!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058724037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1344841200}
review: Civilization III I purchased to go back to the roots. I've played 2, 3, 4, and 5. It is definitely worth the purchase if you enjoy older games and or want to see what the game was before IV and V were released. The gameplay is a bit slow but the build up is immersive and can have you hooked for hours. It only shows my short time playing here on steam because I usually play my original version of the game. I must say this port lives up faithfully and I find nothing wrong with it. The battles are interesting and fun but diplomacy and management is where this game shines. If you are more into the combat I'd recommend Civilization IV or V. I recommend this to anyone who played it in the past and loves video game nostalgia. And there's no nostalgia that beats strategy game memories of the 90's.

review:
I'll admit the first time I played the game I thought it was a huge mistake buying it. After looking online for some sort of tutorial I found out that you could enable tutorial mode in options. It was uphill from there. I built towns, By towns I mean 2, I fought barbarians, I claimed my own mini island... From... Barbarians... , I mined mountains till they were hollow and my towns were rich with resource but... I noticed something was wrong... The population in each of my cities slowly decreased... So I started making a new file... And a new one. And a new one. And a new one.
Overall the games very fun and addicting :P
Bad review?

author: {'steamid': '76561197991307002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1232, 'last_played': 1409456161}
review:
I purchased this game in order to understand and have an enlightenment on the essential game mechanics of the Civilization game series. I am still not sure whether Civilization III was the right choice.

Here are a few topics that I wish to highlight:
- It is a low-paced, turn-based strategy game with a significant amount of historical content.
- There are a few variables in the game that the person should learn before starting to play. Luckily, steam provides us with a manual, so DO read it.
- For beginners, this game may become tough, even at the lowest difficulty setting. Even after learning the basics, there are many things one can do wrong.
- This game can take MANY hours of your time, and once your civilization has more than 10 settlements, it may take more than a minute to play each game turn. In addition, there may be dozens and dozens of turns before a victory condition is met.
- Although it DOES seem to work on my Windows 8.1 machine, there are a few frustrating issues, such as window switching not restoring the original resolution until the game is terminated. Also, the game may occasionally crash on some particular user, and so far it has always crashed after the end of a game. This means that the game could have had a better preparation for modern systems.

Therefore, it is both hard to recommend and unrecommend this game. Take this as a midline evaluation. If you have time to spare, go ahead and give it a try. Or who knows, the other games in the series might be more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033618053', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1413959461}
review:
I played this when I was like... really young I had no Idea what I was doing. I loved it.
I played this in school for social studies. I had the upper hand having played this before. I dominated everyone. I loved it.
I got it on steam. I played it for a day straight. I loved it still.

This game will last forever, however my love for this game is a mixture of honest nostalgia and fanstastic gameplay that does not ruin fond memories. 

Get Civ 5, or 6 or whatever it's at, and leave me to play my civ 3.

Story: 7/10 (Very linear but thats ok. Historic.)
Gameplay: 9/10 (Repetitive sometimes.)
Presentation: 6/10 (Old, and not really great.)
Soundtrack: X/10 (Hmm?)
Replayability: 10/10 (Keeps me coming back.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198029659220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1407993561}
review: I own both Civ III and Civ V and I would say that I enjoy Civ III more. It has a much easier learning curve than Civ V and I find it all around easier as well, plus some nice retro graphics and a very enjoyable soundtrack. My gradfather gave me vanilla Civ III and I got hours and hours of gameplay out of it, then I decided to buy the complete version on steam, and let me tell you, it DOUBLES the content of the original game. For the low price of $4.99 (and occasionally lower) I definatly recomend it. Fair waring though, in all of my games with the french as my competitors, I can safely say that they are giant, self-rightous ass holes. Never make deals with them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120307796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1593976672}
review:
Если кто-то думает, что перед вами ТА САМАЯ ЦИВИЛИЗАЦИЯ, тот будет жестоко разочарован. Ибо это "Complete"! И там стало больше не только народов и плюшек - читерства со стороны компьютера тоже стало неизмеримо больше! Игра превратилась в ад! В старую "некомплитнутую" - версию я играл совершенно спокойно на средних уровнях сложности и средней же агрессивности AI. Теперь же... второй (!) уровень сложности ставлю. Огромную карту. Казалось бы, есть где развернуться. ЩАЗ! AI плодит орды юнитов, города расползаются по континентам как метастазы... Но не это главное, и даже не то, что в боевых стычках стычках AI имеет явное преимущество - и мечник может изрубить танк. И даже не то, что ресурсов практически нет. Причём AI  от нехватки ресурсов никогда не страдает - их нет только в окрестностях ВАШЕЙ территории, и вы будете радоваться ЖЕЛЕЗУ как дару небес, ибо даже его может не быть, и у вас уже средние века, а вы вынуждены бегать с копьями. Кстати, AI не мешают ни тундры, ни пустыни, ни горы - в любых климатических условиях у него будет туча юнитов и городов! 
Но! - самое главное. Выжимаю казну в науку! В городах библиотеки и университеты! Снимаю народ с производства, чтобы те занимались наукой (чего я практически не делал в изначальной версии). Казалось бы, хотя бы в научном отношении моя цивилизация должна быть впереди планеты всей. Не тут-то было. AI не просто опережает вас - AI оставляет игрока в глубокой научной яме! Если из чудес света вам доведётся построить пирамиду - радуйтесь, ибо это, скорее всего, будет ваше первое и последнее чудо. Такой дурости в "неоткомпличенной" версии третьей Цивилизации не было! 
Вывод: игра выглядит вкусно, но на самом деле несъедобна. Рекомендуется исключительно для мазохистов и тех, кто готов эту игрушку долбить сутками, чтобы одержать хоть одну победу из десяти.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079074485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 10493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3006, 'last_played': 1655583936}
review:
So I have always slightly jokingly called Civ 3 the best civ game of all time. Jokingly. Like we all knew 4 was the real fan favourite, right?

WRONG. 

I kid you not, playing any Civ game that isn't 3 just makes me wish I was playing 3. And that's not nostalgia talking! 
Happiness? 3 handled it best. Diplomatic Victory? 3 handled it best. Governments? 3 handled them best. Combat? Troops not getting levels helps to keep things Macro, and instead troops can increase their helthbar. Soundtrack? 3s is best. Religion? Doesn't exist - religious buildings only give Culture / Happiness. That is something about subsequent games that I did like. 

Civ 3 does have one weakness, and it's pretty glaring. Group bombard. The various shortcuts for controlling large stacks works great, right up until you're using bombard units. And that can get    t e d i o u s.

...I guess the moral of the story is that I no longer joke when I say Civ 3 is the best Civ game to date.

review:
Do you have a life? Not anymore. 

Civilization 3 is great. It takes a bit of micromanaging to get things going, but once you have a few cities estabished and a decent army built, there's no need to manually select what they build each time a tas finishes or your queue empties. 

A warning: The game's tutorial mode is nicely hidden, and turning on "tutorial" isn't as helpful as it sounds. To play through the actual tutorial levels, go to "Campaigns" from the main menu. Then go to the campaigns that begin with the number 0. These levels will help a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058635054', 'num_games_owned': 2606, 'num_reviews': 339, 'playtime_forever': 11134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7032, 'last_played': 1707106362}
review: This is my favorite of the Civilization franchise because of its pace. Unlike IV and V it is easy to raise large armies and lots of cities. You don't advance through the ages so quickly, so you don't miss out on early age fun and your armies don't become prematurely obsolete. The best part of Civ3 though is the historical scenarios, which the latter Civilization games haven't done nearly as well, they alone merit replaying this game many times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035807710', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 11256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10656, 'last_played': 1585796480}
review:
This game is everything I want out of the Civilization series, even if a bit dated. The graphics have aged fairly well in my opinion, especially for a game from the very early 2000s. The old map-like aesthetic of the game's empire view is very nice, and the unit sprites are done very well for a game from a time with extremely limited graphical capabilities. One feature I especially love that I think shouldn't have been done away with in future Civilization games is the 'aerial view', which allows you to get an extremely detailed view of your cities.

However, even if the graphics are considered lackluster by some in this time, the soundtrack still holds up extremely well and is possibly the best soundtrack out of the entire Civilization series. From the piano-based melodies of the Medieval era to the jazzy guitar riffs of the Modern era, the soundtrack is extremely immersive and well-produced. Even some DLC scenarios have custom soundtracks, which are just as well-made as the soundtracks of the main game.

The gameplay is also well-done and it isn't too easy, nor is it too hard. The difficulty scaling in this game works well enough, and you are able to even change specifics such as AI aggressiveness, something that appears to be absent from later entries in the series. The advisors in this game are actually quite helpful and their associated menu screens allow you to easily get a detailed overview of your empire in order to best manage it. My only criticism of the more domestic side of gameplay is the way corruption works in this game; it tends to be quite rampant (especially on larger maps, and ESPECIALLY in the later stages of the game) although it can be reduced with wonders such as the Forbidden Palace and buildings such as courthouses.

Combat in this game is based off of an RNG system that works fairly well, although there is the occasional absolutely ludicrous outcome where a spearman will manage to defeat a tank. Unit promotions in this game work on four levels: conscript (the starting level for conscripted units as well as units gifted by villages), regular (the starting level for built units), veteran, and elite. Each promotion grants an extra bar of health. While much more simple than the extensive promotions in games such as Civilization 5, this system still works quite well as Civilization 3 tends to focus much more on wider-scale combat and empire management than single-unit powerhouses.

Overall, Civilization 3 is an excellent -- albeit, somewhat dated -- entry into the Civilization series. I'd probably give up both of my legs to see a remastering of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052225420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 811, 'last_played': 1670787290}
review:
Mein allererstes Computerspiel, und nach bald 9 Jahren spiele ich es immer noch sehr gerne, was schon etwas heißen will.
Die Grafik ist zwar definitiv nicht mehr die neueste, mich persöhnlich stört es jedoch nicht, da ich mich schon lange dran gewähnt hab, bzw. damals mein Rechner eh nicht viel mehr hätte darstellen können :D

Es läuft auch unter Windows 8.1 genau so gut, wie damals unter Win2000/XP. Nur wenn man mit der Maximalanzahl von Zivilisationen spielt, dauert es gegen Ende hin immer sehr lange, bis eine Runde berechnet wurde, was nicht an meinem Rechner liegt, sondern schlicht daran, dass die Engine (die immerhin schon um die 14 Jahre alt sein dürfte) damit überlastet sein dürfte.

Ansonsten genau das richtige Spiel für zwischendurch, nur auf die größeren Maps sollte man verzichten, wenn man nicht später in der Moderne ewig warten muss, bis man weiterspielen kann.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003878190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 833, 'playtime_forever': 5905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5777, 'last_played': 1404638007}
review:
-: menšie bugy, lišta príkazov, sporné terénne výhody, sporná UI, nedostatky vo vyjednávaní

+: grafika, audio, soundtrack, hracia doba, MP, zábava, národy a ich špecifiká, generátor máp, strom rozvoja, kultúrny a technický rozvoj, jednotky a ich počet, rozvoj miest, politické možnosti, systém hry, animácie

Verdikt: Civilization 3 je doslova a dopísmena najzábavnejšia forma dejepisu, ktorá príjemným spôsobom človeka dokáže vzdelávať. Hráčovi dokáže priblížiť podmienky a špecifiká ako sa rozvíjali jednotlivé národy v histórii. K pozitívam hry patrí audiovizuálna stránka hry, extrémna hracia doba a samotný herný systém. Naopak k negatívam patria menšie bugy a nedostatky v politike. Príkazová lišta mohla byť taktiež lepšie riešená po dizajnovej stránke. Sporné sú taktiež jednotlivé terénne podmienky a UI, čo však vynahrádza MP. Cilivization 3 je jednoducho príjemne návykový klenot.

92%

review: Ahh.. some good old turn-based action, this game is an absoloute master piece! fun and exciting gameplay, MASSIVE diversity between different civilisations, unit diversity and especially game customisation. you can practically change every aspect of the game to make it as easy or as difficult as you possibly can, you can set many ways for different civilisation victorys, adding an even deeper layer of customisability to this game. This game is a must have to any strategists steam library and i recommend this to all of my friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024984987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1610422410}
review: Big fan of this game, I've been playing for 13 years, and it's still the Civ game that I keep coming back to. IV was fine if you want to take a step into micromanagement, and V is good for a change of pace, but III is the classic Civ experience for me, and gives me just enough of what I want without being a chore to play. I don't think I'll ever stop playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065379181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1402881278}
review:
Personalmente no me gustó. A varias personas les gusta este juego ya que lo jugaron cuando era nuevo, pero por lo menos en el 2014, la forma en la que debes aprender este juego (leer el booklet) está fuera de lugar para el jugador casual. El multijugador también es escaso. 
A mí me vino en bundle, y quise jugar este juego esperando que sea más simple comparado con el Civilization V que me gustó mucho, pero después de jugar un rato intentando descifrar el uso de tecnologías, movimientos, entre otras de las muchas cosas que te tienes que ocupar en Civilization, desistí de este juego.
Si deseas dedicarle tiempo a un Civilization, yo digo que no lo dediques a este.
Pros: es un juego que corre muy bien en una PC de bajo rendimiento.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113329638', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1403776495}
review:
Personalmente ricordavo un Civilization molto diverso (io giocai al primo per puro caso e mi piacque molto). I comandi sono molto poco intuitivi e bisogna smanettare non poco per poter trasformare parzialmente il gioco in italiano e sistemare alcuni difetti grafici dato che, come vedrete, non vi sono impostazioni grafiche.
Il gioco è pieno di meccaniche non banali e il fatto che non vi sia un tutorial per insegnarvi almeno le basi crea parecchie grane per giocatori inesperti, in particolare per quelli che non traducono dall'inglese in maniera fluida e agevole (i file da leggere sono davvero tantissimi e molti pieni di termini tecnici). Nel complesso non è un brutto gioco, ma in tutta onestà penso che sia bel lontano dall'essere il migliore della sua categoria.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023368021', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 59307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19542, 'last_played': 1697051455}
review: Awesome, addictive game.  It is too easy to waste too many hours playing this game at progressively harder difficulties.  Great looking game despite its age.  It is very rewarding to try out different types of play using different civilizations on different types of maps.  Loads of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030895796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1919, 'last_played': 1583881705}
review: I fell in love with this game a long time ago. I spent countless hours playing this game and is what led me to playing both civ 4 and 5 afterwards, thus having hundreds of hours of gametime. The "one more turn" of the game seems to make me lose track of time, which may have led to less sleep than i should have had.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034611008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 10777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 90, 'playtime_at_review': 8940, 'last_played': 1710474737}
review: One of my favorite games of all time. I have fantastic memories of playing this for hours and hours as a little kid, rediscovering it in my early teens trying to force my friends to play it with me, and finally sitting in college lectures plotting world domination from my laptop instead of taking notes.It's clunky compared to the later games in some ways and not exactly balanced (you can stack units, cities have no protections without units in them, and you can decrease happiness for a few turns to get unholy amounts of money during golden ages). Overall though, this is still what I regard as the most streamlined and refined Civilization to this day. The art style is pleasing without having any extra glam, the soundtrack is ridiculously good, and the UI makes a lot of sense once you come to grips with it. This version also contains the content from the Conquests expansion pack which adds a ton of additional Civs, units, scenarios, and online play. Certainly worth $5. None of the games since have grabbed me quite as much as this one, and it was here that I first learned the power of "one more turn".

author: {'steamid': '76561198052176176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1670012321}
review:
OKay, First off, this may be a little biased as Civ 3 was the game that introduced me to the franchise. That said, It' s a solid 4X title, Graphically, it's obviously not going to be State of the Art, but I've never found that to matter with this genre; and apparently neither have most people given that one of the most popular 4X games around is Alpha Centari, which came out in 1999. 

Sorry, got a bit off topic.

Like all the Civ games, Civilization 3 puts you in control of a settler and warrior, kicks you into the oceon that is its game play and tells you to swim. The tutorial is there, but it's basically a series of tips that pop up when you start doing things. well written and concise, but they don't force your hand. Also like the other Civ games, there is a large tech tree and ages to advance through as your empire grows. The main appeal of the game is that no two playthroughs [which can take weeks to months if you play casually] are ever going to be the same. One game History may play out as you destroy the Aztecs as the Spanish... but in the next game, Gahndi might nuke your American ass into oblivion. 

Ultimately, 4X games aren't for everyone, but everyone should give the genre a try and at the price they're asking for it, Civ 3 is an affordable, still good looking, and complete introduction to the genre as well as a game that experienced players will enjoy for years to come.

[[A note on the CIv Franchise: those of you who started civ with 4 or 5 should also give 3 a try, the three titles are honestly different enough that they could be said to be equally good in their own right, assuming of course that you have the DLC for Civ 5, otherwise.... *shudders*]]

author: {'steamid': '76561198039389246', 'num_games_owned': 1213, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1399532686}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025495184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1444612138}
review:
Although the game is over a decade old, its gameplay, mechanics, and tactical strategies manage to please and challenge strategy gamers, especially within the harder difficulty levels.

The highlights within the game include a wide array of civilizations to choose from around the world and throughout history, a refined isometric perspective from its precedessor, unique qualities to match your gameplay style, and challenging gameplay tactics as you progress through its difficulty. The Complete Edition also features a Conquests version for increased replayability that focuses on your tactical thinking without rapid reactions.

Within the negative aspects of the game, the AI seems a bit limited on handling some of its positive attributes or buffs (normally happens with harder difficulty levels), meaning that it has no idea how to handle its resources efficiently, thus limiting gameplay challenge compared to later Civilization games.  Furthermore, it is difficult to establish friendships and allies within the game, as every opponent seems to collide against you (in the World War II map, even England is your enemy if you select the United States as your civilization), also limiting attaining diplomatic victories.

Overall, the game remains strong based on its design and gameplay, and at an inexpensive price, you really cannot go wrong, especially when there is a discount lurking from time to time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965079839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1402751064}
review:
Civ III, Oldie but Goldie. Trotz seines hohen Alters und der eher mageren Grafik, ist Civ III für mich bis heute der beste Teil der Serie. Auch wenn Teil 4 und 5 mit besserer Grafik und vielen Möglichkeiten aufwarten, überzeugt mich Civ III bis heute durch seine Einfachheit. Jedes Volk hat seine Schwächen und Stärken, man kann seine Taktiken wählen und spielen und es bleibt immer fair. Ein einzelne Partie kann schnell mal mehr als 10Std dauern und das nicht trotz sondern gerade wegen der Einfachheit, denn das komplexe bleibt verborgen und das finde ich angenehm, man muss sich nicht total reinknien, das Spiel sorgt dafür das man es unbewusst selber macht.
Für mich ist und bleibt es das beste Rundenstrategiespiel der Welt!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017988710', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2625, 'last_played': 1400997912}
review:
Let me say that this was my first Civilization game, and for being on sale for $5, I am sure I would buy the game again.

If you're new or interested in Civilization games, I HIGHLY recommend reading further and/or watching videos to understand what you are getting into:

Pros-

This game is highly detailed and allows for a significant amount of strategy-management decisions. Learning the system and "how to beat it" itself was an enjoyable that I still can't fully claim to have achieved.

Cons-

There is no help in-game in actually learning the game. This will either add hours of patience in learning the game, or frustration.

The computer AI is abhorrent for trading.

Fair Warning: This game is SLOW. I am okay about slow games, when I am mentally prepared for it. This game is so slow, whether due to micromanagement, organizing your thoughts, or constant unit/city decisions. In my opinion, the pacing of this game is not evidence of a detailed well thought out game (which yes, it is), but of a poorly designed game. Even in "speed-mode"...just ugh, it's still slow.


I suggest that if you are interested in a strategic, decision-making game, and ok with long games, the Civilization games will suit your needs. Furthermore, I suggest looking into Galactic Civilizations, at the least for the sake of a real tutorial.

Again, if you're new to these games, do your research and check out other people's opinions before diving into the Civilization world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049267390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 5060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4954, 'last_played': 1708443949}
review:
Это отличная игра, одна из лучших 4Х, низкий порог вхождения, понятная и рабочая механика, графика все еще держится и "скэйлится" под любой монитор. Но... 

Здесь архичудовищный ИИ. Ничего подобного вы нигде больше не видели. Представьте себе качка на стероидах в бешенстве размахивающего руками налево и направо вместо того, чтобы боксировать - это ИИ в Civ3. Он читерит в чернейшую. ИИ имеет + 100% ко всему на ЛЮБЫХ сложностях. У него бесконечные деньги, у него нет коррупции. Чтобы ты понял - здесь минимальный уровень сложности равен 6-7 уровню в Civ5 и Civ6. Чем больше у ИИ пространства, тем больше у него преимуществ. Более того - забудьте о союзах. ИИ воюет исключительно против ВАС. Они не воюют друг с другом. И это очень печально. Играл только на ностальжи. 

Настоящая классика это четверка. Civ3 же это это не стратегия, это симулятор выживания. Любите жесткий спенкинг? Вам сюда.

A very complex and interesting game. First play through I was a little confused what was going on and it took a lot of reading of the game index to understand what each upgraded item was, but after a while it was up and running and found it good fun.
This is a real time stealer of a game and after 4 hours building up my army and cities I was finally beaten by 3 civ's teaming up and raiding me... but thats how it goes! The larger your army gets the harder it is to defend.
A fantastic game and loads to it. Should keep you entertained for a good few months ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054498379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1577815312}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III стала для меня одной из первой игр которой я увлекся всерьез и надолго.
Все началось в далеком 2005 году. Я, новоиспеченый первокласник начал стремительно знакомится с людьми с которымы мне в последствии пришлось учится девять веселых и местами не очень веселых лет. Первым из тех с кем я познакомился стал Григорий (Tovarish_Chel) Топилин. Он и дал мне диск с цивилизацией. Диск был как я только недавно начал понимать, пиратский и на нем были изображены скелеты, рыцари, маги и прочая магическая ерунда. Когда я установил игру, я думал что мне придется узреть разного вида фэнтэзийную стратегию, но в место этого я увидел вполне нормальные, существующие страны, их лидеров и настройки мира. Как сейчас помню: создал я мир, играл за греков... А затем в Афинах начался бунт. Я понятия не имел по какой причине это произошло: само проийти, не проходило. Залезаю в окно города, а там написано что жители города недовольны. Я залез в цивилопедию и попытался узнать как решить эту проблему, но мои скромные на тот момент времени познания в английском языке не дали мне этого сделать. Бомбонуло знатно :) 
В 2008 я на сбереженные деньги купил лицензионное золотое издание. Это была игра в которой я мог зависать часами просто играя в одном мире. как я и говорил позже мой комп скопытился и отправился на свалку истории.
И только в 2014 году я вспомнил про такую замечательную игру. Одна из немногих игр которую я купил без скидок, за 200 рублей. Сейчас я тоже мог бы сидеть и играть в этот шедевр многими часами но друзья Александр (DragonBite) Ярославцев, Александр (Y_alex_Y) Терминов, Александр (DeeeeeMON) Куценко и Михаил (Die) Соломко регулярно зовут меня в дотку.

Общая оценка 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198104790615', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 2685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1705790999}
review:
For a game made all the way back in October 2001, this is a fantastic game.

First off, if you bought Civilization Revolution for the Xbox 360 or iPad, that is nothing compared to this old but fantastic game.
Secondly, make sure you play this when you havn't got anything else to do in the next 24 hours because this game takes some time and patients and you are guranteed to get 100% addicted.
However, if you want to go online, nobody will be on there and if you host a server nobody will join (unless, of course, one of your friends have the game and you invite them). Also, on your first game you ever play, make sure you make it so it's on the easiest difficulty and do a little amount of Civilizations otherwise you will get brutally battered like a Cod fish.

10 features Civilization 3 has that Civilization Revolution Doesn't

1. You can alter the map size between Tiny and Huge.
2. You can alter the settings on how to win the game.
3. The Middle Age is included.
4. You get workers to build Outposts, Mines, Barricades, Irrigation (farm/food resources) etc.
5. There is more research.
6. More units.
7. Create your own map in the editor.
8. Edit the map properties.
9. More Civilizations.
10. More Civilizations allowed to be active in game.

Keep in mind that Civilization Revolution is newer than Civilization 3.
I can't really think of anything you can't do in Civilization 3 that you can in Civilization Revolution.
I cannot compare Civilization 3 to Civilization 2, 4 and 5 as I do not have those and I have never played them. I would assume that Civilization 4 and 5 are better though.
I completely reccomend this game and I'd say it is still a brilliant game now in 2014 and that takes a lot for a game to be that good!

Hope this makes you want to buy Civilization 3 because it deserves more buyers. This game is also very handy if you have have a bad Graphics Card and Processor like my computer. When it says it runs on Windows XP only it really means Windows XP or better. Happy Gaming!

review:
Probably one of my most enjoyable strategy games of all time (even at this moment). Sure this is an old game but don't let it sway you from getting this. At first the game may feel confusing, and you may lose; if you put the time to learn it, you have lots of fun destroying civilizations, making allies, and many more!

By the way, theres many mods and scenarios you can try out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037285856', 'num_games_owned': 4306, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 17261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14366, 'last_played': 1444562012}
review:
Definitiv einer meiner all-time-favourites!Civ3 ist ein Zeitfresser wie kaum ein anderes Spiel,nur kurz 1-2 Runden spielen geht einfach nicht.Irgendwas ist immer,der bisher friedliche Nachbar greift eine junge Siedlung an,man beendet eine wichtige Forschung,die Invasionsflotte ist nur noch einen Zug vom Anlegen ans Feindland entfernt....und schon ist es wieder Mitternacht.
So oder so ähnlich sieht eine typische Civ3 Partie aus, es gibt immer zig Dinge zu erledigen und es fällt oftmals schwer abzuschalten weil man quasi nie „fertig“ ist.Klar gibt es diverse Siegbedingungen,zum Beispiel Kultursieg oder einfach eine feste Anzahl Runden doch die KI rüstet erstaunlich gut mit und schenkt einem nichts.
Während man die eigene Zivilisation gedeihen lässt muss man abwägen die Nachbarn diplomatisch zu behandeln oder zu vernichten.Krieg scheint im ersten Augenblick die schlechtere Option da es die eigene Forschung bremst und andere Zivilisationen technologisch davonziehen doch nur auf Freundschaft und Handel kann man sich auch nicht verlassen.Ist man nicht bereit zu tauschen drohen die werten Nachbarn auch gerne mal mit Krieg wenn man keine Militäreinheiten zur Abschreckung hat.Und spätestens wenn Gandhi mit Atomschlägen droht(nein kein Scherz!) merkt man das die Lage ernst ist.
Dazu kommen noch Probleme wie Vulkanausbrüche und Seuchen(je nach Karte) und später in der Moderne muss man die Luftverschmutzung unter Kontrolle halten,damit Wirtschaft und Wohlstand gesichert sind.Denn die braven Bürger wollen zufrieden gestellt werden sonst laufen sie im schlimmsten Fall zum Nachbarn/Feind über wenn dieser besser über seine Untertanen herrscht.
Zugegeben sind die Optionen am Anfang etwas überwältigend,eventuell sogar abschreckend und das Civ3 nur auf Englisch verfügbar ist macht es nicht unbedingt leichter aber wenn man sich die Zeit nimmt sich „reinzuspielen“ kann man extrem viel Spaß damit haben.
Interessant ist auch die eingebaute Datenbank,die zu jeder Nation,Technologie,Einheit,Persönlichkeit und Regierungsform im Spiel Wissen liefert(wenn auch nur in Textform),es soll also keiner behaupten das man in Videospielen nichts lernt!

Nach...viel zu vielen Stunden kann ich dieses Strategiemeisterwerk jedem ans Herz legen,der das Genre mag.Nur ein Tip für das erste Spiel;Nehmt euch eine Woche Urlaub! ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043359936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8752, 'last_played': 1527447075}
review: This has to be the game that I loved the most growing up. Offline and previously owned I have well over 500 hours on this game and I tell you now it has still stood the test of time. You can play this casually or relentlessly and still have the consistent experience of both enjoyment and replayability. Admittingly the AI is a tad bit off and, at the lower difficult, complete push overs but still competent to give you a challenging yet fun experience; plus Ghandi nuked me. 10/10 would be nuked again. You would be silly to not to spend the whole whopping 5 bucks to experience this phenom of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996743017', 'num_games_owned': 922, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 12902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 52, 'playtime_at_review': 5533, 'last_played': 1709695124}
review:
My favorite Civilization game, despite its flaws and quirks. I spent a good 10+ years playing this particular entry, and even own multiple copies of it in various forms. (3 to be exact!) 

I'm a real power gamer when it comes to turn based strategy, and I've always found everything in Civ III to be very easy to minmax. Maybe that comes from over ten years of experience with the game. But I just can't truly get bored of this. Even if I do own Civ IV and V I still find myself going back to III on occasion. I want to chalk it up to it being a good game and not just my own nostalgia.

For $5 (and under during sales) this is a really good deal and you can't really go wrong with Civilization, now can you?

author: {'steamid': '76561198119555956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 31533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4515, 'last_played': 1708664108}

review: Ciertamente los juegos de Civilization tienen una complejidad muy amplia que hace que mucha gente no se acerque a ellos, sin embargo los que encontramos en los juegos de Civilization un reto alto y  para jugar turno por turno pensando con calma cada movimiento de nuestras tropas, nuestras alianzas estratégicas y no malgastar el dinero, encontramos la satifacción en cada partida ganada, como un buen juego de estrategia. Y mi favorito sobre todos es Civ 3 complete. Para mí el mejor juego de Civilization que he jugado.

{'steamid': '76561198060500274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1448134079}
review:
This game was my first TBS. A guy I worked with talked about it, and I bought it. This was a few months before Civ IV came out.  I became a bit obsessed. We even had a play-by-email game going for a while. 

I have no idea how many hours I put into it, but it was a lot. I think I've bought it three times since then. I still love the game. I'm far more likely to play Civ V now, but I just like knowing that Civ III is there, any time I want to play it. Civ III was my gateway game to AoE, RoN, AoM... all of which I have also bought multiple times and currently have installed on my computer.

Yes, most of my warm fuzzy feelings may be simply nostalgia, but I do think the game still has a lot to offer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112485951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1394308354}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980248511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1584184834}
review:
Любимая Цивилизация среди всех игр в серии - в своё время проводил в ней дни и ночи.
Однозначно рекомендую всем (и не только любителям пошаговых стратегий).
P.S.
Маленькая хитрость:
Для того чтобы играть в игру с высоким разрешением, зайдите в папку "(путь до Steam)\SteamApps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete\Conquests" и откройте там файл "conquests.ini". В конец открытого файла "conquests.ini" вставьте строчку "keepres=1" и сохраните изменения. Теперь после запуска в игре будет "родное" разрешение вашего рабочего стола: например, если у вас выставлено разрешение 1920x1080, то и в игре будет Full HD (кроме видороликов).

author: {'steamid': '76561197994553330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1404482290}
review:
All Civilization games are awesome. This is my own personal favourite (i have not played 1 or 2).
Each one takes something away and adds something new.
I prefer this one because there are less factors you have to worry about, 4 is just missing something 'MAGIC'. I do love 5 but 3 is just slightly better (for me).
If you're new to Civilization games, it may be worth you starting with 5 because I imagine peoples personal favourites are the first ones they try.

A full game of civilization (3,4, or 5) can take several days. Obviously you can save and come back to it later. You need to play this game for at least 4 hours before you can learn to like it

author: {'steamid': '76561198031565431', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1394112759}
review:
A little less than a decade ago, this game got me started on the whole Civilization series. It was definitely a life-changer: after many years of playing, I liked it so much that when Civ 4 came out I still preferred 3 over the new one. The map editor included with the game is very straightforward to use - that's always a plus with any game. (cf. StarCraft) I used to use it to do things like editing the Earth map so that all the civs start at their actual capital locations. Oh what fun I had over the years, not only standing the test of time but also writing my own world history...

Now that I am well and truly a Civ 5 player, I doubt I'll ever go back to this game; but this game is definitely worth a play if you have never played any of the Civilization games before. While I do recommend that you start with the latest title, it could also be a good idea to start at 3 and work your way up, see how things have changed over the past decade.

... Just don't come blaming me 5 hours later asking where all your time has gone after just a few "short" turns.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073976105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1675028565}
review:
I have been playing Civ 3 since I was... hm... actually I'm not entirely sure. It's been a really long time. When it went on sale on the Humble Bundle, I had to get it. The game is simple enough that I could play and enjoy it on the lowest difficulty as a little kid, but complex enough that if you don't think about what you're doing on a higher difficulty setting, you will screw up.

I'm currently taking a World Politics class at my college, and I'm constantly realizing just how spot on with how the world operates that the Civilization series as a whole is. Dealing with your citizens while at the same time maintaining foreign relations. Making sure you don't owe the other civs too much. Deciding how much funding you want in each and every little thing...

*Sigh* It's a good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118956190', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5990, 'last_played': 1414850313}
review: This is an amazing game. It's difficult to pick up, but once you understand how everything works, it comes together beautifully. The graphics aren't very good, but considering it was released in 2001, it's quite impressive. The music is not even as close to good as Civ 4, but it's still a very worthwhile game, especially if you only want to spend $5 instead of $30. The best part is, all the stratgies you used in one difficulty, may fail you in the next. There are also interesting scenarios, such as World War II in the Pacific. The game mechanics make everything so interesting. The game is well balanced, so you have to consider what each action you take may cost you. (Like nuking your neighbors.) If you want a cheap, good game that you can play for hours, Civ 3 is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999363847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 11412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9027, 'last_played': 1641421694}
review:
While it may not be able to compete graphically with newer Civilization games, it still keeps it's charm after all these years.

Because it is a Voxel/Sprite based game, making models is simple enough(and I say that due to me seeing a good 8-10 models pumped out a month compared to Civ IV and CIv V's model sections on Civ Fanatics)

the scenario editor is where all the fun is though, want to make a scenario based on a Colonial Marine Invasion of Xenomorph Prime? DO IT!, want to have Skynet and the Resistance fight a war ALL OVER THE GLOBE?! do it! ever wondered how the UNSC would fare against the Imperium of Man or the Galactic Empire? you can do it!

there is so much can be done with the scenario editor, and if that's not enough for you, some wonderful programmers at CivFanatics have made an expanded Civ scenario editor.


new note:"I'm going to conquer Russia before I go to bed!" 3 hours later:"two more turns and I'll have conquered Rome and China!" 1 hour later:"my clock says 3AM... oh well, time to finish my conquest of the world, MONTEZUMA YOU WILL BURN!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198027405620', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 23752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8089, 'last_played': 1650685350}
review:
If you love the wargame aspect of the CIVILIZATION games, this game still has a lot to offer.  I put in a lot of hours in the last two weeks.  Domination games ran about 48 hrs on the lowest setting, longer at higher settings where one must think more about each move, for those who like to micromanage....keep cranking up the difficulty level.   Sorry, CIV I and II fans.  No more Diplomat units.  A very different experience than CIV IV, which became awesome with all the fine mods available.  I admit. This game hits my Turn-Based-Strategy  sweet spot for kicking back and wargaming.  One of the best "old" computer games I bought in the last year, not because I did not have it already; because for $5 I got to play an apparently bug  free game inside of 5 minutes on Windows 7 and no making it run on a VM virtual machine.  Gets my Happy Camper award.

MAJOR IRRITATING PROBLEM:  From the origional, after a unit moves, the game jumps to the next (not nearest) unit that may be half a world away.  There is no way to stop and look at what your just-moved unit saw without scrolling to find it.  This becomes very irritating after a while.  I had forgotten about it.  It is not a bug, it is programming design.  This got fixed in later games so the game paused after each unit moves, allowing you to stay in an area and complete a battle before moving on by hitting a key when YOU are ready.  Think of a scar on Mona Lisa's face.   Think of a good movie that periodically stutters, jumps or freezes.   Oh, wait.  I already have that.  Verison FIOS, may the gods bless their awesome up and download speeds.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972420953', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1538758066}
review:
Probabilmente il più completo e divertente della serie, anche se personalmente ho un debole per il secondo capitolo! (e anche per l'estrema semplicità del primo che lo rende molto immediato).
Niente 3D inutile e fastidioso come nel IV e V, leggero e veloce, sa anche essere competitivo a difficoltà alte, ha diversi scenari e modalità.... e la regola del "ancora un turno soltanto e poi spengo" regna sovrana!

Ci ho perso innumerevoli ore, ma puntualmente un gioco della serie finisce reinstallato almeno una volta l'anno! Imperdibile! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197983601366', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1612807340}
review:
Civilization 3 is the third installement in the popular turn-based strategy series and personally my favorite. 

First of all this title still holds up tremendously well nowadays, it runs on newer operation systems and you can tweak the resolution in a file making the game really great to play. There aren't any issues at all.

Civ3 is not as complex as Civ4 and doesn't have such intricate indepth mechanics but still manages to keep the player busy, you have to manage several aspects of your empire. The more streamlined gameplay makes this Civilization my favorite, it's easy to understand but yet very hard to master. You get down the basics really fast but in order to be good at it, you need some serious practise. There are tons of different civilizations to choose from and many different scenarios. The included expansion offer even more content. The AI is really good and easily challenge you, even on lower difficulties. 

The visuals are also nicely presented, the 2d sprites look good and have a more realistic touch. The soundtrack and soundassets are also amazing and do a great job immersing yourself into the game.

Overall this is just an well designed game and incredibly enjoyable. I recommend this game a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977256794', 'num_games_owned': 2959, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 3951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2529, 'last_played': 1691708787}
review:
Played Civ 4, then Civ 5, then Civ 3, along with seeing Civ 1 and 2 played afterward.

Out of all of them? Civ 3 is by far my favorite.  There's just something about it that makes me enjoy it far more than the others.

Not so much a review but a "I played other Civs first and love this one to death", showing that you don't become attached to games you play before others.

Don't forget you can increase the game's resolution via an ini edit; makes this dated game not so dated anymore and actually pleasing to play (eye strain wise) on high resolution monitors.
